![Product eCommerce focuses on profitability and customer experience](image2)

The levels of confidence and likelihood in the document are evaluated based on the type, amount, quality, strength, and consistency of evidence, as well as the degree of expert agreement on the findings [9]. Confidence is expressed qualitatively, ranging from *low confidence* (inconclusive evidence or disagreement among experts) to *very high confidence* (strong evidence and high consensus) [9, 12]. 

![Confidence levels are evaluated based on evidence and expert agreement, ranging from low to very high](image8) 

Likelihood, on the other hand, is described in probabilistic terms, ranging from *very unlikely* (less than or equal to a 1 in 10 chance) to *very likely* (greater than or equal to a 9 in 10 chance) [3]. 

![Likelihood levels are expressed probabilistically, ranging from very unlikely to very likely](image4) 

Both confidence and likelihood levels are determined through expert assessment and consensus by the chapter author teams, who evaluate the available literature, the quality and quantity of evidence, and the level of agreement across studies [11]. The Traceable Accounts in each chapter provide additional details on the rationale behind these assessments [5].

Perceptions of political parties' ethics and extremism vary significantly across different educational and political affiliation groups. 

![Equal shares of Republicans and Democrats say their own party has good policy ideas, while fewer believe the opposing party does.](image1)  
Public views on ethical standards are divided, with 41% of Americans saying the GOP has high ethical standards, while 42% say this about the Democratic Party [4]. Among independents, 34% believe neither party meets high ethical standards, compared to 19% of Republicans and 18% of Democrats [5]. 

![College-educated individuals are more likely to say neither party has high ethical standards.](image10)  
Those with at least a college degree are more critical, with 31% stating that neither party upholds high ethical standards, while 43% believe it describes one party but not the other, and 17% think it applies to both [10].

![Partisans are more likely to view the opposing party as extreme.](image11)  
Regarding extremism, 48% of Americans view the Republican Party as “too extreme,” compared to 42% for the Democratic Party [8]. Partisans are deeply divided, with about three-quarters of Republicans and Democrats viewing the opposing party as too extreme, while only about two-in-ten say this about their own party [11].

In summary, perceptions of ethics and extremism differ by education and political affiliation, with independents and college-educated individuals more critical of both parties, and partisans more likely to view the opposing party as extreme.

Perceptions of ethical standards and extremism between the Republican and Democratic parties show nuanced differences, often influenced by education and political affiliation. About 41% of Americans say the GOP has high ethical standards, while 42% say this about the Democratic Party, indicating similar views overall [1][4]. However, independents are more critical, with 34% saying neither party has high ethical standards, compared to just 19% of Republicans and 18% of Democrats [5]. Those with at least a college degree are more likely to believe neither party meets ethical standards (31%), whereas fewer with some college (26%) or a high school education or less (20%) share this view [3][12]. 

![Breakdown of ethical standards by education and political affiliation](image4)

When it comes to extremism, more Americans view the Republican Party as “too extreme” (48%) than the Democratic Party (42%) [7]. Partisans are highly polarized, with about three-quarters of Republicans and Democrats viewing the opposing party as too extreme, while only around 20% say this about their own party [11]. These perceptions are influenced by political affiliation, as Republicans and Democrats overwhelmingly believe their own party has good policy ideas (over 80%), while less than a quarter say this about the opposing party [11].

![Comparison of extremism perceptions between parties](image1)

In summary, while ethical standards are viewed similarly across parties, perceptions of extremism are more pronounced for the GOP, and both metrics are heavily shaped by education and political affiliation.

Perceptions of ethical standards and political party preferences show notable variations across education levels and political affiliations. Among college graduates, nearly a third (31%) say that "high ethical standards" describe neither the Republican Party nor the Democratic Party, while 43% believe it applies to one party but not the other, and 17% think it describes both [5][10]. Those with some college experience or a high school degree or less are less likely to hold this view, with 26% and 20%, respectively, saying neither party has high ethical standards [12].

Independents are significantly more likely than partisans to say neither party has high ethical standards, with about a third (34%) holding this view, compared to only about 19% of Republicans and 18% of Democrats [9]. ![College graduates are more likely to view neither party as ethical](image5)

In terms of political preferences, those with a postgraduate degree favor Democratic candidates over Republican candidates by roughly two-to-one (62% to 30%), while those with a four-year college degree also lean Democratic (53% to 40%). Preferences are more divided among voters without a college degree [8]. ![Postgraduate degree holders strongly favor Democratic candidates](image3)

These trends highlight how educational attainment and political affiliation shape perceptions of ethical standards and influence party preferences.

Public perceptions of Trump’s handling of economic policy and his ethical standards vary significantly across political groups. A majority of the public (53%) expresses at least some confidence in Trump’s ability to make good decisions about economic policy, while 46% have little or no confidence [6]. ![Public confidence in Trump’s economic policy decisions is mixed](image1)

However, views on Trump’s ethical standards are deeply divided by party affiliation. Among Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals, 75% rate the administration’s ethical standards as high, while 86% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning individuals view them negatively [9]. ![Partisan divide in perceptions of Trump’s ethical standards](image8)

Notably, within the Republican Party, moderate and liberal Republicans are more critical of Trump’s ethical standards, with 36% rating them as not good or poor, compared to just 15% of conservative Republicans [5]. ![Divergent views on ethical standards within the Republican Party](image8)

In summary, while Trump receives relatively mixed confidence on economic policy, perceptions of his ethical standards are sharply polarized, with Republicans largely supportive and Democrats overwhelmingly critical. ![Polarized views on Trump’s ethical standards](image4)

Public confidence in Trump’s handling of economic policy has seen a modest increase since January 2018, rising from 46% to 53% [10]. Similarly, confidence in his ability to handle an international crisis has also grown, with 43% expressing confidence in May 2018 compared to 35% in January [12]. These improvements are primarily driven by increased confidence among Republicans. For instance, Republican confidence in Trump’s crisis management has risen from 73% in January to 84% in May 2019 [9]. ![Public confidence in Trump's handling of economic policy and international crises has increased, particularly among Republicans.](image3)

However, public opinion remains deeply divided along partisan lines. While Republicans overwhelmingly support Trump’s economic and crisis management decisions, Democrats remain skeptical. Only 46% of the public expresses little or no confidence in Trump’s economic policy decisions, while 53% express some confidence [7]. On international crises, 54% of the public has little or no confidence in Trump [6]. ![Partisan divides remain stark, with Republicans supporting Trump and Democrats expressing skepticism.](image6)

Overall, while public confidence in Trump’s economic and crisis management abilities has improved, it remains polarized, with Republicans increasingly supportive and Democrats largely critical.

Public confidence in Trump’s ability to handle economic policy and international crises has seen notable changes over time. In January 2018, 46% of the public expressed confidence in his ability to handle economic policy, which increased to 53% by May 2018 [5][9]. Similarly, confidence in his ability to handle an international crisis rose from 35% in January to 43% by May 2018 [4][6]. This upward trend is particularly pronounced among Republicans and Republican-leaning independents, whose confidence in Trump’s crisis handling increased from 73% in January to 84% by May 2018 [11].

![Confidence in Trump’s ability to handle economic policy and international crises increased from January to May 2018](image2)

When it comes to overall sentiment toward Trump’s conduct, Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals are more favorable than Democrats. Roughly 38% of Republicans say they like Trump’s conduct, while 45% have mixed feelings and 16% disapprove [2]. Conservative Republicans are even more supportive, with 44% approving of his conduct compared to 25% of moderate or liberal Republicans [1]. In contrast, Democrats overwhelmingly disapprove of Trump’s conduct, with 85% saying they do not like it, and only 5% expressing approval [8].

![Republican and Democrat sentiment toward Trump’s conduct shows a stark divide](image5)

In summary, while public confidence in Trump’s economic and international crisis management has improved, Republican support for his conduct remains much stronger than Democratic disapproval, highlighting a significant partisan divide.

Public confidence in Donald Trump’s ability to handle an international crisis has increased since January, with 43% expressing confidence in May 2018, up from 35% in January. This is still lower than the 48% who expressed confidence in April 2017. ![Confidence in Trump's ability to handle an international crisis has risen slightly since January](image8) 

In contrast, confidence in Trump’s ability to make good decisions about economic policy has also increased, with 53% expressing confidence in May 2018, up from 46% in January. ![Confidence in Trump's economic policy decisions has risen moderately since January](image8) 

While both areas have seen an uptick in confidence, economic policy consistently garners higher confidence levels compared to handling international crises. The gap between the two has narrowed slightly over time, but economic policy remains the stronger area of public trust.  

Overall, public confidence in Trump’s handling of both international crises and economic policy has improved since January, though economic policy continues to be viewed more favorably.

Opinions among Republicans and Democrats regarding Trump’s conduct and the ethical standards of his administration have shown notable shifts and consistencies over time. Among Republicans and Republican leaners, approval of Trump’s conduct has increased, with 80% now saying they agree with him on many or all issues, up 11 percentage points from August 2017 [12]. However, within the party, there are ideological divides: 44% of conservative Republicans like his conduct, compared to 25% of moderate or liberal Republicans [6]. Additionally, 36% of moderate or liberal Republicans rate the ethical standards of Trump administration officials as not good or poor, while only 15% of conservative Republicans share this view [11].

![Ethical standards ratings among Republicans and Democrats](image3) shows that 86% of Democrats and Democratic leaners rate the ethical standards of Trump administration officials as not good or poor, with 61% considering them poor.

Among Democrats, disapproval of Trump’s conduct remains high and consistent, with 85% saying they do not like the way he conducts himself [3]. This sentiment is particularly strong among liberal Democrats, 93% of whom give low marks to the administration’s ethical standards [10].

![Views on Trump's conduct among Republicans and Democrats](image6) highlights the divergence in opinions, with 80% of Republicans and leaners expressing approval, while 85% of Democrats and leaners disapprove.

Overall, while Republicans have grown more aligned with Trump on policy issues, their views on his conduct and ethical standards remain split along ideological lines. Democrats, meanwhile, have maintained a consistently critical stance, with little change in their disapproval over time.

Approval ratings of the Trump administration officials’ ethical standards are notably lower compared to those of past administrations. According to [1] and [11], only 39% of Americans rate the ethical standards of Trump administration officials as excellent or good, while 58% rate them as not good or poor. This is significantly lower than ratings for previous administrations, as highlighted in [11], which notes that these ratings are the lowest since the question was first asked during Ronald Reagan’s administration in 1983. ![Comparison of ethical ratings across administrations](image7)

Public approval of Trump’s job performance is mixed and closely tied to these ethical evaluations. [3] indicates that Trump’s job approval ratings have remained relatively stable and are roughly on par with those at the start of his presidency. However, [4] shows that disapproval is more intense, with 42% of the public disapproving of Trump’s job performance very strongly. Additionally, [6] and [8] reveal demographic divides, with men, whites, and older adults more likely to approve of Trump’s performance, while women, younger adults, non-whites, and those with higher education levels are more likely to disapprove. ![Public disapproval of Trump’s job performance](image8)

The connection between ethical standards and job performance is further emphasized by [12], where 86% of Democrats rate the ethical standards of Trump officials as not good or poor, compared to 75% of Republicans who rate them as good or excellent. This stark partisan divide mirrors the broader public’s polarized views on Trump’s job performance. ![Partisan views on ethical standards](image3)

In summary, the Trump administration’s ethical standards are rated lower than those of past administrations, and this negative perception is closely linked to the public’s divided and often critical views of Trump’s job performance.

Educational levels and political affiliations significantly shape perceptions of ethical standards and approval ratings of Donald Trump. Among those with higher education, such as college graduates or postgraduates, disapproval of Trump is notably higher (62% and 68% respectively) compared to those with some college education (53%) or a high school degree or less (49%) ![Disapproval and approval rates by education level](image1). This trend aligns with their skepticism toward both political parties’ ethical standards, as 31% of those with at least a college degree believe neither the Republican Party nor the Democratic Party has high ethical standards, while 43% think it describes one party but not the other [12].

Political affiliation is another critical factor. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents overwhelmingly approve of Trump (81% and 89% respectively), while Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents strongly disapprove (88% and 93% respectively) ![Disapproval and approval rates by political affiliation](image1). Independents, particularly those who lean Democratic, are significantly more likely (88%) to rate the Trump administration’s ethical standards as “not good” or “poor” compared to Republican-leaning independents (67% rate them as “excellent” or “good”) [7]. Additionally, independents are more likely (34%) to say neither party has high ethical standards, compared to 19% of Republicans and 18% of Democrats [9].

In summary, higher education correlates with greater disapproval of Trump and skepticism about both parties’ ethics, while political affiliation strongly influences approval ratings and perceptions of ethical standards in the Trump administration.

Voter reactions to the 2016 U.S. presidential election differed significantly from previous elections, particularly in terms of emotional responses and general sentiments. In 2016, only 50% of voters said they were happy about Donald Trump’s victory, while 48% were unhappy. This is slightly less positive than reactions to Barack Obama’s re-election in 2012, when 52% were happy, and notably lower than 2008, when 58% expressed happiness about Obama’s first win [2]. ![Half of voters were happy with Trump’s election, but less positive than Obama’s 2008 victory.](image5)  

Emotionally, reactions to Trump’s election were mixed. While 51% of voters felt hopeful about his presidency, 36% felt proud, and many reported feeling uneasy [9]. These emotions were less uniformly positive compared to 2008, when 69% of voters felt hopeful about Obama’s election, and only 35% felt uneasy [12]. ![Voters expressed hopefulness, pride, and unease about Trump’s election.](image2)  

The 2016 election also stood out for its surprise factor. A striking 73% of voters were surprised by Trump’s victory, including 87% of Clinton supporters and 60% of Trump voters [3]. ![Most voters, especially Clinton supporters, were surprised by Trump’s victory.](image8)  

Additionally, the 2016 campaign was viewed more negatively than past elections. Voters criticized the conduct of the candidates, parties, press, and pollsters, with negative assessments reaching higher levels than in any election since 1988 [4]. ![Voters viewed the 2016 campaign more negatively than previous elections.](image6)  

In summary, voter reactions to Trump’s 2016 victory were less positive than those to Obama’s elections, with surprise, hopefulness, and unease being the most prevalent emotions.

Emotional reactions to Trump’s election starkly differ between Trump and Clinton voters. Among Trump supporters, 96% feel hopeful, and 74% feel proud, reflecting widespread optimism about his presidency [3][7]. ![Trump voters are overwhelmingly hopeful and proud about his election](image5). In contrast, Clinton voters express overwhelmingly negative emotions: 90% feel uneasy, 77% feel sad, 76% feel scared, and 62% feel angry [7][12]. ![Clinton voters feel uneasy, sad, scared, and angry about Trump’s election](image3).

There’s also a notable difference in their expectations of Trump’s first term. An overwhelming 97% of Trump voters expect his first term to be successful, with 88% confident about the kind of president he will be [6][11]. ![Trump voters are highly confident and expect a successful first term](image6). Conversely, Clinton voters hold far more pessimistic views: only 15% believe his first term will be successful, while 76% expect it to be unsuccessful [9]. ![Clinton voters overwhelmingly expect Trump’s first term to be unsuccessful](image7). These contrasting emotions and expectations highlight the deep partisan divide in reactions to Trump’s election and his presidency.

Perspectives on the potential success of Trump’s first term and the willingness to give him a chance are sharply divided between Trump and Clinton voters. Among Trump voters, an overwhelming 97% expect him to have a successful first term, mirroring the 92% of Obama voters who felt similarly about their candidate in 2008 [9]. In contrast, just 15% of Clinton voters believe Trump’s first term will be successful, with 76% expecting it to be unsuccessful [10].

![Most Trump voters are confident about his upcoming presidency](image2) This confidence is further reflected in Trump voters’ attitudes, as 88% are confident about the kind of president he will be, while only 10% have serious concerns [12]. Clinton voters, however, are more skeptical; 39% say they cannot give Trump a chance “because of the kind of person he has shown himself to be,” though 58% are willing to see how he governs [1][11].

![Clinton voters are divided in their willingness to give Trump a chance](image3) Additionally, Trump voters overwhelmingly believe he will prioritize the needs of all Americans (84%), while 75% of Clinton voters think he will favor his supporters [3]. These contrasting views highlight the deep polarization in expectations and openness toward Trump’s presidency.

Trump and Clinton voters differ significantly in their priorities for Trump’s presidency, reflecting contrasting views on his leadership and vision. For Trump voters, the top priorities are health care (29%), the economy (15%), and immigration (15%) [9][10]. Many Trump supporters specifically want to repeal the Affordable Care Act, emphasizing a desire for policy changes in line with Trump’s campaign promises [10]. 

In contrast, Clinton voters prioritize unifying the country (12%) and changing Trump’s personal behavior (11%) [6]. They are less focused on policy areas like health care (12%) and more concerned with addressing divisions and healing the country after a contentious election [6]. Clinton voters also express less confidence in Trump’s ability to handle key issues like health care, illegal immigration, and foreign policy, with many feeling his goals are not very clear [2][3][8].

![Clinton voters prioritize unifying the country and addressing divisions](image1)  
![Trump voters prioritize health care, the economy, and immigration](image5)

These differences suggest that Trump voters are more policy-focused and aligned with his campaign promises, while Clinton voters are skeptical of his leadership and prioritize healing and unity. This divide is further highlighted by the fact that 84% of Clinton voters feel Trump’s goals are not very clear, compared to 87% of Trump voters who believe they have a good idea of his vision [8]. 

![Clinton voters see Trump’s goals as unclear, while Trump voters feel confident about his vision](image4)  
![Trump voters express greater confidence in his ability to handle the economy and terrorism](image2)

Overall, the priorities and confidence levels of Trump and Clinton voters reflect deep divisions in their expectations of his leadership and their perceptions of his ability to govern effectively.

Trump and Clinton voters exhibit stark differences in their confidence in Trump’s handling of foreign policy and their expectations for race relations post-election. ![Majority of Clinton voters have no confidence in Trump on foreign policy, while Trump voters express varying levels of confidence.](image7) Among Trump voters, only 47% have a great deal of confidence in Trump’s handling of foreign policy, with 29% expressing a fair amount of confidence. In contrast, a significant majority of Clinton voters—63%—say they have no confidence at all in Trump on this issue, while 6% express a fair amount of confidence and only 23% report having a great deal of confidence [12].

![Most Clinton voters expect worse race relations post-Trump election, while half of Trump voters expect improvement.](image6) Expectations for race relations also differ significantly. Half of Trump voters (50%) expect race relations to improve after Trump’s election, while 38% believe there will be no change, and only 9% expect things to worsen [7]. Conversely, an overwhelming majority of Clinton voters (84%) believe Trump’s election will lead to worse race relations, with only 2% expecting improvement and 13% foreseeing no change [11]. 

In summary, Trump voters show moderate to high confidence in Trump’s foreign policy and are optimistic about race relations, while Clinton voters overwhelmingly lack confidence in his foreign policy and expect race relations to deteriorate.

Trump and Clinton voters have starkly different confidence levels in Trump’s ability to improve race relations and political cooperation, as highlighted by the survey data. Nearly half of Trump voters (50%) expect race relations to improve, while only 9% think they will get worse [10]. In contrast, an overwhelming majority of Clinton voters (84%) believe race relations will worsen under Trump, with only 2% anticipating improvement [4]. 

![Trump voters and Clinton voters have contrasting views on race relations under Trump](image8)

Regarding political cooperation, Trump voters are more optimistic, with 47% expecting improvements in partisan relations, while only 9% predict worsening relations [9]. Clinton voters, however, are more pessimistic, with a large portion believing partisan relations will not improve in the wake of Trump’s election [12]. 

Overall, Trump voters are more confident in Trump’s ability to improve both race relations and political cooperation compared to Clinton voters, who largely anticipate negative outcomes.

Voters' expectations of race relations and partisan relations following the 2016 election reveal significant differences. On race relations, there is widespread skepticism, with only 25% of voters expecting improvement, while 46% anticipate worsening relations and 26% foresee no change [8]. This pessimism is particularly pronounced among Clinton voters, 84% of whom expect race relations to deteriorate, compared to only 2% who anticipate improvement [2]. In contrast, Trump voters are more optimistic, with 50% expecting improvement and only 9% expecting worsening relations [7].  

When it comes to partisan relations, expectations are more evenly divided. About 27% of voters think relations between the two parties will improve, while an equal percentage expect them to worsen, and 45% anticipate no change [11]. Trump voters are slightly more optimistic than Clinton voters, with 47% expecting improvement compared to 9% who expect worsening relations [10]. However, the overall mood reflects a lack of confidence in significant progress, with many voters believing that the partisan divide in Washington will persist [12].

The perceived implications of having enthusiastic supporters for a president are mixed. On one hand, strong support can provide a mandate for the president's agenda, but it can also deepen partisan divides. ![Supporters can lead to less productivity in government](image1). This suggests that while enthusiasm may bolster a president's ability to rally their base, it could also hinder bipartisan cooperation and effective governance. 

In summary, voters are more pessimistic about race relations than partisan relations after the 2016 election, and enthusiastic support for a president may exacerbate political gridlock rather than foster collaboration.

Over time, the political orientations of Democratic and Republican voters have shown distinct shifts, which are reflected in their reactions to the 2016 election outcomes. 

Among Democratic voters, there has been a significant move toward favoring a more liberal direction for the party. In 2016, **49%** of Democratic and Democratic-leaning voters wanted their party to move in a more liberal direction, up from **38%** two years prior and **33%** after Obama’s 2008 and 2012 victories [3][10]. This shift is visually represented in `![Trends in Democratic voters' preference for a more liberal direction](image2)`.

In contrast, Republican and Republican-leaning voters have consistently favored a more conservative direction. In 2016, **60%** wanted the GOP to move in a more conservative direction, while **36%** preferred moderation, a trend that has remained stable in recent years [9][8]. This is illustrated in `![Trends in Republican voters' preference for a more conservative direction](image1)`.

The 2016 election results further highlight the partisan divide: **94%** of Trump voters were happy that the GOP retained control of Congress, while **87%** of Clinton voters were unhappy [2]. Reactions to the election outcomes reveal a deepening polarization, with Trump voters slightly less optimistic about improving partisan relations (**47%**) compared to Obama voters in 2008 (**55%**), and Clinton voters more likely to foresee worsening relations (**43%**) than McCain voters in 2008 (**31%**) [12]. This division is captured in `![Voter reactions to the 2016 election outcomes](image3)`.

Overall, Democratic voters are increasingly supportive of a more liberal direction, while Republican voters remain steadfast in their preference for conservatism, reflecting a growing ideological and partisan divide in the wake of the 2016 election.

In 2008, there was a stronger inclination among voters for bipartisan cooperation compared to 2016. Nearly six-in-ten Republicans (59%) supported their leaders working with Obama, while only 36% wanted them to stand up to him [2]. Similarly, 78% of Obama’s voters and 76% of McCain’s voters believed their respective party leaders should work across the aisle, even if it meant disappointing their supporters [6]. Additionally, 52% of Obama supporters favored appointing Republicans to his cabinet, highlighting a more cooperative spirit [3].

In contrast, 2016 saw sharper partisan divides and a more adversarial stance. Only 32% of Democratic voters wanted their leaders to work with Trump, while 65% preferred standing up to him, even if it meant less legislative progress [12]. Similarly, while 53% of Republican voters supported Trump working with Democrats, 39% wanted him to stand up to Democratic leaders [5]. Moreover, only a small share of Trump voters (10%) expressed enthusiasm for bipartisan appointments [9].

![More mudslinging was reported in 2016 compared to past elections](image1)  
The 2016 election was marked by heightened negativity, with 92% of voters describing it as more negative than past elections, further polarizing voter sentiments [7]. Additionally, grades for political leaders and institutions were notably low in 2016, reflecting widespread dissatisfaction [10].  

Overall, voters in 2008 were more optimistic and supportive of bipartisan collaboration, while 2016 was characterized by greater polarization and a preference for adversarial politics.

Voter perceptions of political entities and the campaign’s negativity in the 2016 election are deeply intertwined, as the election was widely regarded as exceptionally negative, which in turn influenced how voters evaluated the conduct of key actors. A staggering 92% of voters described the campaign as more negative than past elections, marking a 20-point increase from the previous high in 2004 [2][12]. This pervasive negativity likely contributed to the overwhelmingly low grades voters gave to political parties, the press, and pollsters. For instance, only 22% and 26% of voters gave the Republican and Democratic Parties an A or B grade, respectively, while failing grades (F) reached historic highs of 30% and 28% [3]. ![The 2016 election saw record levels of voter dissatisfaction with the conduct of political parties, press, and pollsters.](image4)

The media and pollsters also received harsh evaluations, with only 22% and 21% of voters awarding them an A or B, while 38% and 30% gave them failing grades, respectively [7][10]. This suggests that the negative tone of the campaign may have eroded trust in these institutions. Additionally, voters were critical of themselves, with only 40% giving “the voters” an A or B grade—the lowest since 1996 [11]. ![Voters expressed high levels of negativity toward the press, pollsters, and even themselves in the 2016 election.](image7)

The campaign’s focus on mudslinging rather than policy issues further shaped voter perceptions. While 81% of voters felt informed enough to make a decision, 73% noted that there was less discussion of issues compared to past campaigns, which likely exacerbated dissatisfaction [6]. ![Voters perceived the 2016 campaign as more focused on mudslinging than on substantive issues.](image1)

In summary, the 2016 election’s unprecedented negativity directly influenced how voters perceived the conduct of political entities, leading to historically low approval ratings for parties, the press, pollsters, and even themselves. ![The 2016 election’s negativity significantly impacted voter perceptions of key campaign actors.](image4)

Trump and Clinton voters exhibited starkly different emotional reactions following the 2016 election, reflecting the polarized nature of the contest. Among Trump voters, the dominant emotions were positive, with **96% feeling hopeful** and **74% feeling proud** about his victory [5]. Words like “happy,” “relieved,” and “hopeful” were frequently mentioned, highlighting their satisfaction with the outcome ![Trump voters' emotions](image2). In contrast, Clinton voters expressed overwhelming negativity, with **90% feeling uneasy**, **77% sad**, and **76% scared** [5]. Words like “shocked,” “disappointed,” and “disgusted” were common, emphasizing their distress and disbelief ![Clinton voters' emotions](image2).

These emotional divides align with voters’ perceptions of Trump’s performance and the campaign’s tone. Trump received low grades for his conduct, with only **30% giving him an A or B**, while Clinton received slightly higher ratings at **43%** ![Grades for Trump and Clinton](image1). The election was widely viewed as extraordinarily negative, with **92% of voters** saying there was more mudslinging than in past campaigns [7] ![Mudslinging perception](image6). This negative campaigning likely intensified the emotional reactions on both sides, with Clinton voters feeling particularly disillusioned and Trump voters celebrating an unexpected victory.

Overall, the emotional responses of Trump and Clinton voters reflect their contrasting views of the election’s outcome and its conduct, highlighting the deep divisions in American politics at the time.

The emotional reactions to Trump's victory starkly differ between Trump and Clinton voters, reflecting their vastly different expectations prior to the election. 

Trump voters overwhelmingly expressed positive emotions, with “happy” being the most frequent response, followed by “surprised,” “relieved,” and “hopeful” [7] ![Emotional reactions of Trump voters include happiness and surprise](image8). This aligns with the fact that 97% of Trump voters said they were happy he won [12], and over half (51%) felt hopeful about his election [9]. However, 60% of Trump voters also expressed surprise at the outcome, indicating that many did not fully anticipate his victory [2] ![Most Trump voters were surprised by the election result](image6).

In contrast, Clinton voters primarily reported negative emotions, with “shocked” being the most common reaction, followed by “disappointed” and “disgusted” [10] ![Clinton voters expressed shock and disappointment](image8). A staggering 93% of Clinton voters said they were unhappy with the election result [12], and 84% believed Trump’s presidency would worsen race relations [8]. Their surprise is further highlighted by the fact that 87% of Clinton voters were stunned by Trump’s victory [3] ![A large majority of Clinton voters were surprised](image6).

These reactions suggest that many Clinton supporters were confident in her victory and unprepared for the outcome, while Trump supporters, though optimistic, were also caught off guard by his win. This disparity underscores the profound polarization and differing expectations among voters leading up to the election.

Voter sentiments towards Trump’s victory and expectations for a female president in their lifetime reveal significant differences between Trump and Clinton voters.  

Trump voters overwhelmingly express happiness about his victory, with 97% saying they are happy he won. In contrast, 93% of Clinton voters are unhappy with the outcome [11]. This aligns with their reactions to the GOP retaining congressional control, where 94% of Trump voters are happy, while 87% of Clinton voters are unhappy [5].  

On the topic of a female president in their lifetime, 79% of all voters expect this to happen, with no significant differences between Trump and Clinton supporters [4]. However, this shared optimism contrasts sharply with their feelings about Trump’s victory, highlighting a clear divide based on partisan lines.  

![Trump voters are predominantly happy about his victory, while Clinton voters are unhappy](image3)  

![Most voters expect a female president in their lifetime, with no significant partisan differences](image5)  

In summary, Trump and Clinton voters diverge sharply in their reactions to Trump’s victory but share similar expectations for a female president in the future.

Public perceptions of government efforts to combat terrorism have shifted significantly over time, with increasing dissatisfaction and varying views based on political affiliation and age. For the first time since the September 2001 terrorist attacks, more Americans (52%) say the government is doing "not too well" or "not at all well" in reducing the threat of terrorism, compared to 46% who say it is doing "very" or "fairly well." This marks a 26-point decline in positive ratings since January [2]. 

![Percentage of Americans rating government efforts to combat terrorism](image7)

These negative assessments are consistent across the political spectrum. Among Republicans, only 27% now say the government is doing well, down sharply from 63% at the beginning of the year. Similarly, Democrats' positive ratings have dropped from 85% to 64%, and independents' ratings have fallen by 25 points to 44% [3]. Older and less educated Americans are particularly critical, with 57% of those aged 50 and older giving the government negative marks, compared to 46% of younger adults (18-29) [6][10]. 

![Views on government efforts by age group](image8)

Concerns about government restrictions on civil liberties have also evolved. While 56% of Americans now worry that anti-terrorism policies have "not gone far enough" to protect the country, this represents a significant shift from July 2013, when more people (47%) were concerned about policies going "too far" restricting civil liberties [1][12]. This shift is especially pronounced among Republicans, with 71% now prioritizing the need for stronger anti-terrorism measures, up 33 points since 2013 [7]. 

![Concerns about government anti-terrorism policies by political affiliation](image2)

In summary, public confidence in the government’s ability to combat terrorism has declined significantly, with negative perceptions most prevalent among Republicans, older Americans, and those with less education.

Age and political ideology significantly shape perceptions of the U.S. government’s efforts to reduce the terrorist threat, and these perceptions have evolved over time. Older Americans are more critical of the government’s performance compared to younger adults. A majority of those aged 50 and older (57%) say the government is not doing well in reducing the terrorist threat, while 46% of those aged 18-29 hold negative views, with 53% rating the government’s performance positively [4]. ![Younger adults are more positive about government efforts than older adults.](image7)

Political ideology also plays a key role. Democrats remain the most supportive group, with 64% saying the government is doing at least fairly well, though this marks a decline from 85% in early 2015. Independents’ positive ratings have dropped 25 points to 44%, and only 27% of Republicans now give the government positive marks, down from 63% [3]. ![Republicans and independents are more critical of government efforts than Democrats.](image4)

Over time, concerns about government policies have shifted. In 2013, following the NSA surveillance revelations, more Americans were worried about civil liberties being restricted (47%) than about policies not going far enough to protect the country (35%). By late 2015, this trend reversed, with 56% concerned about policies not going far enough, and only 28% worried about overreach [2][8]. ![Concerns have shifted from civil liberties to security over time.](image6)

Younger adults are more likely to express concern about government overreach in both anti-terror policies and military involvement. For example, 55% of those under 30 worry the U.S. is too involved in Iraq and Syria, while older age groups prioritize concerns about not doing enough to stop militants [7][9]. ![Younger adults are more concerned about overreach than older adults.](image1)

In summary, age and political ideology significantly influence perceptions of government efforts, with older and conservative Americans more critical, and younger adults and Democrats more supportive. Over time, concerns have shifted toward security rather than civil liberties.

In 2015, perceptions of the government’s performance in reducing the terrorist threat varied significantly across age groups. Older adults (50 and older) were more critical, with 57% saying the government is not doing well in reducing the terrorist threat, while 42% gave it a positive rating. In contrast, younger adults (18-29) were more divided, with 46% giving a negative rating and 53% saying the government is doing very or fairly well [6]. ![Older adults are more critical of the government’s anti-terror efforts](image2)

When it comes to concerns about anti-terror policies, a majority of older adults (65+) were more worried that policies have not gone far enough to protect the country (71%), while only 15% were concerned about policies restricting civil liberties too much. Younger adults (18-29) were more evenly split, with 44% concerned that policies do not go far enough and 43% worried about excessive restrictions on civil liberties [5][7]. ![Older adults prioritize security over civil liberties](image5)

In summary, older age groups tend to prioritize security over civil liberties, while younger adults are more evenly divided in their concerns.

Public opinions on government anti-terrorism efforts have evolved significantly across different age groups and political affiliations.  

Among **age groups**, younger adults (18-29) are nearly split in their concerns: **43%** worry that policies go too far in restricting civil liberties, while **44%** believe they do not go far enough to protect the country. In contrast, older adults (65+) show a stronger emphasis on security, with **71%** expressing greater concern that policies are insufficient to protect the nation [4]. Middle-aged groups (30-49 and 50-64) also lean toward security concerns, with **52%** and **60%**, respectively, saying policies do not go far enough.  

![Younger adults are split on concerns about civil liberties vs. security](image4)  
![Older adults prioritize security over civil liberties](image4)  

Across **political affiliations**, Republicans are significantly more likely to say anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough, with **71% of conservative Republicans** and **74% of moderate/liberal Republicans** holding this view. Among Democrats, **67% of conservative/moderate Democrats** share this concern, while **liberal Democrats** are evenly split, with **41%** worried about policies going too far and **41%** concerned they do not go far enough [5][6]. Independents fall in between, with **55%** prioritizing security concerns.  

![Republicans are more likely to prioritize security over civil liberties](image7)  
![Liberal Democrats are evenly split on security vs. civil liberties](image7)  

Overall, security concerns have risen across all groups since 2013, particularly after Edward Snowden’s disclosures about NSA surveillance programs, which initially heightened concerns about civil liberties. However, the focus has since shifted back toward protecting the country, especially among older adults and Republicans [7][4].  

In summary, older adults and Republicans are more likely to prioritize security over civil liberties, while younger adults and liberal Democrats show a more balanced or split perspective on the issue.

Public perceptions of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS and its potential success have shown notable shifts and partisan divides. Overall, while a majority continues to hold negative views of the campaign's current progress, optimism about its ultimate success has increased over time [1][9].

![Majority still views the current campaign negatively, but optimism about success has risen](image1)  
As of December 2015, 58% of respondents believed the campaign was going "not too well" or "not at all well," while 35% viewed it as going "very" or "fairly" well [7]. However, the share of those who believe the U.S. and its allies will succeed in the campaign rose to 66%, an 11-point increase from July 2015 [9]. This is visually supported by ![Image showing increased optimism about campaign success from July to December 2015](image6).

Partisan divides are evident in both current assessments and predictions of success. Republicans are far more critical of the campaign's progress, with only 26% saying it is going at least fairly well, compared to 45% of Democrats and 33% of independents [2]. Despite this, majorities across all groups predict ultimate success: 65% of Republicans, 72% of Democrats, and 62% of independents [2]. ![Partisan differences in views of the campaign's progress and success](image4) highlights these variations.

Concerns about the campaign also differ by political affiliation. Three-quarters of Republicans (75%) worry the U.S. will not go far enough in stopping ISIS, while only 18% fear overinvolvement [6]. Conversely, 67% of liberal Democrats express greater concern about the U.S. becoming too involved, with only 27% worried about insufficient action [10]. ![Party breakdown of concerns about military action](image2) illustrates these perspectives.

Approval of the military campaign has remained steady, with 64% supporting it as of December 2015 [11]. However, younger respondents and liberal Democrats are more likely to oppose the campaign, while older adults and conservatives strongly favor it [5][10]. ![Overall approval trends of the military campaign from 2014 to 2015](image7) shows this stability.

In summary, while public perceptions of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS remain largely negative, optimism about its ultimate success has grown. Partisan differences persist, with Republicans more critical of current efforts but equally optimistic about success, and Democrats more concerned about overinvolvement.

Perceptions of Islam's encouragement of violence vary significantly across political affiliations. **Republicans** are most likely to associate Islam with violence, with 68% saying it is more likely than other religions to encourage violence, a historical high [8]. In contrast, only 30% of **Democrats** hold this view, marking a 12-point decline from 2014 [12]. **Independents** fall in between, with 45% believing Islam encourages violence [7].![Republican 68%](image2)  

These perceptions are deeply polarized, with the gap between Republicans and Democrats now wider than ever [7]. This divide may influence opinions on government efforts to combat terrorism. **Republicans** are highly critical, with only 27% saying the government is doing at least fairly well in reducing the terrorist threat, down from 63% in early 2015 [5]. **Democrats**, however, are more supportive, with 64% saying the government is doing fairly well, though this is a drop from 85% earlier in the year [5].![Government handling of terrorism](image5)  

The correlation suggests that those who associate Islam with violence (primarily Republicans) are more likely to disapprove of government efforts, possibly due to heightened security concerns or perceived inadequacies in addressing terrorism. Conversely, Democrats, who are less likely to link Islam with violence, may have a more favorable view of government actions.![Perceptions of Islam and violence](image3)

Perceptions of Islam encouraging violence have shifted notably over time, with stark differences across political affiliations. Among Republicans, the belief that Islam is more likely to encourage violence has remained high, with 68% holding this view in 2015, little changed from 67% in September 2014 and the highest since 2002 [9]. In contrast, Democrats’ views have softened, with only 30% associating Islam with violence in 2015, down from 42% in September 2014 [9]. This widening partisan gap is now at its highest [7].

Independents remain evenly split, with 45% saying Islam is more likely to encourage violence and 45% saying it is not [2]. The broader public also reflects this division, with 46% agreeing that Islam is more likely to encourage violence and 45% disagreeing, down from a peak of 50% in September 2014 [6].

![Partisan views on Islam and violence, 2015](image1)

![Partisan views on Islam and violence over time](image2)

Public opinion on party capabilities in handling terrorism contrasts with these views. Republicans hold a significant advantage, with 46% of the public believing the Republican Party can better handle the terrorist threat, compared to 34% favoring the Democrats [8]. This 12-point gap underscores a persistent trust in Republicans on this issue, despite their stronger association of Islam with violence.

![Public trust in parties on terrorism, 2015](image5)

In summary, while partisan views on Islam and violence have diverged sharply, with Republicans maintaining a strong association and Democrats softening their stance, public trust in the Republican Party’s ability to handle terrorism remains significantly higher.

Perceptions of scrutiny of Muslims vary significantly across political and demographic groups, and these differences are closely tied to the perceived importance of terrorism as a national issue.  

Majorities of most religious and demographic groups, including young people, minorities, and those with higher education, say Muslims should not face additional scrutiny solely because of their religion. For example, **80% of young adults (18-29)** and **74% of Black Americans** reject the idea of greater scrutiny of Muslims [1][2][4]. Similarly, **69% of postgraduates** and **65% of college graduates** oppose such scrutiny, while those without a college degree are somewhat more divided [7]. ![{Young adults, minorities, and the highly educated oppose scrutiny of Muslims}](image1)  

Political ideology plays a significant role in these perceptions. **Conservative Republicans** stand out as the only group in which a majority **(57%)** supports greater scrutiny of Muslims [3][12]. In contrast, **87% of liberal Democrats** and **67% of conservative and moderate Democrats** reject additional scrutiny [5]. Independents also lean against scrutiny, with **62%** opposing it [9]. ![{Conservative Republicans support scrutiny, while Democrats and independents oppose it}](image5)  

These attitudes align with partisan views on terrorism as a national issue. **Republicans (41%)** are far more likely than **Democrats (23%)** or **independents (28%)** to cite terrorism, defense, or national security as the most important problem facing the nation [6]. This suggests that Republicans’ heightened concern about terrorism may contribute to their greater support for scrutinizing Muslims. ![{Republicans prioritize terrorism more than Democrats or independents}](image4)  

Overall, perceptions of scrutiny of Muslims are deeply divided along political and demographic lines, with Republicans and conservative groups more likely to support scrutiny, while Democrats, independents, and younger or more educated individuals oppose it. These divisions reflect broader differences in how terrorism is prioritized as a national issue.

Perceptions of terrorism and government efforts to combat it have shifted significantly over time, with notable differences across demographic and political groups. For the first time since the September 2001 attacks, more Americans now believe the government is performing not too well or not at all well in reducing the threat of terrorism (52%) than those who say it is doing very or fairly well (46%). This marks a 26-point decline in positive ratings since January [4]. 

Older and less educated individuals are more critical of the government’s efforts. Among those aged 50 and older, 57% say the government is not doing well, compared to 46% of younger adults (18-29) [11]. Similarly, 58% of those with postgraduate degrees rate the government positively, while only 44% of those with less education do so [3]. ![Older and less educated Americans are more critical of government efforts](image9)

Partisan divides are stark. Republicans are far more critical, with only 27% saying the government is doing well, down from 63% at the start of the year. Democrats, though more positive, have also seen a decline, with 64% expressing approval compared to 85% in January [12]. ![Republicans are more critical of government efforts](image12)

Concerns about terrorism itself have surged. Nearly 29% of Americans now cite terrorism, national security, or ISIS as the most important problem, the highest share since February 2003. This is a sharp increase from 4% a year ago [10]. 

Public sentiment also reflects a growing concern that anti-terror policies have not gone far enough to protect the country (56%), outweighing worries about civil liberties (28%) [8]. ![Concern that anti-terror policies have not gone far enough has risen](image7)

In summary, perceptions of terrorism have become more prominent, and confidence in government efforts has declined, with older, less educated, and Republican groups expressing the most criticism.

The survey results reveal stark differences in how Republicans and Democrats view terrorism and economic issues. On terrorism, Republicans are far more likely to associate Islam with violence, with 68% holding this view compared to 30% of Democrats [2]. Additionally, 71% of Republicans believe anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough, a significant increase from 38% in 2013, while Democrats are more divided on this issue [3]. Republicans are also more likely to advocate for overwhelming military force to combat terrorism (72%) compared to Democrats (27%), who believe excessive force can lead to more hatred and terrorism [4]. ![Republicans are more likely to see overwhelming force as the best way to defeat terrorism](image4)

When it comes to economic issues, Democrats are more likely to prioritize general economic concerns and unemployment, while Republicans focus more on immigration and national security. For instance, 14% of Republicans cite immigration as the most important problem, compared to just 3% of Democrats [8]. Conversely, Democrats are more likely to mention political gridlock and division (8%) compared to Republicans (2%) [8]. ![Republicans and Democrats have differing priorities on economic and security issues](image7)

Overall, Republicans are more concerned with terrorism and national security, while Democrats place greater emphasis on economic issues and domestic challenges like political gridlock.

Views on the importance of terrorism and perceptions of government efforts to address the threat vary significantly across political affiliations. Republicans are far more likely to prioritize terrorism, defense, and national security, with 41% citing these issues as the most important problem facing the nation, compared to 28% of independents and 23% of Democrats [6]. ![Republicans prioritize terrorism more than Democrats or independents](image7)

This partisan divide extends to evaluations of the government’s performance in combating terrorism. A majority of Democrats (64%) still believe the government is doing at least fairly well, though this is down from 85% in January. In contrast, only 27% of Republicans and 44% of independents rate the government’s efforts positively [5]. ![Democrats are more positive about government efforts than Republicans or independents](image6)

Conservative Republicans, in particular, have become sharply critical, with only 18% now saying the government is doing well, compared to 59% in January [7]. Independents’ positive ratings have also dropped significantly, falling from 69% to 44% over the same period [5]. ![Conservative Republicans are highly critical of government efforts](image3)

These differences in priorities and evaluations may stem from varying trust levels in the government’s approach. Republicans and conservatives are more likely to believe that anti-terror policies have not gone far enough to protect the country, while Democrats are more concerned about these policies restricting civil liberties [11]. ![Concerns about anti-terror policies vary by political affiliation](image4)

Overall, Republicans view terrorism as a more pressing issue and are less satisfied with the government’s efforts, while Democrats are more positive about the government’s performance but less likely to prioritize terrorism as a top concern. ![Partisan differences in views on terrorism and government efforts](image1)

Independent voters hold distinct views on government regulation and economic fairness compared to Democrats and Republicans. On economic fairness, **Democrats (85%)** and **Democratic-leaning independents (81%)** largely agree that the U.S. economic system unfairly favors powerful interests, while **Republicans (29%)** are more likely to view it as generally fair. **GOP-leaning independents** are divided, with nearly equal shares saying the system is fair (49%) or unfair (46%) [7][12]. ![GOP leaners are divided on economic fairness](image2)

Regarding government regulation, **Republican-leaning independents (78%)** overwhelmingly prefer smaller government with fewer services, aligning closely with **Republicans (74%)**. In contrast, **Democratic-leaning independents**, like **Democrats**, tend to favor bigger government and more services [6][9]. ![Republican-leaning independents prefer smaller government](image3)

Overall, independents are divided on these issues, with their views often reflecting a mix of partisan leanings rather than a unified stance [8].

Over the past two decades, unfavorable views toward both major U.S. political parties among independents have shown notable shifts. In 1994, the share of independents who held unfavorable opinions of both parties was relatively lower, but it surged in later years. For instance, by 2015, more than a third of independents (36%) viewed both parties unfavorably [8]. However, this trend has declined in recent years, with the share dropping to 24% among GOP leaners and 37% among independents who do not lean toward a party [4][7].

![Independents' unfavorable views of both parties have fluctuated over time, peaking in 2015 and declining recently.](image8)

Subgroups within independents exhibit distinct patterns in their views. Republican-leaning independents, for example, have seen a decline in their unfavorable views of both parties, from 47% at one point to 24% more recently [7]. Democratic-leaning independents, on the other hand, show a similar but less pronounced trend. Meanwhile, independents who do not lean toward any party are more likely to view both parties unfavorably (37%), compared to those who lean toward a party [4][11].

![Republican-leaning independents have a lower share of unfavorable views of both parties compared to non-leaning independents.](image5)

In summary, unfavorable views of both parties among independents peaked around 2015 but have since declined, with significant differences observed between leaners and non-leaners.

Over the past two decades, unfavorable views toward the opposing party have surged across all political affiliations. For instance, the share of Democratic-leaning independents with a **very unfavorable** opinion of the Republican Party has more than quadrupled, from **8% in 1994** to **37% in 2018**. Similarly, Republican leaners’ very unfavorable views of the Democratic Party have risen from **15% in 1994** to **39% in 2018** [4]. This trend reflects a broader polarization, where both partisans and party-leaning independents increasingly view the opposing party negatively [5].  

Currently, **87% of Republicans** and **88% of Democrats** view the opposing party unfavorably, with Republican-leaning independents (**81%**) and Democratic-leaning independents (**84%)** nearly mirroring these percentages [2]. This intense polarization is evident in the data, where the shares of partisan identifiers and leaners with unfavorable impressions of the opposition party are at or near all-time highs [2].  

Among independents who do not lean toward either party, **37%** hold unfavorable views of both parties, the highest share compared to Republicans (**10%**) and Democrats (**9%**) [8]. However, this share has declined from a peak of **36% in 2015** to **37% currently** [9]. Additionally, **22%** of non-leaning independents have favorable opinions of both parties, while only **11%** view the Democratic Party favorably and **9%** view the Republican Party favorably [12].  

![Polarization trends in unfavorable views of the opposing party](image5)  
![Current levels of favorability and unfavorability among independents](image7)  

In summary, unfavorable views toward the opposing party have intensified over time, with independents who do not lean toward a party being the most likely to view both parties negatively, though this share has slightly declined in recent years.

Republicans and Democrats in the U.S. have distinct perceptions of China’s handling of the coronavirus outbreak, which also shape their views on U.S.-China relations. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are significantly more critical of China’s response to the pandemic, with **82%** saying China has done a bad job, compared to **54%** of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents. Additionally, **61%** of Republicans believe China has done a very bad job, while only **30%** of Democrats share this view [9]. 

![Republicans are more critical of China's handling of the pandemic](image7)

This criticism extends to the perception of China’s role in the global spread of the virus. **73%** of Republicans think China’s early handling of the pandemic contributed a great deal to its spread, compared to **38%** of Democrats [10]. Furthermore, **71%** of Republicans believe the U.S. should hold China responsible for its role in the outbreak, even if it worsens economic relations, while only **37%** of Democrats agree with this stance [11].

![Republicans are more likely to prioritize holding China responsible over maintaining strong relations](image5)

These partisan differences reflect broader trends in views on U.S.-China policy. Republicans are more likely to advocate for a tougher approach, while Democrats lean toward building a stronger relationship with China [12]. Overall, Republicans are more critical of China’s handling of the pandemic and more supportive of punitive measures, whereas Democrats are less critical and prioritize maintaining diplomatic ties.

Republicans and Democrats have differing perceptions of China’s handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, with Republicans being significantly more critical. Around 82% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents say China has done a bad job dealing with the coronavirus, compared to 54% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents. Additionally, 61% of Republicans believe China has done a **very bad job**, a stark contrast to 30% of Democrats who share this view [4]. 

This partisan divide is also evident in opinions about China’s role in the global spread of the virus. Republicans are more likely to blame China’s initial handling of the outbreak, with 73% stating it contributed a great deal to the pandemic’s spread, compared to 38% of Democrats [2]. Over time, these critical views have intensified across the political spectrum, but Republicans consistently hold more negative perceptions than Democrats [8].

![Republicans are significantly more critical of China's handling of COVID-19 than Democrats](image4)  

The survey data also reveals that older Americans, particularly those aged 50 and older, are more likely to fault China’s handling of the pandemic, with 73% expressing criticism [4]. This aligns with the broader trend of Republicans, who tend to be older, holding harsher views [5]. Over the past year, these negative perceptions have grown, with both Republicans and Democrats becoming more critical of China’s role in the pandemic and its economic ties to the U.S. [6].

![Older Americans and Republicans are more critical of China's COVID-19 response](image5)  

In summary, Republicans are consistently more critical of China’s handling of COVID-19 than Democrats, and these perceptions have grown increasingly negative over time, particularly among older Americans and Republican-leaning individuals.

Americans’ views on China’s role in the coronavirus outbreak and U.S.-China relations vary significantly, with notable differences across political affiliations. A majority of Americans (64%) believe China did a bad job handling the outbreak, including 43% who say it was a *very* bad job [4]. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more critical, with 82% saying China handled the pandemic poorly, compared to 54% of Democrats and Democratic leaners [11]. ![Critical views on China's handling of the pandemic by party](image3)

Three-quarters of Americans (78%) believe China’s initial handling of the outbreak in Wuhan contributed to the global spread of the virus, with 51% saying it contributed a *great deal* [9]. Republicans are particularly critical, with 73% attributing a great deal of blame to China, compared to 38% of Democrats [9]. ![Blame attribution for the global spread of COVID-19 by party](image5)

Regarding U.S.-China relations, half of Americans (50%) think the U.S. should hold China responsible for its role in the pandemic, even if it worsens economic relations, while 38% prioritize strong U.S.-China ties [3]. Republicans are twice as likely as Democrats (71% vs. 37%) to favor holding China accountable [3]. ![Preferences for U.S.-China relations by party](image4)

Older Americans (50+) are more critical of China, with 73% blaming its early handling of the pandemic [11]. Additionally, those who think China handled the outbreak poorly or contributed to its spread are more likely to have unfavorable views of the country [12]. ![Age and political affiliation differences in views on China](image2)

Overall, Republicans and older Americans are more critical of China’s role in the pandemic and favor a tougher stance in U.S.-China relations, while Democrats are more likely to prioritize maintaining strong ties. ![Trends in U.S. public opinion on China's role in the pandemic](image6)

American perceptions of China's role in handling COVID-19 and broader U.S.-China relations have significantly worsened, with increased blame placed on China and a growing preference for tougher policies. Around two-thirds of Americans (64%) believe China has done a bad job dealing with the coronavirus outbreak, and nearly three-quarters (78%) attribute a great deal or fair amount of blame to the Chinese government’s initial handling of the outbreak in Wuhan [8]. This sentiment is reflected in the image: ![The Chinese government's initial handling of the coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan is a great deal to blame for the global spread of the virus](image2).

Half of Americans (50%) think the U.S. should hold China responsible for its role in the outbreak, even if it worsens economic relations, while 38% prioritize maintaining strong ties [3]. This partisan divide is visually captured in: ![Rep/Lean Rep 73](image3).

Economic ties between the U.S. and China are perceived as worsening, with 68% describing them as in bad shape, up 15 percentage points since May 2019 [12]. Overall, unfavorable views of China have risen sharply, with 73% of Americans holding a negative opinion of the country, up 26 points since 2018 [11]. In summary, American perceptions of China’s COVID-19 handling and broader relations have deteriorated, with increasing blame and a shift toward tougher policies, though economic considerations remain a point of contention.

Negative perceptions of China have significantly increased across all demographic groups, particularly among older Americans and Republicans. 

Americans ages 50 and older are substantially more negative toward China compared to younger age groups, with 81% holding unfavorable views versus 71% of those ages 30 to 49 and 56% of those under 30 [5]. Partisan divides have also widened. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely to view China negatively (83%) compared to Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents (68%) [1]. Overall, 73% of Americans now hold unfavorable views of China, a record high and a 26-percentage-point increase since 2018 [8] [10]. This trend is consistent across education levels and genders but is particularly pronounced among older adults and Republicans. ![Negative views of China have reached historic highs across all demographics](image7) 

In summary, negative perceptions of China have risen sharply over time, with older Americans and Republicans showing the most significant increases in unfavorable views.

Unfavorable views of China in the United States have risen significantly over time, with notable differences across age groups and political affiliations. In the U.S., political affiliation significantly influences preferences for foreign policy partners and desired cooperation levels. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more inclined to favor Israel as a key partner (26%), compared to Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents (9%) [2]. Democrats, on the other hand, place greater emphasis on Canada and Mexico for their top foreign policy affiliations [2]. However, both parties similarly rank Germany as their fifth most or second-most important partner [2]. ![Republicans and Democrats in the U.S. have differing preferences for foreign policy partners, with Republicans favoring Israel more than Democrats](image8)

When it comes to cooperation with Germany, Democrats in the U.S. are more likely to desire greater collaboration than Republicans [12]. Additionally, about two-thirds of Democrats (66%) prefer close ties with Germany, compared to 57% of Republicans, while 31% of Republicans prefer close relations with Russia compared to 21% of Democrats [11]. ![U.S. Republicans and Democrats show differing preferences for cooperation with Germany and Russia](image1)

In Germany, political affiliations also play a role, though the differences are less dramatic. Germany views France as the most important partner, followed by the U.S. [7]. Supporters of the CDU/CSU party are more willing to cooperate with the U.S. than those who support the Greens and the SPD, reflecting a pattern where those on the ideological right in Germany tend to have a more favorable view of the U.S. [12]. ![German political parties rank France as their most important partner, followed by the U.S.](image3)

Overall, while there are clear partisan differences in the U.S. regarding foreign policy partners and cooperation, Germans exhibit more uniformity in their preferences, with France and the U.S. consistently ranking high across political affiliations. ![Germans are more unified in their foreign policy preferences compared to the U.S.](image7)

Americans and Germans differ significantly in their preferences for increased cooperation with Russia and China. Germans are almost twice as likely as Americans to want greater collaboration with Russia, with 75% of East Germans and 63% of West Germans favoring closer ties, compared to 41% of Republicans and 32% of Democrats in the U.S. [3][10]. ![Germans show higher support for cooperation with Russia than Americans](image1).

In the U.S., partisan divides are evident. Republicans are more inclined than Democrats to favor increased cooperation with Russia (41% vs. 32%) [3]. Similarly, Republicans are less likely to prefer close ties with Germany over Russia (31% vs. 21% among Democrats) [4]. ![Republicans in the U.S. are more likely to favor Russia than Democrats](image2).

When it comes to China, younger Americans (18-29) are more likely to prioritize a close relationship with China over Germany (58% vs. 32%), while older Americans prefer Germany [7]. ![Younger Americans favor China over Germany more than older Americans](image4). Germans, however, are twice as likely to prefer closer ties with the U.S. over China (50% vs. 24%) [8]. ![Germans prefer the U.S. over China more than Americans do](image8).

Political affiliations in Germany also play a role. Supporters of CDU/CSU are more willing to cooperate with the U.S. than those backing the Greens or SPD [9]. ![German political affiliations influence their willingness to cooperate with the U.S.](image2). 

In summary, Germans show stronger support for cooperation with Russia than Americans, with Republicans in the U.S. and East Germans particularly favoring closer ties. Meanwhile, Germans prefer closer relations with the U.S. over China, while younger Americans lean toward China. Political affiliations in both countries significantly shape these preferences.

In the U.S., political party affiliation significantly shapes attitudes toward cooperation with Russia and China. Republicans are more inclined to favor closer ties with Russia, with 31% expressing this preference compared to 21% of Democrats [1]. Similarly, 41% of Republicans support increased cooperation with Russia, while only 32% of Democrats share this view [11]. This aligns with broader ideological trends, as conservative Americans tend to view Russia more favorably than liberals [8]. Conversely, Democrats are more likely to emphasize cooperation with Germany and prioritize relationships with Canada and Mexico over Russia or China [4].

In Germany, attitudes toward cooperation with the U.S. and Russia also vary by political affiliation. Supporters of the CDU/CSU, Germany’s conservative party, are more willing to cooperate with the U.S. than those aligned with the Greens or SPD [6]. Meanwhile, Germans in the former East are more supportive of closer ties with Russia (75%) compared to those in the former West (63%) [11]. This regional divide reflects historical and ideological differences, as East Germans are nearly twice as likely to prefer a close relationship with Russia over the U.S. [10].

When it comes to China, younger Americans (aged 18–29) are more likely to favor a close relationship with China over Germany (58% vs. 32%), while older Americans prioritize Germany [5]. This generational divide could influence future political preferences as younger Americans become more prominent in the electorate. In Germany, however, the population as a whole is twice as likely to prefer a close relationship with the U.S. over China (50% vs. 24%) [9].

These findings underscore how political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany shape attitudes toward international cooperation, particularly with Russia and China, reflecting deeper ideological and historical divides. ![Americans display a clear preference for Germany over Russia, but Republicans are more favorable toward Russia than Democrats.](image1) ![Germans show a smaller preference gap between Russia and the U.S., with East Germans more supportive of Russia.](image2) ![Younger Americans are more likely to prioritize relations with China over Germany, unlike older Americans.](image3) ![Conservative Americans and Germans on the right are more favorable toward Russia, while liberals favor the UN and EU.](image5) ![Republicans and Democrats in the U.S. differ in their support for Russia, while CDU/CSU supporters in Germany are more pro-U.S.](image6) ![Americans and Germans show varying levels of support for cooperation with Russia and China based on political affiliation.](image7) ![Political divides in the U.S. and Germany influence attitudes toward foreign policy partners like Russia and China.](image8)

In the U.S., political affiliation significantly influences attitudes toward cooperation with Russia. Republicans are more likely to favor increased cooperation with Russia (41%) compared to Democrats (32%) [8]. This aligns with the broader trend that conservatives in the U.S. tend to view Russia more favorably than liberals [6]. Democrats, on the other hand, show a stronger preference for closer ties with Germany (66%) than Republicans (57%) [3].

In Germany, the ideological divide on Russia is less pronounced but still evident. Germans on the political right are more likely to view Russia favorably than those on the left [6]. However, regional differences within Germany play a larger role, with East Germans being far more supportive of close ties with Russia (75%) than West Germans (63%) [8]. East Germans also prioritize relations with Russia over the U.S. more than their western counterparts [12].

![German political affiliation influences views on Russia, with East Germans favoring closer ties](image8)  
![U.S. political affiliation affects attitudes toward Russia, with Republicans more inclined to cooperate](image4)

When comparing the views of Americans and Germans on the world’s leading economic power, there is a stark contrast. Half of Americans view the U.S. as the leading economic power, while only 24% of Germans share this view. Instead, 53% of Germans believe China holds this position, compared to 32% of Americans [3]. `![Germans are more likely to view China as the leading economic power, while Americans favor the U.S.](image1)` This divide reflects differing perceptions of global economic dominance [4].

In terms of international relationships, Germans generally hold more favorable views of the EU than Americans. Roughly seven-in-ten Germans favor the EU, whereas only about half of Americans do [6]. Similarly, Germans tend to view China and Russia more positively than Americans, though favorable opinions of Russia remain limited in both countries [6]. `![Germans view the EU and China more positively than Americans](image2)` Ideological differences also play a role. For instance, American conservatives and Germans on the political right are more likely to favor Russia, while liberals and those on the left in both countries prefer the UN and EU [5].

When it comes to cooperation, Americans are more eager to collaborate with Germany than Germans are with the U.S. Nearly seven-in-ten Americans want to cooperate more with Germany, compared to only half of Germans [11]. `![Americans are more eager to cooperate with Germany than Germans are with the U.S.](image5)` These differences highlight the contrasting perspectives on international alliances and economic leadership between the two nations.

Americans and Germans exhibit notable differences in their perceptions of international organizations and economic powers, influenced by ideological, historical, and geopolitical factors. While both groups share relatively positive views of the UN and NATO, Germans tend to hold more favorable opinions of these organizations than Americans [1][10]. For instance, 65% of Germans favor the UN compared to 59% of Americans, and 57% of Germans favor NATO compared to 52% of Americans [5]. However, the gap widens significantly when it comes to the EU, with 71% of Germans favoring it compared to only 50% of Americans [10].
