This stark divide reflects differing historical and political contexts, as Germans view the EU as integral to European stability, while Americans are more ambivalent [10].

When it comes to economic powers, perceptions are markedly different. Half of Americans see the U.S. as the world’s leading economic power, while only 24% of Germans agree. Instead, 53% of Germans name China as the top economic power, compared to 32% of Americans [7][8]. This divergence may stem from Germany’s economic ties with China and a more globalized perspective, whereas Americans may emphasize their nation’s economic dominance [7].

Ideological differences further shape these views. In both countries, conservatives and those on the political right are more likely to view Russia favorably, while liberals and the left favor the UN and EU [11]. However, the ideological divide is more pronounced among Americans than Germans, with a 42-point gap in UN favorability and a 35-point gap in EU favorability [6]. Historical factors also play a role, as Germans from the former East view Russia more favorably (43%) and the EU less favorably (59%) compared to those from the former West (33% and 71%, respectively) [4].

![Germans and Americans have differing views of international organizations and economic powers.](image5)  
![Ideological differences shape views of the UN, EU, and Russia in both countries.](image6)  

In summary, Americans and Germans differ significantly in their views of international organizations and economic powers, influenced by ideological leanings, historical contexts, and geopolitical realities.

Americans are far more likely than Germans to view military force as necessary, with about eight-in-ten Americans believing it is sometimes required to maintain global order, compared to only half of Germans [5][9]. This divide is also evident across ideological lines: in the U.S., 90% of conservatives support the use of military force, while only 65% of liberals agree. In Germany, nearly six-in-ten on the ideological right see military force as necessary, compared to about a third on the left [1].

![Americans are more supportive of military force than Germans](image8)  

Regarding defense spending, Americans and Germans hold differing views. Half of Americans believe their European allies should maintain current defense spending levels, marking a shift from 2017 when 45% supported increased spending [3]. Germans are more divided, with about four-in-ten favoring increased defense spending and a similar share supporting maintaining current levels [7]. Republicans in the U.S. are more likely than Democrats to favor increased defense spending in Europe, but this view has declined among both groups since 2017 [2].

![Germans are divided on increasing or maintaining defense spending](image6)  

Age demographics play a significant role in perceptions of U.S.-Germany relations. In both countries, young people are the most positive about the relationship. In the U.S., 82% of those aged 18-29 view the relationship as good, compared to 73% of those aged 65 and older. Similarly, in Germany, 40% of young people see the relationship positively, while only 31% of the oldest age group agree [4][11].

![Younger generations in both countries view U.S.-Germany relations more positively](image3)  

In summary, Americans are more likely than Germans to see military force as necessary, and both nations differ in their views on defense spending. Younger demographics in both countries are more optimistic about U.S.-Germany relations.

Americans and Germans hold notably different views on military intervention and defense spending. In the U.S., about eight-in-ten Americans believe it is sometimes necessary to use military force to maintain order in the world, while only about half of Germans share this view [3]. This divide is further emphasized by ideological differences: nine-in-ten American conservatives see military force as necessary, compared to only 65% of liberals. In Germany, nearly six-in-ten on the ideological right agree, but only about a third on the left do [1].

When it comes to defense spending, Americans are more likely than Germans to support increased military budgets for European allies. Half of Americans believe European allies should maintain current spending levels, a shift from 2017 when 45% advocated for increases. In Germany, the public is split, with about four-in-ten favoring increased defense spending and a similar share preferring to maintain current levels [9][12]. Additionally, 85% of Americans consider U.S. military bases in Germany important to their country’s security, whereas only about half of Germans agree [5][8].

![Americans and Germans differ on defense spending priorities](image5)  
The chart illustrates how Americans are divided on whether European allies should increase or maintain defense spending, while Germans are similarly split on their own country’s defense budget.

![Germans are less convinced of U.S. military bases' importance](image8)  
This chart shows that while 78% of Americans agree U.S. military bases in Germany are important, only 47% of Germans share this view.

These differences extend to NATO obligations. Six-in-ten Americans believe their country should defend a NATO ally against a potential Russian attack, while an equal share of Germans oppose such intervention [11]. This contrast highlights the broader divergence in how the two nations perceive military force and security.

American and German opinions on defense spending have shown notable shifts and partisan divides over recent years. In the U.S., there has been a decline in the belief that European allies should increase their defense spending, with half of Americans now favoring maintaining current levels, compared to 45% in 2017 [3]. This shift is more pronounced among Republicans, where support for increased European defense spending fell by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019, with a more modest decline among Democrats [9]. ![Decline in U.S. support for increased European defense spending](image2)

In Germany, public opinion on defense spending is divided, with about four-in-ten favoring increases and a similar share supporting maintaining current levels. This marks a change from 2017, when half of Germans were content with defense spending and a third wanted increases [8]. Partisan gaps are evident, with CDU/CSU supporters more likely to favor spending increases, while Greens are more skeptical, with only 28% supporting higher defense budgets [11]. ![German partisan views on defense spending](image4)

Americans largely view U.S. military bases in Germany as important to national security (85%), with nearly six-in-ten seeing them as very important [5]. However, this view is not shared by Germans, where only about half see these bases as important for German security, while 45% disagree [7]. ![U.S. and German views on military bases](image7)

In summary, American opinions have shifted toward maintaining European defense spending, particularly among Republicans, while Germans remain divided, with partisan differences influencing their views.

From 2017 to 2019, views on national defense spending in both the U.S. and Germany underwent notable shifts, with partisan divides playing a significant role in shaping perspectives.  

In the U.S., there was a decline in the belief that European allies should increase their defense spending. In 2017, 45% of Americans supported this idea, but by 2019, only 35% held the same view, reflecting a 10-percentage-point drop [7]. This shift was more pronounced among Republicans, with support falling by 14 percentage points, while Democrats also saw a modest decline [12]. Despite this, support for the U.S. military presence in Germany remained high across parties, with 85% of Americans seeing these bases as important to U.S. security interests [6]. Republicans were particularly likely to emphasize this importance, with nine-in-ten viewing the bases as crucial, compared to about eight-in-ten Democrats [8].  

In Germany, public opinion on defense spending became more divided. While about half of Germans were content with defense spending levels in 2017, by 2019, only about four-in-ten held this view, with a similar share advocating for increases [3]. Partisan differences were evident, as supporters of the CDU/CSU were more supportive of defense spending increases, while only 28% of Greens supported such a move [1]. Views on the importance of U.S. military bases in Germany also varied by age, with younger Germans more skeptical—roughly six-in-ten aged 18 to 29 doubted the bases’ contribution to national security, compared to 61% of those 65 and older who saw them as important [10].  

Both countries also saw stable views on whether Europeans were spending too much on defense, with relatively few in either nation holding this belief [2].  

![Support for U.S. military bases in Germany by age group](image5)  
![Partisan views on U.S. military presence in Germany](image3)  

In summary, from 2017 to 2019, Americans became less inclined to support increased defense spending by European allies, while Germans became more divided on whether to increase or maintain their own spending. Partisan and generational differences further shaped these evolving perspectives.

In the U.S., political affiliations significantly influence opinions on increasing defense spending in Europe. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely than Democrats to favor increased defense spending in Europe. However, support among Republicans for European allies to boost their defense budgets has declined by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019, with a more modest decline among Democrats [2]. ![Support for increased defense spending among Republicans and Democrats has declined over time](image7).

In Germany, partisan differences also shape views on defense spending. Supporters of the CDU/CSU are more in favor of increasing defense spending, whereas only 28% of Greens support such an increase. The SPD falls in the middle, with 41% in favor of higher defense spending [9]. ![German political parties differ in their support for increased defense spending](image3).

These trends highlight the impact of political ideology on defense spending opinions in both countries, with shifts over time reflecting changing geopolitical priorities and domestic political dynamics.

Age differences in Germany and political affiliations in the U.S. significantly shape perceptions of the importance of U.S. military bases in Germany and the selection of foreign policy partners.

In Germany, younger generations are more skeptical about the importance of U.S. military bases. Roughly six-in-ten Germans aged 18 to 29 believe these bases do not contribute to German national security, while 61% of those aged 65 and older view them as important to Germany’s defense[10]. This generational divide is evident in the data: ![Younger Germans are more likely to doubt the importance of U.S. military bases](image8).

In the U.S., political affiliation influences views on foreign policy partners and the importance of military bases in Germany. While both Republicans and Democrats agree that the UK is their most important partner, Republicans are more likely to prioritize Israel (26%) compared to Democrats (9%). Democrats, on the other hand, emphasize Canada and Mexico more. However, both parties rank Germany similarly as the fifth most or second-most important foreign policy partner[9]. ![Republicans prioritize Israel more than Democrats, while both rank Germany similarly](image1).

Regarding the U.S. military presence in Germany, there is a partisan divide, though overall support remains high. Among Republicans, 85% see U.S. military bases in Germany as important to U.S. security, while 63% of Democrats share this view[12]. The data also shows that 69% of Americans want to cooperate more with Germany, a sentiment that has grown over time[7]. ![Republicans and Democrats both support U.S. military bases in Germany, though Republicans more strongly](image8).

In summary, younger Germans doubt the importance of U.S. military bases, while older Germans see them as vital. In the U.S., political affiliations influence the choice of foreign policy partners, but both parties support the military presence in Germany.

Views on U.S. global engagement and handling of international issues vary significantly across political affiliations and educational backgrounds. Political partisanship plays a major role in shaping these perspectives. For instance, while $64\%$ of liberal Democrats believe the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems, only $44\%$ of conservative and moderate Democrats share this view [3]. In contrast, about three-quarters of Republicans, regardless of their ideological leanings, prefer that the U.S. focus on its own problems rather than assisting other nations [7]. 

![Opinions on assisting other countries differ by party affiliation, with Democrats more supportive than Republicans](image5)

Education also influences attitudes toward global engagement. Postgraduates are the most supportive, with six-in-ten advocating for U.S. assistance to other countries, while clear majorities of those with some college experience or only a high school diploma prioritize addressing domestic issues [6]. This educational divide is further illustrated in critical assessments of U.S. pandemic handling, where around two-thirds of postgraduates and college graduates criticize the U.S. response, compared to just $43\%$ of those with a high school education or less [10]. 

![Educational background correlates with critical views of U.S. handling of the pandemic](image4)

Partisan and ideological differences are even more pronounced in evaluations of U.S. performance during the pandemic. Liberal Democrats are the most critical, with $81\%$ rating the U.S. response as poor or only fair, while only $22\%$ of conservative Republicans share this view [12]. These divisions extend to broader assessments of U.S. global influence, with liberal Democrats far more pessimistic about America’s future standing than their Republican counterparts [12]. 

![Partisan differences in evaluations of U.S. pandemic handling and global influence](image3)

Overall, political affiliation and education level significantly shape perspectives on U.S. global engagement and international issue management, with Democrats and more educated individuals generally more supportive of international assistance but also more critical of U.S. performance.

Political affiliations and educational backgrounds significantly shape Americans’ perceptions of the U.S. and China’s handling of the COVID-19 pandemic. 

Partisan divides are stark in evaluating the U.S. response. **71% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents** praise the U.S.’s handling of the outbreak, while only **27% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents** share this view [6]. This gap is further amplified among ideological lines, with **liberal Democrats** holding more negative views than moderate or conservative Democrats [7]. ![Partisan differences in U.S. response evaluation](image2) ![Ideological divides in U.S. response evaluations](image4)

When it comes to China, **Republicans are more critical** than Democrats, with **80% of conservative Republicans** saying China has not handled the crisis well, compared to a smaller majority of Democrats [9]. However, **six-in-ten or more in every age group** are critical of China’s performance, with older Americans being particularly negative [11]. ![Partisan and age differences in China’s response evaluation](image6)

Education also plays a role. **Two-thirds of Americans with postgraduate degrees** and **six-in-ten college graduates** criticize the U.S. response, compared to **four-in-ten with a high school degree or less** [10]. ![Educational differences in U.S. response evaluation](image2) ![Educational divides in U.S. response evaluations](image4)

In summary, political affiliation drives sharp differences in perceptions of the U.S. and China’s COVID-19 responses, while higher education correlates with increased criticism of the U.S. approach.

Political affiliations significantly influence Americans' perceptions of how the U.S. and China have handled the COVID-19 pandemic. Regarding the U.S., there is a stark partisan divide: 71% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents believe the U.S. has done a good or excellent job, compared to just 27% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents [3]. This gap is also reflected in assessments of China’s response. While majorities across both parties criticize China’s handling of the pandemic, conservatives are particularly critical, with 80% of conservative Republicans saying China has not done a good job, compared to a smaller majority of Democrats [9]. 

![A chart showing partisan differences in U.S. and China’s COVID-19 response evaluations](image7)

The partisan divide is less pronounced when evaluating other countries. For instance, Democrats are slightly more likely than Republicans to praise Germany and South Korea’s handling of the outbreak, but the gap is less than 10 percentage points [11]. This suggests that while partisanship heavily colors views of the U.S. and China, it plays a smaller role in shaping opinions about other nations’ responses. 

![A chart illustrating the partisan gap in U.S. and international COVID-19 response evaluations](image6)

Overall, political affiliation strongly influences how Americans perceive the U.S. and China’s handling of the pandemic, with Republicans more likely to approve of the U.S. and criticize China compared to Democrats.

Perceptions of the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries in handling the coronavirus show significant differences along partisan lines. While 60% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from the international response, only 28% of Republicans and Republican leaners share this view [5]. This divide is even more pronounced among the most ideological groups: 67% of liberal Democrats think the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations, compared to just 25% of conservative Republicans [8]. 

These perceptions align with trust levels in international organizations like the WHO and EU. Liberal Democrats are far more likely to trust information from the WHO (86%) and the EU (79%) than conservative Republicans, where only 27% trust the WHO and 49% trust the EU [2][image3]. This partisan gap is also evident in evaluations of the WHO’s handling of the pandemic: 62% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents say the WHO has done at least a good job, compared to 28% of Republicans and GOP leaners [4].

Interestingly, those who believe the U.S. can learn from other countries, regardless of party, are more likely to think other nations are handling the pandemic effectively [3][9]. For example, 70% of Democrats and 48% of Republicans who think the U.S. can learn from other countries say Germany is handling the pandemic well, compared to 71% and 62% respectively for South Korea [image5][image6]. This suggests that trust in international responses and perceptions of the U.S.'s ability to learn from them are deeply intertwined with political affiliation. 

![Trust levels in international organizations like the WHO and EU vary significantly by political affiliation](image3)  
![Perceptions of the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries differ by political affiliation](image5)  

In summary, Democrats are more likely than Republicans to believe the U.S. can learn from other countries and to trust international organizations, reflecting a broader partisan divide in views on global cooperation during the pandemic.

Views about the future influence of the U.S., EU, and China after the coronavirus outbreak vary significantly based on political affiliation and education level. 

**U.S. Influence**:  
Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to believe the U.S.’s international influence will strengthen after the crisis, while Democrats are four times more likely than Republicans to expect it to weaken [1]. Within the Democratic Party, liberal supporters are 20 percentage points more likely than conservatives and moderates to foresee a decline in U.S. influence [1]. Education also plays a role, with Americans who have completed higher levels of education more likely to think the country’s global influence will recede [10]. For example, 45% of those with postgraduate education hold this view [10].  

![About 41% of respondents believe U.S. influence will remain the same post-pandemic, with variations by education and political affiliation](image1)  

**EU Influence**:  
Majorities in both parties believe the EU’s international influence will remain unaffected by the pandemic [3]. However, there are slight partisan differences, with 61% of Republicans and 57% of Democrats holding this view [8].  

![59% of respondents expect the EU’s influence to stay the same post-pandemic](image8)  

**China Influence**:  
Partisan divides are stark regarding China’s future influence. Roughly six-in-ten Republicans believe China’s international clout will diminish after the outbreak, compared to just 40% of Democrats [6]. Age also influences these views, with older Americans (65+) being 16 percentage points more likely than those under 30 to expect a decline in China’s influence [6]. Half of Americans overall believe China’s global influence will decrease [12].  

![Half of Americans expect China’s influence to decline post-pandemic, with notable partisan and age divides](image5)  

In summary, Republicans tend to be more optimistic about U.S. influence and more pessimistic about China’s, while Democrats are more likely to foresee a decline in U.S. influence. Education levels further shape these views, with higher education correlating with expectations of reduced U.S. influence. The EU’s influence is largely seen as stable across political lines.

Americans are divided in their predictions about how the global influence of the U.S. and China will change after the coronavirus outbreak, with significant variations across demographic and political groups. 

When it comes to the U.S., Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to believe the U.S.’s international influence will strengthen, while Democrats are four times more likely to expect it to weaken. Liberal Democrats are particularly pessimistic, with a 20 percentage point gap compared to their conservative and moderate counterparts [3]. Additionally, education plays a role; those with higher education levels are more likely to foresee a decline in U.S. influence. For instance, 45% of postgraduate-educated Americans predict a reduction in the country’s global clout [9]. ![Republicans are more optimistic about U.S. influence post-pandemic](image5)

Regarding China, half of Americans believe its global influence will decrease, with Republicans being more likely (60%) than Democrats (40%) to hold this view. Older Americans (65+) are 16 percentage points more likely than those under 30 to predict a decline in China’s influence [11]. ![Older Americans and Republicans are more likely to predict a decline in China’s influence](image6)

In contrast, fewer Americans (about one-third) believe the EU’s influence will change significantly, with majorities in both parties expecting it to remain unaffected [4]. ![EU influence is expected to remain stable across party lines](image5)

Overall, partisan and age divides are the most significant factors shaping these predictions, with Republicans and older adults more likely to foresee a decline in China’s influence and a strengthening of U.S. influence, while Democrats and younger, more educated individuals are more skeptical about the U.S.’s post-pandemic global role.

Americans generally hold a negative view of China’s handling of the coronavirus outbreak, with nearly two-thirds stating that China has not done a good job, including 37% who believe the country has performed poorly [9]. This sentiment is reflected in the widespread distrust of coronavirus information from the Chinese government and the belief that China has mishandled the crisis [7].   

When it comes to China’s future influence in world affairs, half of Americans believe its global clout will decline after the pandemic, while one-third think it will remain the same, and nearly one-in-five anticipate an increase [11]. There are notable partisan differences in these perceptions. Roughly six-in-ten Republicans believe China’s international influence will diminish, compared to just 40% of Democrats [5]. Older Americans (65+) are also more likely than younger adults to predict a decline in China’s global standing [5].

![Americans' views on China's global influence](image4)  

Partisan divides are further highlighted in attitudes toward China. Republicans, particularly conservative Republicans, are significantly more negative about China’s handling of the outbreak and its global role [2][10]. For instance, eight-in-ten conservative Republicans believe China has not handled the crisis well, compared to a lower share of Democrats [2]. These differences underscore the broader polarization in American perceptions of China amidst the pandemic.  

![Partisan differences in views on China's handling of the outbreak](image3)  

Overall, Americans’ perceptions of China’s response to the pandemic and its future influence in world affairs are shaped by strong partisan divides, with Republicans expressing more negative evaluations than Democrats.

Partisan views on the U.S. role in addressing global challenges and its international influence after the coronavirus outbreak show significant differences from 2013 to 2020. Republicans and Democrats have diverging perspectives on whether the U.S. should focus on its own problems or help other countries, as well as on the expected impact of the pandemic on U.S. global influence.

![Republicans are more likely to believe the U.S. does too much in helping address global challenges](image1)  
From 2013 to 2020, Republicans increasingly believe the U.S. does too much in addressing global challenges, with 62% holding this view in 2020 compared to 52% in 2013. In contrast, only 26% of Democrats share this opinion, a smaller share that has remained relatively stable over the years [7].

![Democrats are more likely to believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other countries about combatting COVID-19](image2)  
Democrats are also more likely than Republicans to think the U.S. can learn from other countries about slowing the spread of COVID-19, with 60% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents saying the U.S. can learn a great deal, compared to just 28% of Republicans and Republican leaners [10].

![Democrats are more likely to expect a decline in U.S. international influence after the pandemic](image6)  
Regarding the pandemic’s impact on U.S. international influence, 56% of liberal Democrats believe the U.S. will have less influence in world affairs, compared to just 8% of conservative Republicans. This stark divide reflects broader partisan splits, with Democrats being four times more likely than Republicans to expect a weakening of U.S. influence [1][4].

![Views on whether the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems show a partisan divide](image3)  
On the question of whether the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems, 64% of Democrats believe it should, while only 22% of Republicans agree. This highlights a significant partisan gap in perspectives on America’s global responsibilities [12].

In summary, Republicans tend to favor a focus on domestic issues and are skeptical of learning from other countries, while Democrats are more supportive of international collaboration and foresee a decline in U.S. global influence post-pandemic.

Partisan views on the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries and its role in global affairs during the coronavirus pandemic vary significantly. Liberal Democrats are more likely to believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations about combating the virus, with 67% holding this view, compared to just 25% of conservative Republicans [5]. ![Partisan differences in learning from other countries](image5) Additionally, 60% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents say the U.S. can learn a great deal from international responses, while only 28% of Republicans and Republican leaners agree [11].

Regarding the U.S.'s role in global affairs, 64% of liberal Democrats believe the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems, a stance shared by only 22% of conservative Republicans [9]. ![Partisan differences in U.S. global role](image5) Furthermore, 56% of liberal Democrats think the U.S. will have less influence in world affairs post-pandemic, compared to just 8% of conservative Republicans [3]. These stark contrasts highlight the ideological divide in perceptions of America’s global engagement and its capacity to learn from others during the pandemic.

Views on whether the U.S. should focus on its own problems or help other countries vary significantly across political affiliations and educational levels. 

Among Republicans, **77%** of conservatives and **61%** of those identifying as more moderate or liberal believe the U.S. should deal with its own problems and let other countries manage as best they can [11]. In contrast, **64%** of liberal Democrats and **44%** of conservative/moderate Democrats think the U.S. should assist other countries with their issues [6]. ![Republicans and Democrats show stark differences in whether the U.S. should focus on its own problems or help others](image8)

Education also plays a role in shaping these views. **60%** of postgraduates support helping other countries, whereas college graduates are evenly split. Conversely, majorities of those with some college experience or only a high school diploma believe the U.S. should prioritize its own problems [3]. ![Educational attainment influences views on whether the U.S. should help other countries](image6)

Overall, these differences highlight the ideological and educational divides in opinions about America’s role in the world.

Perceptions of the U.S. role in solving world problems vary significantly by political affiliation and have become more polarized over time. A majority of Republicans (62%) now believe the U.S. does too much to help solve world problems, while only 8% think it does too little, and 29% say it does the right amount [2]. This sentiment aligns with their broader view that the U.S. should focus on its own problems and let other countries manage theirs, a stance supported by about three-quarters of Republicans [3]. ![Most Republicans believe the U.S. does too much to solve world problems](image1)

On the other hand, a plurality of Democrats (48%) feel the U.S. does too little to help solve global challenges, while 26% each believe it does too much or the right amount [2]. Over half of Democrats (51%) support the idea that the U.S. should help other countries deal with their problems, especially among liberal Democrats (64%) [12]. ![Democrats are more supportive of the U.S. helping other countries](image2)

Over time, the partisan gap in these views has widened significantly. In earlier surveys, the divide between Republicans and Democrats was far less pronounced [5], but by 2020, 62% of Republicans felt the U.S. does too much, compared to just 26% of Democrats [10]. ![The partisan gap in views on U.S. global involvement has widened over time](image7)

In summary, Republicans increasingly believe the U.S. should focus on domestic issues, while Democrats, particularly liberals, advocate for greater global engagement, reflecting a growing polarization in perceptions of the U.S. role in the world. ![Republicans and Democrats hold increasingly divergent views on U.S. global involvement](image8)

Views on U.S. global engagement and domestic priorities vary significantly by political affiliation and educational attainment. 

Among Republicans, 62% believe the U.S. does too much to help solve world problems, with only 8% saying it does too little and 29% stating it does the right amount [1]. This sentiment is stronger among conservative Republicans, with 75% preferring the U.S. to focus on its own problems rather than assisting other countries [8]. Conversely, Democrats are more divided: 48% say the U.S. does too little to help globally, while 26% each believe it does too much or the right amount [1]. Within Democrats, 64% of liberals advocate for helping other countries, compared to 44% of conservative and moderate Democrats [2]. 

Educational attainment also plays a role in shaping these views. Postgraduates are most supportive of global engagement, with 60% favoring U.S. assistance to other countries, while those with a high school diploma or less are more likely to prioritize domestic issues [3]. This pattern is reflected in the data, where 56% of postgraduates believe the U.S. should help other countries, compared to 29% of those with a high school education [image7]. 

Overall, there is a stark partisan divide, with Republicans leaning toward domestic focus and Democrats more split but generally more supportive of global engagement. Higher education levels correlate with greater support for international assistance. ![A graph showing partisan and educational differences in views on U.S. global engagement](image7) ![A chart illustrating Republicans' preference for domestic over global focus](image8) ![Data on education-level differences in opinions about U.S. global assistance](image1) ![A visualization of partisan divides in global engagement views](image2) ![Educational attainment's influence on perspectives about U.S. global involvement](image3)

Americans’ confidence in President Biden’s ability to deal effectively with China is relatively low compared to their views on the seriousness of issues related to China. While 53% of Americans express confidence in Biden’s handling of China, this is the lowest among the foreign policy issues tested, such as improving relationships with allies (67%) and dealing with terrorism or climate change (around 60%) [5]. This lack of confidence is particularly pronounced among Republicans, with only 19% expressing confidence compared to 83% of Democrats [7].

At the same time, Americans view several China-related issues as very serious: 53% see the loss of U.S. jobs to China as a very serious problem, and 50% view China’s growing military power as a very serious issue [6]. Cyberattacks from China are also a major concern, with 91% of Americans considering them at least somewhat serious, including 59% who view them as very serious [7][12].  

![Cyberattacks from China are a major concern, with 59% viewing them as very serious.](image7)  

![Americans are particularly concerned about China’s growing military power, with 50% seeing it as a very serious problem.](image2)  

Despite these significant concerns, confidence in Biden’s ability to address them lags. For example, while 50% view China’s military power as a very serious issue, only 53% are confident in Biden’s ability to deal effectively with China overall [5][6]. This disconnect suggests that while Americans recognize the gravity of China-related challenges, they are less assured of Biden’s capacity to manage them.  

![Only 53% of Americans are confident in Biden’s ability to deal effectively with China.](image8)

Confidence in President Biden's ability to deal effectively with China varies significantly across demographic groups. Women (59%) are more confident than men (48%), and Black (82%) and Hispanic adults (70%) express more confidence than White adults (43%)[10]. Those with a college degree (60%) also show higher confidence compared to those with less schooling (50%)[10]. However, partisan differences are stark: 83% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning individuals have confidence in Biden on China, while only 19% of Republicans and Republican-leaners say the same. Among Republicans, conservative members (10%) have even less confidence than moderates or liberals (30%)[7].

![Demographic confidence in Biden to deal with China](image7)

Americans have significant concerns about various issues in the U.S.-China relationship. The most serious problems, as perceived by the public, include cyberattacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China’s growing military power, and China’s policies on human rights. Over half of Americans describe these issues as very serious[12]. 

![Primary concerns regarding China](image8)

Concerns about these issues have generally increased more among Republicans than Democrats since 2020. For example, the share of Republicans who view the loss of U.S. jobs to China as a very serious problem rose by 14 percentage points, while there was no significant change among Democrats[6]. Additionally, older Americans (ages 65 and older) are more concerned about China-related issues than younger adults (ages 18-29), with a gap of at least 20 percentage points on most issues[1]. 

In summary, confidence in Biden regarding China is higher among women, Black and Hispanic adults, and those with higher education, but significantly lower among Republicans. The primary concerns about China center on cyberattacks, job losses, military power, and human rights policies.

Confidence in President Biden's ability to deal effectively with China varies significantly across demographic and political groups. Among Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents, 83% express confidence in Biden’s handling of China, while only 19% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents share this view[3][12]. Conservative Republicans are particularly skeptical, with just 10% expressing confidence, compared to 30% of moderate or liberal Republicans[12]. ![Partisan differences in confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China](image6)

Demographic differences are also notable. Women (59%) are more confident than men (48%) in Biden’s ability to handle China. Black (82%) and Hispanic adults (70%) express more confidence than White adults (43%). Additionally, those with a college degree (60%) are more likely to trust Biden on this issue compared to those without a college degree (50%)[11]. ![Demographic differences in confidence in Biden's ability to deal with China](image3)

When it comes to concerns about China, Americans identify several issues as very serious. Cyberattacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China’s growing military power, and China’s policies on human rights are highlighted as the top concerns, with 53% viewing job losses and military power as very serious issues, and 50% expressing similar concern about human rights[2][5][7]. ![Serious concerns about China](image7)

Americans also prioritize human rights over economic relations, with a majority favoring promoting human rights in China even if it harms economic ties![American preferences on human rights vs. economic relations with China](image1). Overall, while confidence in Biden varies widely across groups, concerns about China’s actions and policies remain consistently serious across the political spectrum.

Confidence levels in President Joe Biden’s ability to deal effectively with China vary significantly across demographic groups. Women (59%) are more confident than men (48%), and Black (82%) and Hispanic adults (70%) express higher confidence compared to White adults (43%). Additionally, those with a college degree are more likely to trust Biden’s handling of China (60%) than those with less education (50%) [7]. Partisan differences are stark, with 83% of Democrats and Democratic leaners expressing confidence, compared to only 19% of Republicans and Republican leaners. Conservative Republicans (10%) are the least confident, while moderate/liberal Republicans (30%) and conservative/moderate Democrats (86%) show more trust [11].

![Confidence in Biden varies by demographic, with women and minorities expressing higher trust](image8)

Americans’ major concerns regarding China include cyber attacks, the loss of U.S. jobs, China’s growing military power, and its human rights policies. Cyber attacks evoke the most concern, with roughly two-thirds of Americans viewing them as a very serious problem [2]. The loss of U.S. jobs to China is seen as a very serious problem by 53%, an increase of 6 points since 2020 [6]. China’s military power and human rights policies also rank high, with significant concerns expressed across partisan lines, though Republicans tend to express greater concern than Democrats [8].

![Concerns about China include cyber attacks, job losses, and military power](image3)

In summary, confidence in Biden varies by gender, race, education, and party affiliation, while concerns about China center on cyber attacks, job losses, military power, and human rights.

Americans have critical views of both China’s handling of the COVID-19 pandemic and its respect for personal freedoms. More than half of Americans (54%) believe China has done a bad job managing the pandemic, with 28% describing its response as very bad [2]. Similarly, an overwhelming 90% of Americans say the Chinese government does not respect the personal freedoms of its people, a sentiment that cuts across age, education, and political groups [9]. 

This critical perspective is further supported by data showing that 45% of Americans rate China’s pandemic response as very bad, while only 2% think it has been very good ![China’s pandemic response is viewed very negatively](image1). When it comes to personal freedoms, 90% of Americans believe China does not respect its citizens’ rights, a view that has grown stronger in recent years [9].

Despite these criticisms, Americans are equally critical of their own country’s pandemic response, with 58% describing the U.S. handling as bad [10]. ![The U.S. is seen as equally poor in pandemic response](image7). This suggests that while Americans are deeply concerned about China’s actions, they also recognize shortcomings within their own government.

When it comes to U.S. priorities in its relations with China, Americans are divided. A significant portion (56%) believes the U.S. should prioritize promoting human rights, even if it harms economic relations ![Americans prioritize human rights in U.S.-China relations](image6). This contrasts with those who prioritize economic relations over addressing human rights issues. The emphasis on human rights aligns with widespread concerns about China’s policies, including its crackdowns in Hong Kong and persecution of ethnic minorities [9].

In summary, Americans view China’s handling of the pandemic and its respect for personal freedoms negatively, with strong support for prioritizing human rights in U.S.-China relations.

When it comes to balancing the promotion of human rights versus strengthening economic relations with China, political affiliations in the U.S. show some interesting patterns. A significant majority of both Democrats and Republicans (about seven-in-ten) believe the U.S. should prioritize human rights, even if it harms economic ties with China [1]. However, within these groups, differences emerge based on ideological leanings. Conservative Republicans are more likely than moderate or liberal Republicans to emphasize human rights [1]. Similarly, liberal Democrats are the most likely among Democrats to prioritize human rights over economic dealings [1]. 

![Large shares of conservative Republicans and liberal Democrats prioritize human rights over economic ties with China](image6)

This shared concern over human rights is one of the few areas where Democrats and Republicans largely agree, as both parties increasingly view China’s human rights policies as a major issue in bilateral relations [7]. However, when it comes to economic and trade policies, Republicans (especially conservative Republicans) are far more likely to favor a tougher stance against China, with 81% supporting this approach compared to about six-in-ten Democrats who prefer building stronger economic ties [10]. 

![Republicans are more likely to favor a tougher stance on China, while Democrats lean toward stronger economic ties](image2)

Despite these differences, the overall sentiment among Americans is clear: 70% believe the U.S. should promote human rights in China, even if it harms economic relations [6]. This reflects a broader consensus that human rights should take precedence over economic considerations in U.S.-China relations. 

![Americans largely agree that promoting human rights in China is a priority, even at the expense of economic ties](image3)

When it comes to prioritizing human rights over economic relations with China, there is a strong consensus across political affiliations in the U.S. About 70% of Americans overall believe the U.S. should promote human rights in China, even if it harms economic relations [7]. This view is particularly pronounced among liberal Democrats, with large shares prioritizing human rights over economic ties. Conservatives Republicans are also more likely than their moderate or liberal counterparts within the party to hold this opinion [6]. For instance, 7 in 10 Democrats and Republicans agree on promoting human rights at the potential cost of economic relations [6].

However, opinions diverge when it comes to trade policies. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents overwhelmingly favor a tougher stance on China, with 72% advocating for this approach. This sentiment is even stronger among conservative Republicans, with 81% supporting a tougher stance [12]. In contrast, about 6 in 10 Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents prefer focusing on building stronger economic ties with China, a sentiment consistent across liberal and moderate Democrats [12].

![A chart showing the percentage of Americans prioritizing human rights over economic relations with China](image1)  
[7]

![A breakdown of political affiliations favoring a tougher stance on China versus strengthening economic ties](image7)  
[12]

In summary, while both Democrats and Republicans prioritize human rights over economic relations, Republicans are far more likely to advocate for a tougher trade stance, whereas Democrats lean towards fostering stronger economic ties with China.

Views on U.S. trade policies with China and preferences for either getting tougher or building stronger relationships vary significantly across political affiliations in the U.S. Republicans, particularly conservative Republicans, overwhelmingly favor a tougher stance on China, with 81% of conservative Republicans and 72% of Republicans overall supporting this approach[2]. They also tend to view tariffs on Chinese goods positively, with about half of Republicans (and notably more among conservatives) believing tariffs are good for the U.S.[3][5]. In contrast, Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents lean toward building stronger ties with China, with about six-in-ten favoring this approach[2]. Democrats are also more critical of tariffs, with most viewing them as bad for the U.S.[3][5]. 

Public opinion on tariffs reflects these partisan divides. While 44% of Americans overall say tariffs are bad for the U.S., 30% think they are good[9]. Republicans are more likely to see tariffs as beneficial, while Democrats are more likely to view them negatively[5]. However, a majority of Americans (56%) report that tariffs have had no real effect on their personal lives, with little variation by income or geography[9]. 

![Republicans favor a tougher stance on China, while Democrats lean toward building stronger ties](image1)

The preference for prioritizing human rights over economic relations, even if it harms U.S.-China ties, is shared by about seven-in-ten Democrats and Republicans, though this sentiment is stronger among conservative Republicans and liberal Democrats[10]. Younger Americans (ages 18-29) are more likely to emphasize building stronger relationships with China compared to older age groups[12].

![Most Americans prioritize human rights over economic relations with China](image4)

Overall, Republicans tend to view the U.S.-China economic relationship as bad (64% of Americans share this view[11]) and support a tougher approach, while Democrats are more inclined to focus on strengthening ties and are critical of tariffs. These differences highlight the polarized perspectives on trade policies and U.S.-China relations based on political affiliation.

The perspectives of different political affiliations on the impacts of tariffs and international students in the U.S. reveal notable contrasts. 

When it comes to tariffs, Republicans are more likely to view them positively, with about half saying increased tariffs on Chinese and other foreign products were good for the U.S. This sentiment is especially strong among conservative Republicans, while moderate or liberal Republicans are divided. Democrats, on the other hand, most often say the tariffs were bad for the U.S. [3] [4]. ![Most Republicans view tariffs positively, while Democrats disagree.](image2)

Regarding international students, partisanship also plays a role. While both Democrats and Republicans generally see international students in a positive light, the degree of support differs. $92\%$ of Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents view visiting students positively, compared to $67\%$ of Republicans and Republican leaners [1]. However, when focusing specifically on Chinese students, Republicans are more likely than Democrats to favor limitations on their enrollment at U.S. colleges and universities [12]. ![Republicans are more likely than Democrats to support limiting Chinese students.](image5)

In summary, Republicans tend to support tariffs and are more inclined to limit Chinese student enrollment, whereas Democrats generally oppose tariffs and are more supportive of international students overall.

Opinions on limiting Chinese students in U.S. universities vary significantly across age groups and political affiliations, and these views are often tied to perceptions of Chinese leadership. Americans aged 50 and older are more likely to support such limitations, with roughly seven-in-ten in favor, while younger Americans (ages 18-29) oppose the idea by nearly two-thirds [7]. This generational divide is mirrored in confidence levels in Chinese President Xi Jinping: 53% of those aged 65 and older have no confidence in Xi, compared to 35% of those aged 18-29 [10].

![Older Americans are more likely to support limits on Chinese students and distrust Xi Jinping](image4)  
The image shows that 69% of Americans aged 50-64 and 65+ support limiting Chinese students, while only 29% of those aged 18-29 do.

Politically, Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely to favor restrictions on Chinese students compared to Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents [7]. This aligns with broader partisan differences, as Republicans are also more likely to view China as an enemy and support tougher economic policies toward China [4]. Conversely, Democrats tend to have slightly more confidence in Xi, with only a third saying they have no confidence at all [12].

![Republicans are more likely to support limits on Chinese students than Democrats](image8)  
The image illustrates that 58% of Republicans/Republican-leaning individuals support limiting Chinese students, compared to 42% of Democrats/Democratic-leaning individuals.

These trends suggest that older Americans and Republicans are more inclined to view China as a threat, both in terms of student exchanges and leadership trust, while younger Americans and Democrats adopt a more moderate or welcoming stance.

American perceptions of China have become significantly more negative from 2018 to 2021, with a sharp rise in cold feelings toward the country. In 2018, 46% of Americans felt "cold" toward China, but by 2021, that number had risen to 67%, a 21-point increase. The share of those who feel "very cold" (0-24 on a feeling thermometer) doubled, from 23% in 2018 to 47% in 2021 [1][7]. This shift is particularly pronounced among Republicans, with 62% now feeling "very cold," compared to 38% of Democrats [3]. ![Shift in negative feelings toward China](image4)

Several major concerns have fueled this growing negativity. First, economic issues loom large, with 64% of Americans describing U.S.-China economic relations as somewhat or very bad. Many cite China’s dominance as a manufacturing center, job losses to China, and concerns about cyberattacks and China’s growing technological power as significant problems [4][8]. ![Concerns over China's economic impact](image6)

Human rights violations, particularly China’s treatment of Uyghurs in Xinjiang, are another key driver. Half of Americans now view China’s human rights policies as a very serious problem, a 7-point increase since 2020 [5][8]. References to human rights are also among the top responses when Americans are asked what first comes to mind about China [10]. ![Human rights concerns in perceptions of China](image1)

Additionally, there is a growing consensus on the need to limit China’s power and influence. Nearly half of Americans (48%) believe this should be a top foreign policy priority, up 16 percentage points since 2018. Only 7% think it should not be a priority at all [6]. ![Prioritizing limiting China's influence](image4)

In summary, American perceptions of China have grown increasingly negative from 2018 to 2021, driven by concerns over economic competition, human rights violations, and China’s growing global influence.

Americans have grown increasingly concerned about several key issues in their relationship with China. Cyberattacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China’s growing military power, and China’s policies on human rights are particularly prominent, with half or more Americans describing these as *very* serious problems [1][3]. Concerns over China’s human rights policies, for instance, have risen by 7 percentage points in just one year, with 50% now viewing it as a very serious issue [1]. ![Growing concerns over China’s human rights policies and military power](image2)

Economic tensions also loom large. Around 64% of Americans describe economic relations between the U.S. and China as somewhat or very bad, with many expressing worries about China’s dominance in manufacturing and its impact on U.S. jobs [10]. ![Economic concerns dominate U.S.-China relations](image8)

Additionally, Americans are critical of China’s handling of global issues like climate change, with 79% saying China is doing a bad job, and the COVID-19 pandemic, where 54% view China’s response negatively [2][6]. ![Criticism of China’s handling of global issues](image5)

Partisan divides further shape these concerns. Republicans are more likely to view China as an enemy, support limiting Chinese students’ access to U.S. education, and advocate for tougher economic measures against China. Meanwhile, Democrats are more inclined to prioritize human rights, even at the expense of economic relations [9]. ![Partisan divides in U.S. views on China](image1)

Overall, concerns about China have intensified across multiple fronts, with economic, security, and human rights issues at the forefront of American perceptions. ![Rising concerns about China on many issues](image7)

Financial optimism among Hispanic subgroups has significantly increased from 2008 to 2015, with Latinos showing greater optimism than the general population. 

Among all Latinos, 81% expect their family’s financial situation to improve, a 14-percentage-point increase since 2008 [4]. This contrasts with the general population, where only 61% share this optimism, a modest 6-point rise during the same period [5]. ![Graph showing Hispanic and general public financial optimism trends](image5)

Breaking down by age, younger Latinos are particularly optimistic. About 90% of those under 30 expect financial improvement, a 13-point increase since 2008 [1]. Latinos aged 30-49 and 50-64 also saw gains of 16 percentage points each [1]. Even older Latinos (65+) experienced a 7-point rise in optimism [1].

Gender-wise, Latino men (+18 points) and Latina women (+11 points) both became more optimistic over the seven-year period [3]. Both U.S.-born and immigrant Latinos saw their optimism rise by 14 points, reaching 81% in 2015 [3]. ![Demographic breakdown of financial optimism changes](image8)

Education levels also influenced optimism. Latinos with some college education saw a 20-point increase, compared to +9 for high school graduates and +11 for those with less education [9]. ![Education level impact on financial optimism](image7)

Overall, Latinos have shown a faster rise in financial optimism than the general population, with the gap between the two groups reaching a 20-percentage-point difference in 2015, the largest since 2004 [10]. ![Comparison of Hispanic and general population financial optimism](image6)

Hispanics’ current financial situations and educational levels significantly shape their expectations for their children’s financial futures. Overall, 72% of Hispanic adults believe their children will be better off financially than they are, with 75% of immigrants and 70% of U.S.-born adults sharing this optimism [1]. ![Most Hispanics are optimistic about their children’s financial future](image3).

Those with a positive view of their current financial situation are more likely to expect their family’s finances to improve in the next year compared to those who rate their economic circumstances as only fair or poor [4]. This trend is further supported by data showing that Latino adults, especially those prospering, are most optimistic about their finances and their children’s futures [5]. ![Optimism about family finances has risen faster among Latinos than the general population](image4).

Educational attainment also plays a role. Latino high school graduates are the most optimistic, with 79% expecting their children to be better off—higher than those with some college experience (69%) or less than a high school education (71%) [10]. ![Hispanics with higher educational attainment are more optimistic about their children’s financial future](image3).

In summary, Hispanics in better financial conditions and those with higher educational levels are more likely to have positive expectations for their children’s financial futures.

Latinos have shown significant improvements in their perceptions of financial well-being and optimism about their financial future since 2000, particularly in the years following the Great Recession. The share of Latinos who expect their family’s finances to improve “a lot” or “some” rose from 67% in 2008 (during the Great Recession) to 81% in 2015, outpacing the general U.S. population, which saw a 6-point increase to 61% during the same period [4]. This optimism is also reflected in their views of their children’s financial future, with 72% of Latino adults expecting their children will be better off financially than they are now [3]. ![Latino optimism about family finances has risen faster than the general population](image1)

However, despite this growing confidence, economic indicators present a mixed picture. Median household income for Latinos has stagnated since the Great Recession, remaining at $42,491 in 2014, essentially unchanged from pre-recession levels [5]. The poverty rate, while improved from its peak of 26.5% in 2010, remains high at 23.6% in 2014, above pre-recession levels [5]. ![Hispanic median household income has stagnated since 2000](image2) 

Unemployment rates among Latinos have declined since the Great Recession, falling from a high of 12.8% in 2010 to 6.4% in late 2015, and further to 5.6% in early 2016 [6]. However, this rate remains above its pre-recession low of 5% in 2006 and is higher than that of non-Hispanic workers [6]. ![Latino unemployment rates have declined but remain above pre-recession levels](image7) 

In summary, while Latinos are increasingly optimistic about their financial future, economic progress in terms of income and poverty has been limited, and unemployment, though improved, remains elevated compared to pre-recession levels.

The trends in unemployment rates and economic perceptions between Hispanic and non-Hispanic populations reveal both progress and persistent challenges. While the Hispanic unemployment rate has improved since the Great Recession, falling from 12.8% in 2010 to 6.4% in late 2015 and 5.6% in early 2016, it remains above its pre-recession low of 5% in 2006 and higher than the rate for non-Hispanic workers [8]. ![Hispanic unemployment rate has improved but remains above pre-recession levels](image8).

Despite this, Hispanic perceptions of economic well-being have increased, with 35% of Hispanics rating economic conditions as good or excellent in 2015, compared to 25% of whites [5]. Additionally, 72% of Latino adults believe their children will be better off financially than they are [4], and 34% expect U.S. economic conditions to improve in the coming year—twice the share of other groups [5]. ![72% of Latinos expect their children to be better off financially](image1).

However, income and wealth disparities persist. Median household income for Hispanics stagnated at $42,491 in 2014, unchanged since the Great Recession, and the poverty rate of 23.6% in 2014 remains above pre-recession levels [2]. ![Hispanic median household income remains stagnant compared to all households](image2). Hispanic households also experienced the largest percentage decline in net worth through 2009, and their wealth continued to fall post-recession, unlike white households [2]. ![Wealth disparities persist for Hispanic households](image3).

These disparities are compounded by educational and generational factors. For instance, 56% of Latinos with some college education and 50% of U.S.-born Latinos rated their financial situation as excellent or good in 2015, compared to just 23% of those with less than a high school education and 31% of immigrants [9]. ![Educational attainment influences financial perceptions among Latinos](image3).

In summary, while Hispanic unemployment rates have declined and economic optimism has grown, income and wealth disparities remain significant, influenced by factors like education and generational status.

Hispanic households have faced distinct economic challenges compared to all U.S. households from 2000 to 2015, particularly in unemployment, income, poverty rates, and wealth.  

The unemployment rate for Hispanics has improved since the Great Recession, falling from a high of 12.8% in 2010 to 6.4% in late 2015, though it remains higher than the pre-recession low of 5% in 2006 and above the non-Hispanic unemployment rate [7]. ![Hispanic unemployment rate remains higher than non-Hispanic workers](image4). Median household income for Hispanics stagnated post-recession, at $42,491 in 2014, unchanged since the recession, mirroring trends in the general U.S. population [8]. ![Median household income for Hispanics remains unchanged since the Great Recession](image5).  

The Hispanic poverty rate, at 23.6% in 2014, is down from its peak of 26.5% in 2010 but still above pre-recession levels [8]. Wealth disparities are pronounced; Hispanic households experienced the largest percentage decline in net worth during the recession, and unlike white households, their net worth continued to fall afterward [8]. ![Hispanic households saw the largest decline in net worth during the recession](image5).  

In summary, while Hispanic households have seen improvements in unemployment and slight reductions in poverty, their income has stagnated, and wealth disparities persist compared to the general U.S. population.

Perceptions of personal financial situations among Latino groups improved significantly from 2008 to 2015. In 2015, 40% of Latinos reported their personal finances were in "excellent" or "good" shape, a 17 percentage point increase from 2008, when only 23% held a similarly positive view [10]. This improvement was widespread across most demographic subgroups. For example, ratings of personal finances rose by 17 points among U.S.-born Hispanics and by 18 points among foreign-born Hispanics [6]. Positive views of economic well-being also increased by 16 points among Latino men and 18 points among Latina women [6]. Additionally, Latinos ages 18 to 29 saw a dramatic 27 percentage point increase in positive financial assessments, with 48% reporting excellent or good financial shape in 2015 [2]. ![Latinos experienced significant gains in personal financial ratings from 2008 to 2015](image6)

However, perceptions of family income relative to the cost of living showed less improvement. Between 2014 and 2015, Hispanic views on this measure were unchanged, with about half saying they were falling behind financially, similar to the U.S. public as a whole [4]. In 2015, 53% of Latinos said their family income was not keeping up with the cost of living, while 37% reported it was staying about even and 10% said it was growing faster [11]. ![Hispanic views on family income relative to the cost of living remained stable between 2014 and 2015](image1)

Despite these mixed results, Latino economic perceptions were more positive in 2015 compared to 2004, when only 31% rated their financial condition as excellent or good [7]. In contrast, the general public’s financial outlook was lower in 2015 than in 2004, when 51% had a positive view [7]. ![Latino financial perceptions in 2015 were more positive than in 2004, unlike the general public](image5)

Internet usage and device ownership among seniors differ significantly from the general adult population, with distinct trends in daily engagement. While seniors are less likely to go online compared to all adults, those who do tend to incorporate it into their daily routines. For example, 71% of older internet users go online daily or nearly daily, and an additional 11% go online three to five times per week [1][7]. This trend is even more pronounced among seniors with broadband or smartphones, with 78% of broadband users and 84% of smartphone owners accessing the internet daily or nearly daily [7].

Device ownership among seniors is notably lower, especially for smartphones. Ownership decreases substantially after age 75, with only 10% of 75-79-year-olds and 5% of those 80+ owning smartphones [10]. ![Smartphone ownership declines drastically after age 75](image5). Broadband adoption also drops off sharply around age 75, with 65% of 65-69-year-olds having broadband at home, compared to just 21% of those 80+ [8][7]. ![Broadband adoption decreases significantly with age](image7).

Affluence and education play a significant role in tech adoption among seniors. Higher-income and more educated seniors use the internet and broadband at rates approaching or exceeding the general population [6][11]. For instance, 87% of college-educated seniors and 90% of those with household incomes over $75,000 go online, compared to 40% of those with a high school diploma or less and 39% of those earning under $30,000 [7]. ![Higher income and education correlate with greater internet usage](image7).

Seniors who use social networking sites (SNS) like Facebook (27% of the older adult population) tend to socialize more frequently, with 81% engaging with others daily or nearly daily, compared to 71% of online seniors who do not use SNS and 63% of those offline [9][12]. ![27% of seniors use social networking sites](image1).

In summary, internet usage among seniors is less frequent than among all adults, but those who go online do so regularly. Device ownership, especially smartphones, declines sharply with age, while higher income and education levels drive greater tech adoption.

Device ownership among older adults shows notable differences when compared to their internet usage patterns. While 77% of older adults own a cell phone of some kind, only 18% own a smartphone, a significantly lower rate than the general population [7]. ![Smartphone ownership among older adults is significantly lower than cell phone ownership.](image5) Additionally, tablet and e-book reader ownership is equally common among seniors, with 18% owning each device [4]. ![Tablet and e-book reader ownership is as common as smartphone ownership among older adults.](image6) 

Despite this, internet usage among older adults has been steadily increasing, with 59% of seniors now going online, a six percentage point increase from 2012 [6]. ![Internet usage among older adults has seen a steady increase over the years.](image4) Among internet users, 71% go online daily or almost daily, and 11% do so three to five times per week [5]. ![Older internet users show high frequency of online activity.](image3) However, broadband adoption at home is lower among seniors, with only 47% having access, compared to 94% of all adults [1]. ![Broadband adoption among older adults is significantly lower than the general population.](image1)

In summary, while device ownership among older adults is relatively lower, particularly for smartphones, their internet usage patterns reflect a growing engagement with digital technologies, albeit with slower adoption rates compared to the general population.

Device ownership and online activity among seniors differ significantly from the general adult population. While **55% of all adults own smartphones**, only **18% of seniors do** [1][5]. In contrast, tablets and e-book readers are equally popular among older adults, with **18% owning tablets, 18% owning e-book readers, and 27% owning either or both** [1][7]. ![Tablet and e-book ownership is comparable among seniors, while smartphone ownership lags behind](image1)

Regarding internet usage, **59% of seniors report using the internet**, a substantial increase from **35% in 2008** but still trailing the **86% of all U.S. adults** [11]. Broadband adoption among seniors has more than doubled from **19% in 2008** to **47% in recent years**, though this remains lower than the general population [2][6]. ![Internet and broadband adoption have increased among seniors but remain below the general population](image3) ![Internet adoption among seniors has grown significantly since 2000 but lags behind the general adult population](image4)

Social media usage among seniors is also lower, with **27% of older adults using social networking sites** compared to a higher rate among the general population [4][9]. ![Only 27% of seniors use social networking sites, while 41% of seniors do not go online](image2)

Certain subgroups of seniors, such as those aged 80+, those with low incomes, and those without college education, are even less likely to adopt technology or go online [12][8]. ![Device ownership and broadband adoption vary significantly by age, education, and income among seniors](image5) ![Broadband and internet usage decrease with age among seniors](image6)

In summary, while device ownership and online activity are less prevalent among seniors compared to the general adult population, adoption rates have been increasing steadily over time, particularly for internet and broadband usage.

Device ownership and social networking usage among seniors reveal interesting patterns. Seniors are more likely to own tablets or e-book readers (27%) than smartphones (18%), which contrasts with the general population where smartphones are more prevalent. ![Seniors own tablets or e-readers more than smartphones](image3) Despite this, only 27% of seniors use social networking sites (SNS) like Facebook, as shown in the chart. ![27% of seniors use social networking sites](image4)

The relationship between device ownership and social networking usage is nuanced. While 59% of seniors use the internet, only 46% of these online seniors (or 27% of all seniors) use SNS. ![59% of seniors use the internet](image2) Notably, SNS users tend to have more persistent social connections compared to non-users [4]. 

Older adults with higher education and income levels are more likely to own devices and use SNS. For instance, college-educated seniors are three times more likely to own both tablets and e-book readers compared to those without college education [10]. Similarly, SNS adoption is higher among younger, higher-income, and more educated seniors, who also show internet and broadband adoption rates closer to the general population [3].

In summary, while device ownership among seniors is notable, especially for tablets and e-book readers, their social networking usage remains relatively limited but is more pronounced among those with higher socioeconomic status.

Internet and broadband adoption rates among older adults (ages 65+) vary significantly based on age, education, and income, and these rates are generally lower than those of the general adult population. 

### Age:
- **Internet Use:** Among seniors, 59% report using the internet, but this varies greatly by age group. Usage is highest among those aged 65-69 (74%) and drops to 37% for those aged 80 and older [6][9]. ![Internet use among seniors drops significantly after age 75](image6)
- **Broadband Adoption:** Similarly, broadband adoption is 65% for seniors aged 65-69 but falls to 21% for those 80 and older [6][12]. ![Broadband adoption declines sharply with age](image6)

### Education:
- **Internet Use:** Seniors with a college education have significantly higher internet adoption rates (87%) compared to those with a high school diploma or less (40%) [6]. ![Education level strongly influences internet use among seniors](image6)
- **Broadband Adoption:** Broadband adoption follows a similar pattern, with 76% of college-educated seniors having broadband at home, compared to 27% of those with a high school diploma or less [6]. ![Broadband adoption is higher among more educated seniors](image6)

### Income:
- **Internet Use:** Higher-income seniors (household income ≥$75,000) have an internet adoption rate of 90%, while those with incomes below $30,000 have a rate of 39% [6]. ![Higher income correlates with greater internet use among seniors](image6)
- **Broadband Adoption:** Broadband adoption is 82% for seniors with incomes ≥$75,000 but only 25% for those with incomes below $30,000 [6]. ![Income level greatly affects broadband adoption among seniors](image6)

### Comparison with General Population:
- Seniors’ internet adoption (59%) and broadband adoption (47%) lag behind the general adult population, where 86% use the internet [1][12]. ![Seniors' internet and broadband adoption rates are lower than the general population](image5)

In summary, internet and broadband adoption rates among older adults are highest among younger, more educated, and higher-income seniors but remain substantially below the national average.

Internet, broadband, cell phone, and smartphone adoption rates among seniors vary significantly based on income and education levels.  

**Internet and Broadband Adoption**:  
- **Education**: College graduates have the highest adoption rates, with 87% using the internet and 76% having broadband at home. In contrast, only 40% of seniors who have not attended college go online, and just 27% have broadband [1][6][9].  
- **Income**: Seniors with annual household incomes of $75,000 or more have the highest rates, with 90% using the internet and 82% having broadband. For those earning less than $30,000 annually, only 39% go online and 25% have broadband [8][9].  
![Seniors with higher education and income levels have significantly higher internet and broadband adoption rates](image3)  

**Cell Phone and Smartphone Adoption**:  
- **Education**: College graduates are more likely to own cell phones (87%) and smartphones (35%), while seniors with high school education or less have lower rates (70% for cell phones and 10% for smartphones) [7][12].  
- **Income**: Higher-income seniors ($75,000+) show the highest cell phone (92%) and smartphone (42%) adoption rates. In contrast, those earning less than $30,000 have much lower rates (67% and 8%, respectively) [8][12].  
![Cell phone and smartphone adoption rates are higher among seniors with higher education and income levels](image8)  

In summary, seniors with higher education and income levels consistently exhibit higher adoption rates for internet, broadband, cell phones, and smartphones compared to their lower-income and less-educated counterparts.

Internet and smartphone adoption rates among older adults (65+) vary significantly by income and education levels. 

Affluent and well-educated seniors adopt the internet and broadband at substantially higher rates than those with lower levels of income and education. For example, in the 65+ age group, **90% of those with a household income of $75,000+ go online**, compared to **39% of those with an income of less than $30,000**. Similarly, **87% of college graduates go online**, while only **40% of those with a high school diploma or less do so** [1]. ![Total for all 65+](image1)

Smartphone ownership also reflects this disparity. **42% of seniors with an income of $75,000+ own smartphones**, compared to just **8% of those with an income of less than $30,000**. Education plays a similar role: **35% of college graduates own smartphones**, while only **10% of those with a high school diploma or less do** [4]. ![Cell phone Smartphone](image4)

Comparatively, the overall smartphone adoption rate among the general population is **55%**, while just **18% of seniors own smartphones**. However, cell phone ownership among seniors is more widespread, with **77% of older adults owning a cell phone**, though this still trails the national average of **91%** [7]. ![Smartphone Tablet or e-reader](image5)

In summary, income and education are significant determinants of internet and smartphone adoption among older adults, with affluent and well-educated seniors adopting these technologies at much higher rates than their less affluent and less educated peers. These rates, however, remain lower than the general population. ![% of internet users in each age group who go online](image8)

Internet usage and smartphone ownership among seniors vary significantly based on their educational backgrounds. Seniors with higher levels of education are more likely to use the internet and own smartphones compared to those with less education.

![Internet and Broadband Usage by Education](image1)  
For internet usage, **87%** of seniors who are college graduates go online, compared to **69%** of those with some college education, and only **40%** of high school graduates or less [1][5]. Broadband adoption follows a similar trend, with **76%** of college graduates having broadband at home, **57%** of those with some college, and **27%%
** of high school graduates or less [1][5].  

![Smartphone Ownership by Education](image8)  
Smartphone ownership is also higher among more educated seniors. **35%** of college graduates own smartphones, compared to **19%** of those with some college, and **10%** of high school graduates or less [11][12]. These disparities highlight the impact of education on technology adoption among older adults.  

In summary, seniors with higher educational attainment are significantly more likely to use the internet, have broadband at home, and own smartphones than those with lower levels of education.
