Internet and broadband adoption among seniors vary significantly based on education and income levels, as do cell phone and smartphone ownership. Here’s how they compare:

**Education Level:**
- **College Graduates:**  
  - **Internet and Broadband:** 87% of college-educated seniors go online, and 76% have broadband at home [2].  
  - **Cell Phones and Smartphones:** 87% own cell phones, and 35% own smartphones [image5].  
  ![Seniors with a college degree have the highest rates of internet and broadband adoption.](image2)

- **High School Graduates or Less:**  
  - **Internet and Broadband:** Only 40% go online, and 27% have broadband at home [12].  
  - **Cell Phones and Smartphones:** 70% own cell phones, and just 10% own smartphones [image5].  
  ![Seniors with high school education or less have significantly lower adoption rates for technology.](image5)

**Income Level:**

  - **Internet and Broadband:** 90% go online, and 82% have broadband at home [12].  
  - **Cell Phones and Smartphones:** 92% own cell phones, and 42% own smartphones [image5].  
  ![Higher-income seniors show the highest rates of internet, broadband, and smartphone adoption.](image5)

- **Household Income < $30,000:**  
  - **Internet and Broadband:** Only 39% go online, and 25% have broadband at home [12].  
  - **Cell Phones and Smartphones:** 67% own cell phones, and just 8% own smartphones [image5].

In summary, both education and income strongly influence internet and broadband adoption, as well as cell phone and smartphone ownership among seniors, with college graduates and higher-income individuals consistently showing the highest rates.

Broadband adoption at home among seniors varies significantly based on their educational attainment and household income. Seniors with higher levels of education are far more likely to have broadband at home compared to those with less education. For instance, 76% of seniors with a college degree are broadband adopters, while only 27% of those who have not attended college have broadband at home [9].  

Household income also plays a critical role in broadband adoption. Among seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more, 82% have broadband at home, compared to just 25% of those earning less than $30,000 annually [9]. This trend is further illustrated in `![Broadband adoption by education and income levels](image5)`, which shows a clear correlation between higher education, higher income, and increased broadband adoption among seniors.  

In summary, both higher educational attainment and higher household income are strongly associated with greater broadband adoption among seniors.

Education level significantly influences the adoption of tablets and e-book readers among seniors. Seniors who have graduated from college are around three times as likely to own both an e-book reader and a tablet compared to those who have not attended college. Additionally, seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more are about four times as likely to own each device than those with a household income of less than $30,000 [12].

![Seniors with higher education and income are more likely to own tablets and e-book readers.](image4)

When comparing adoption trends across different age groups, younger seniors (ages 65-69) are more likely to adopt these devices compared to those aged 80 and older. For instance, 23% of seniors aged 65-69 own an e-book reader, while only 10% of those aged 80+ do. Similarly, 23% of seniors aged 65-69 own a tablet, compared to 10% of those aged 80+ [8]. This trend aligns with the broader adoption of technology, where younger adults generally adopt new technologies at higher rates than older adults [7].

![Adoption of tablets and e-book readers declines with age among seniors.](image8)

Overall, while education and income play a significant role in the adoption of tablets and e-book readers among seniors, age also remains a critical factor, with younger seniors more likely to adopt these technologies than their older counterparts.

Educational attainment significantly influences how workers perceive workforce technologies. Workers with higher levels of education, particularly college graduates, tend to have more positive views of these technologies. For example, 90% of college graduates feel that office productivity tools like word processing or spreadsheet software have had a positive impact on their careers, compared to only 45% of those with a high school diploma or less [12]. Similarly, college graduates are more likely to say that technology has made their work more interesting (64% vs. 38%) and increased their opportunities for career advancement (53% vs. 32%) compared to workers with lower educational attainment [2].

![College graduates are more likely to view workforce technologies positively](image3)

These disparities are also evident when examining specific technologies. For instance, there is a 27-percentage point difference in the perception of email or social media’s positive impact between college graduates (72%) and those with a high school diploma or less (45%) [12]. Additionally, 24% of workers with a high school diploma or less report that none of the six measured technologies have positively impacted their jobs, whereas only 2% of college graduates share this sentiment [12].

Regarding driverless car technology, public expectations are high. Approximately two-thirds of Americans anticipate that most vehicles on the road will be driverless within the next 50 years, with 9% predicting this will happen within the next decade [8]. ![Public expectations for driverless car technology are widespread](image1)

In summary, educational attainment shapes workers’ perceptions of workforce technologies, with higher education correlating with more positive views. Meanwhile, the public widely expects driverless car technology to become prevalent in the coming decades.

Workers with higher levels of education tend to perceive the impact of workforce technologies more positively than those with lower educational attainment. For example, 90% of college graduates view office productivity tools like word processing or spreadsheet software as having a positive impact on their careers, compared to just 45% of workers with high school diplomas or less [9]. Similarly, there are significant gaps in positive perceptions for technologies like email or social media (a 27-point difference), smartphones (22 points), and scheduling software (21 points) between these groups [9]. !["Positive impact of workforce technologies by education level"](image5)

Overall, 24% of workers with high school diplomas or less say none of the six measured technologies has positively impacted their careers, while only 2% of college graduates share this view [9]. This suggests that educational attainment plays a significant role in shaping workers' experiences with technology in the workplace. !["Educational differences in technology perceptions"](image5)

Regarding driverless cars, public expectations are optimistic, with 94% of Americans aware of their development. Two-thirds anticipate that most vehicles on the road will be driverless within the next 50 years, and 9% believe this will happen in the next decade [1]. !["Public expectations for driverless car adoption"](image4)

In summary, higher education levels correlate with more positive views of workforce technologies, and a majority of Americans expect driverless cars to become mainstream within the next half-century.

The perceptions of automation and workforce technology impacts vary significantly between future expectations for driverless vehicles and the current experiences of U.S. workers with existing technologies. While Americans anticipate significant future advancements in automation, their current experiences with workforce technologies reveal a more mixed and nuanced outlook.

Many Americans are highly aware of driverless vehicle development, with $94\%$ expressing some familiarity and $9\%$ predicting widespread adoption within the next 10 years. Fully two-thirds expect most vehicles to be driverless within the next half-century, reflecting optimism about this specific automation technology [1]. This contrasts with the broader, more varied experiences workers report with current technologies. Workers express mixed views on how today’s technologies have impacted their jobs and careers, with some seeing positive effects and others viewing them as neutral or even damaging [4][5].

Current technologies like word processing software, smartphones, and email are viewed positively by the majority of workers, with $70\%$, $67\%$, and $60\%$ respectively reporting positive impacts on their careers [8]. However, the benefits of these tools are not evenly distributed. Workers with higher levels of educational attainment are more likely to view technology positively, while those with less education often see it as less beneficial or even harmful [6]. 

![Workers with higher education are more likely to view technology positively](image7) 

For instance, industrial robots have positively impacted $27\%$ of workers, but this varies widely by education level, with college graduates reporting higher positive impacts than those with less education [2][image2]. Similarly, while $53\%$ of workers feel technology has made their work more interesting, $34\%$ report no major impact, and $12\%$ say it has made their work less interesting [12][image3].

![More workers find technology makes their work interesting than those who don't](image3)

Looking ahead, there is concern about the potential for automation to disrupt traditional job roles, particularly in manufacturing, transportation, and retail [9]. Many Americans anticipate significant societal impacts from automation, including the replacement of entire job categories with robots, but their attitudes often reflect worry rather than optimism [10]. This contrasts with the more immediate, tangible experiences workers have with current technologies, which, while mixed, are often viewed as enhancing productivity and career opportunities [8][12].

In summary, while there is optimism about the future of automation, particularly in areas like driverless vehicles, current experiences with workforce technologies reveal a more complex reality, with benefits often skewed toward those with higher education and mixed sentiments among the broader workforce.

Workers with higher levels of education, particularly those with at least a four-year college degree, tend to have more positive perceptions of workplace technologies compared to those with only a high school diploma or less. This difference is most evident in how technology impacts job interest and career opportunities. 

For instance, 64% of college graduates say technology has made their work more interesting, while only 38% of workers with high school diplomas or less share this view![College graduates are more likely to find technology makes their work more interesting.](image1). Similarly, 53% of college graduates believe technology has increased their career advancement opportunities, compared to just 32% of those with high school diplomas or less![College graduates see greater career advancement opportunities due to technology.](image1).

In contrast, a significant portion of non-college-educated workers feel that technology has had little to no impact on their careers. For example, 44% of workers with high school diplomas or less say word processing or spreadsheet software has not affected their professional lives, and 35% say the same about email or social media [7]. Additionally, nearly one-quarter (24%) of these workers report that none of the six technologies measured in the survey has positively impacted their jobs or careers, compared to just 2% of college graduates [1].

Overall, workers with higher education levels are more likely to view technology as a positive force that enhances their work experience and career prospects, while those with less formal education often perceive it as having little to no impact.![Workers with higher education express more positive views on technology's impact.](image4)![Educational disparities in technology's impact on careers are pronounced.](image8).

Workers with higher levels of education, particularly those with at least a four-year college degree, are significantly more likely to view workplace technologies as having a positive impact on their careers, especially in making their work more interesting and increasing opportunities for advancement. For instance, 64% of college graduates say technology has made their work more interesting, compared to just 38% of workers with a high school diploma or less. Similarly, 53% of college graduates feel technology has increased their career opportunities, while only 32% of those with lower educational attainment share this view [9]. ![College graduates are more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting and increased opportunities for advancement](image1)  

These disparities are consistent across various technologies. College graduates are notably more positive about the impact of tools like word processing or spreadsheet software, with 90% reporting a positive impact, compared to 45% of workers with high school diplomas or less. Similar gaps exist for technologies like email, social media, and smartphones [11]. ![Workers with college degrees are more positive about the impact of specific technologies on their jobs](image6)  

In contrast, a significant portion of non-college-educated workers report that technology has had no meaningful impact on their careers. For example, 44% of workers with high school diplomas or less say word processing or spreadsheet software has not impacted their professional lives, and 35% say the same about email or social media [3]. ![Non-college-educated workers often report that technology has had no impact on their careers](image3)  

Overall, educational attainment strongly influences how workers perceive the role of technology in their work, with higher education correlating with more positive views on its impact. ![Workers with higher education are more likely to see technology as enhancing their work experiences](image7)

Workers with higher levels of education, particularly those with at least a four-year college degree, have significantly more positive perceptions of technology’s impact on their job opportunities and work interest compared to those with high school diplomas or less. For instance, **64% of college graduates** say technology has made their work more interesting, while only **38% of workers with high school diplomas or less** share this view. Similarly, **53% of college graduates** believe technology has increased their opportunities for career advancement, compared to just **32% of those with lower educational attainment** [1][10].  

![Educational differences in perceptions of technology's impact on work interest and opportunities](image1)  

Workers with some college education but no four-year degree occupy a middle ground, expressing more positive views than those with only a high school diploma but less optimism than college graduates [12]. This trend is consistent across various technologies, such as office productivity tools, smartphones, and email or social media, where college graduates report more favorable impacts [1][9].  

![Workers' perceptions of technology's impact on job demands](image4)  

Furthermore, workers with high school diplomas or less are more likely to report that technology has had no impact on their careers, with **44%** stating that word processing or spreadsheet software hasn’t affected them professionally [2]. This contrasts sharply with college graduates, who are far less likely to feel neutral or negative about technology’s role in their work.  

In summary, educational attainment strongly influences workers’ perceptions of technology’s effects on their careers, with higher education correlating with more positive views on job opportunities and work interest.

Americans' levels of awareness about automation significantly influence their perspectives on machines taking over human jobs, with varying degrees of enthusiasm and worry. Those who have heard a lot about this concept are more likely to find it realistic (47% very/somewhat realistic) and express enthusiasm (47%) compared to those with lower awareness (30% for "heard a little" and 18% for "heard nothing") [10]. However, even high-awareness individuals remain as worried (76%) as those with less knowledge (72% for "heard a little" and 69% for "heard nothing") [5][11].

![Most high-awareness Americans find automation realistic and express enthusiasm but remain worried](image1)

When it comes to expected outcomes, Americans generally foresee more negative than positive consequences. Approximately 76% anticipate increased economic inequality [4], and 75% believe the economy is unlikely to create many new, well-paying jobs for humans [12]. Smaller shares expect positive outcomes, such as improved economic efficiency (57%) or the ability to focus on more meaningful aspects of life [12].

![Americans expect increased inequality and fewer new jobs from automation](image6)

Overall, while awareness leads to a more nuanced understanding and some enthusiasm, it does not diminish concerns about the potential negative impacts of automation on jobs and society.

Public opinion on workforce automation policies varies significantly between Democrats and Republicans, particularly on issues like universal basic income and national service programs. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are far more supportive of a universal income (77% vs. 38%) and a national service program (66% vs. 46%) in the event of widespread job losses due to automation [1][12]. However, both parties are more aligned on limiting machines to performing dangerous or unhealthy jobs, with strong bipartisan support (86% of Democrats and 81% of Republicans favoring this policy) [6][12]. ![Bipartisan support for limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs](image6)

Additionally, while 65% of Democrats believe the government has an obligation to care for displaced workers, even if it means raising taxes, 68% of Republicans feel individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being despite automation [5]. ![Partisan differences on government obligation vs. individual responsibility](image8)

Overall, the public strongly supports limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs (85% in favor), with nearly half (47%) strongly favoring this policy [3]. ![Strong public support for limiting machines to dangerous jobs](image1)

Political affiliations and education levels significantly shape opinions on government obligations and automation limits related to job displacement. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are more supportive of government intervention, with 65% favoring the idea that the government should take care of displaced workers, even if it means higher taxes [1][4]. In contrast, 68% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents believe individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being, even in the face of widespread automation [4]. ![Democrats lean toward government responsibility, while Republicans favor individual accountability](image8)

Educational attainment also influences views on limiting automation. Among those with high school diplomas or less, 70% support limiting the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines, compared to only 41% of those with four-year college degrees [6]. ![Lower education levels are more supportive of automation limits](image8) This suggests that individuals with less formal education are more concerned about job displacement and advocate for stricter regulations on automation.

Partisan differences are also evident in support for specific policies, such as a guaranteed income or national service program. For example, 77% of Democrats favor a universal basic income, compared to just 38% of Republicans [11]. Similarly, 66% of Democrats support a national service program for displaced workers, while only 46% of Republicans do [11]. ![Democrats show higher support for income and service programs](image6)

In summary, political affiliation and education level are key factors in shaping public opinion on government obligations and automation limits. Democrats and those with lower education levels are more likely to support government intervention and stricter automation regulations, while Republicans and those with higher education levels tend to prioritize individual responsibility and fewer restrictions on businesses.

Political affiliation significantly influences American views on policies related to workforce automation and job displacement. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are more supportive of government intervention, such as providing a universal basic income and creating a national service program for displaced workers. For instance, 77% of Democrats favor a universal basic income, compared to only 38% of Republicans [4][7]. Similarly, 66% of Democrats support a national service program, while only 46% of Republicans do [4]. ![Democrats and Republicans differ on support for government interventions like universal basic income and national service programs](image6)

However, there is more agreement across party lines on limiting machines to dangerous or dirty jobs, with 86% of Democrats and 83% of Republicans supporting this idea [9]. Additionally, both groups show comparable support for limiting the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines, with 60% of Democrats and 54% of Republicans in favor [11]. ![Both Democrats and Republicans largely support limiting machines to dangerous or dirty jobs](image6)

Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely to believe individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being even if jobs are automated, with 68% holding this view compared to 30% of Democrats who think the government should take care of displaced workers [3]. ![Republicans emphasize individual responsibility for financial well-being in the face of automation](image1)

In summary, while Democrats favor government-led solutions like income guarantees and job programs, Republicans lean toward individual responsibility, though both groups agree on certain limitations for automation.

Attitudes towards workforce automation and the perceived impact of technology vary significantly across different age groups and education levels. Younger adults, particularly those aged 18 to 24, are among the most likely to have been personally impacted by workforce automation, with 6% of U.S. adults reporting job loss or reduced pay/hours due to automation, and this group is notably affected [3]. ![Younger adults are more likely to be impacted by automation](image4)

When it comes to education, workers with higher levels of education, such as college graduates, generally view technology more positively. For instance, 64% of college graduates say technology has made their work more interesting, compared to just 38% of those with a high school diploma or less. Similarly, 53% of college graduates feel technology has increased their career advancement opportunities, versus 32% of those with lower education levels [2][5]. ![College graduates have more positive views on technology](image5)

In contrast, workers with lower educational attainment are more likely to view technology as a negative force. For example, 46% of workers impacted by automation believe technology has decreased their career opportunities, and 34% feel it has made their work less interesting, compared to only 11% of other workers who share these views [1]. Additionally, workers without college education are less likely to express positive attitudes towards workforce technologies, with only 38% indicating technology has made their jobs more interesting and 32% believing it has increased their career advancement opportunities [12]. ![Workers with lower education express less positive attitudes](image10)

In summary, younger adults and those with lower education levels are more likely to experience negative impacts from automation, while college graduates tend to view technology more positively, seeing it as an enhancer of their work experience and career prospects.

Workforce automation and technology are perceived differently across demographics and education levels, with educational attainment being a key factor in shaping these views. Workers with higher levels of education, particularly college graduates, are more likely to view technology positively, noting that it has made their work more interesting and increased their opportunities for career advancement. For instance, 64% of college graduates say technology has made their work more interesting, compared to just 38% of those with a high school diploma or less [1][9]. ![College graduates are more likely to report technology positively impacts their career](image1)

Similarly, college graduates are more likely to say technology has increased their career advancement opportunities (53% vs. 32% for those with less education) [9][12]. ![Educational differences in perceptions of technology’s impact](image1) Workers without a college education are significantly less likely to express positive attitudes toward workforce technologies, often viewing them as neutral or even damaging to their career prospects [11].

In terms of job demands, college graduates are more likely to say technology has made their work both more demanding (45% vs. 36%) and less demanding (31% vs. 20%) compared to those with less education [9]. ![Mixed views on how technology affects job demands](image2)

Additionally, specific technologies such as word processing software, smartphones, and email are generally viewed positively by most workers, with 70%, 67%, and 60% respectively reporting positive impacts on their careers [7]. However, technologies like industrial robots and customer self-service tools are seen more negatively, with only 25% and 27% of workers reporting positive impacts [3][6]. ![Workers’ perceptions of specific technologies](image6)

Demographically, younger workers and certain occupational groups, such as fast food workers and insurance claims processors, are more likely to report being impacted by automation technologies [4][7]. ![Demographic breakdown of technology’s impact](image4)

Overall, perceptions of workforce automation and technology vary widely, with education level being a significant determinant of whether workers view these changes as beneficial or detrimental.

Workers’ perceptions of how technology impacts their job’s interest and career advancement opportunities vary significantly based on their education levels and the specific technologies they use. 

Workers with higher levels of education, particularly those with college degrees or more, are substantially more likely to view technology as a positive force. For example, **64% of college graduates** say technology has made their work more interesting, compared to just **38% of workers with high school diplomas or less**. Similarly, **53% of college graduates** believe technology has increased their career advancement opportunities, while only **32% of those with high school diplomas or less** share this view [5]. ![Higher education correlates with positive perceptions of technology’s impact on work](image5)

The types of technologies also play a role in shaping these perceptions. Technologies like **word processing or spreadsheet software**, **smartphones**, and **email or social media** are viewed positively by a majority of workers, with **70%**, **67%**, and **60%** respectively reporting a positive impact on their careers [10]. ![Workers perceive common workplace technologies positively](image6) However, technologies such as **industrial robots** and **customer self-service tools** are less favorably viewed, with only **20%** and **24%** of workers reporting a positive impact, respectively [6].

Workers in the middle educational tier—those with some college but no four-year degree—tend to have attitudes that fall between these two extremes. They are more positive than those with no college experience but less positive than those with advanced degrees [9]. ![Educational tier influences perception of technology’s impact](image5)

In summary, education levels and specific technologies significantly influence workers' perceptions of job interest and advancement opportunities, with higher education and widely-used workplace tools fostering more positive views.

Younger adults are more likely to experience amusement on social media compared to anger, with 54% of users aged 18-29 frequently encountering content that makes them feel amused, while 27% frequently see content that makes them feel angry [6]. In contrast, older adults (ages 65 and older) experience these emotions at more comparable frequencies, with 30% frequently amused and 24% frequently angry [6]. ![Younger adults are more amused by social media content](image8)

Across all age groups, amusement is the most frequently experienced emotion, with 44% of users frequently feeling amused by the content they see [5]. Anger follows, with 25% of users frequently encountering anger-inducing content [2]. Other emotions, such as loneliness, show more variation by age, with younger adults (18-29) more likely to feel lonely (15%) compared to older adults (50 and older, 4%) [7]. ![Amusement is the most frequent emotion experienced on social media](image7)

In summary, while amusement is the dominant emotion across all age groups, younger adults are more likely to feel amused and lonely, whereas older adults experience amusement and anger at more similar rates.

Younger social media users, particularly those aged 18-29, are more likely to feel amused by content they encounter compared to older age groups, with 54% reporting frequent amusement, while only 30% of those aged 65 and older feel the same. However, younger users are also more likely to feel lonely, with 15% reporting this emotion frequently, compared to just 4% of those aged 50 and older. Feelings of anger are more evenly distributed across age groups, with 27% of 18-29-year-olds and 24% of those 65+ frequently encountering anger-inducing content [1][4][5][6].

![Bar graph showing the percentage of social media users in different age groups who frequently feel amused, angry, or lonely](image5).

In terms of content exposure, users across all age groups frequently encounter overly dramatic or exaggerated posts (58%) and accusations or arguments made without all the facts (59%). Younger adults are twice as likely to see amusing content compared to anger-inducing content, while older adults experience these types of content at a more comparable frequency [1][3][12].

![Pie chart showing the percentage of social media users who see specific types of content frequently](image1).

Overall, social media elicits a mix of emotions and exposes users to a variety of content types, with age playing a significant role in how these experiences are perceived and felt.

Different age groups and genders perceive emotional responses and behaviors on social media in varied ways, and they frequently encounter certain types of content that shape these perceptions.

Younger adults, aged 18 to 29, are more likely to feel lonely due to social media content, with 15% reporting this feeling, compared to just 4% of those aged 50 and older. Conversely, older adults are less frequently amused by social media content, with only 30% of those aged 65 and older reporting amusement, similar to the 24% who feel angry.[7] ![Younger adults feel more lonely, while older adults are less amused](image3)

Amusement is the most common emotion across all age groups, with 88% of users reporting they see content that makes them feel amused, and 44% frequently experiencing this emotion.[6] ![Amusement is the most common emotion across all age groups](image7)

In terms of gender, men are slightly more likely than women to encounter mean or bullying behavior online, with 29% of men reporting this compared to 19% of women. Women, on the other hand, are slightly more likely to see kind and supportive behavior. However, the majority of both genders (52% of men and 56% of women) see an equal mix of supportive and bullying behavior.[12] ![Men encounter more bullying, while women see more kindness](image6)

The types of content frequently encountered on social media include overly dramatic or exaggerated posts (58%) and people making accusations or starting arguments without having all the facts (59%).[10] ![Frequent content includes drama and arguments](image5)

Additionally, users are exposed to a mix of positive and negative behaviors, with 54% seeing an equal mix of kind or supportive and mean or bullying behaviors. Around 21% more often see kind behavior, while 24% more often see mean behavior.[4] ![Users see a mix of positive and negative behaviors](image6)

In conclusion, younger adults are more likely to feel lonely, while older adults are less amused. Men encounter more bullying behavior, and women see more kindness. Commonly encountered content includes drama, arguments, and a mix of positive and negative behaviors.

Younger social media users, particularly those aged 18-29, report feeling more amused (54%) but also more lonely (25%) and depressed (19%) compared to older age groups [8]. In contrast, older age groups, such as those 65+, experience these emotions less frequently, with only 9% feeling inspired and 15% connected [8]. Anger is more evenly distributed across age groups, with 27% of 18-29-year-olds and 23% of those 65+ reporting frequent feelings of anger [8].

![Younger users feel more amused, lonely, and depressed compared to older age groups](image8)

Regarding behaviors, men are slightly more likely than women to encounter mean or bullying content on social media (29% vs. 19%), while women are more likely to see kind or supportive behavior [9]. However, the majority of both genders (52% of men and 56% of women) report seeing an equal mix of supportive and bullying behavior [9].

![Men are more likely to see mean or bullying content, while women see more kind behavior](image7)

The most common types of posts encountered across all age groups are those that are overly dramatic or exaggerated (58%) and posts where people start arguments without all the facts (59%) [8]. Additionally, many users frequently encounter posts that appear to be about one thing but turn out to be about something else, as well as posts that teach something useful [3].

![Overly dramatic posts and argumentative content are the most frequently encountered types of posts](image3)

In summary, younger users experience more intense emotions like amusement, loneliness, and depression, while men are more likely to encounter negative behaviors like bullying. Dramatic and argumentative posts are the most common across all age groups.

Men and women's perceptions of online behaviors on social media reveal notable differences. According to previous surveys, men are slightly more likely than women to encounter harassing or abusive behavior online. Specifically, **29% of men** report seeing mean or bullying content more often compared to **19% of women** [2]. Conversely, women are slightly more likely to say they see kind or supportive behavior more frequently [2]. However, the majority of both genders—**52% of men and 56% of women**—report seeing an equal mix of supportive and bullying behavior [2]. 

![Men are more likely than women to see bullying or deceptive behavior on social media](image1)

When it comes to deception and correcting misinformation, men are around twice as likely as women to say they more often see people being deceptive (**24% of men vs. 13% of women**) [12]. Despite this, majorities of both men (**58%**) and women (**67%**) see an equal mix of deceptiveness and attempts to correct misinformation [12]. 

![Men are more likely than women to see deceptive behavior, but both genders see an equal mix of deceptiveness and correction attempts](image4)

These perceptions are relevant to the frequency of encountering dramatic or exaggerated posts. **58%** of users say they frequently see overly dramatic or exaggerated posts, and **59%** frequently see people making accusations or starting arguments without all the facts [1]. This aligns with the broader exposure to a mix of behaviors, where **54%** of users see an equal mix of kindness and meanness, and **63%** see an equal mix of deceptiveness and efforts to correct misinformation [9]. 

![Users frequently see dramatic or exaggerated posts and arguments without facts](image2)

In summary, men are more likely than women to perceive bullying and deception on social media, though both genders primarily encounter a balance of positive and negative behaviors. This occurs alongside the frequent exposure to dramatic or exaggerated content that dominates many social media interactions.

Men and women perceive social media content and behavior differently, which has implications for how platforms tailor their recommendations and advertisements. Men are more likely than women to report seeing deceptive behavior (24% vs. 13%) and bullying or mean content (29% vs. 19%) [1][3]. On the other hand, women are slightly more likely to say they more often see kind or supportive behavior [3]. Despite these differences, majorities of both genders see an equal mix of positive and negative behaviors, such as kind vs. bullying (52% of men and 56% of women) and deceptive vs. corrective behavior (58% of men and 67% of women) [1][3]. ![Equal mix of kind and bullying behavior](image4)

These differing perceptions suggest that social media platforms should consider these nuances when delivering targeted content. For example, platforms could avoid showing overly dramatic or accusatory posts more frequently to men, who are more likely to perceive them negatively. ![Posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated](image2) For women, who tend to notice supportive behavior more often, platforms might emphasize positive and educational content to enhance their experience. ![Posts that teach something useful](image2)

Additionally, men and women’s divergent experiences with harassment and abusive behavior online [3] could inform how platforms manage moderation and recommendations. Tailoring ads and recommendations based on these insights could improve user satisfaction and engagement. For instance, platforms could prioritize local events or community-building content, which is generally acceptable across age groups [2]. ![Recommend events in their area](image8) However, caution should be exercised with political ads, as they are less acceptable across the board [2][9]. ![Show them messages from political campaigns](image8)

In summary, social media platforms can enhance user experience by tailoring content and advertisements to align with the differing perceptions and preferences of men and women, focusing on reducing negative experiences and amplifying positive interactions.

Different age groups exhibit varying levels of acceptance when it comes to social media platforms using their personal data, with younger users generally being more comfortable than older users. For example, about two-thirds of social media users younger than 50 find it acceptable for platforms to use their data to recommend people they might want to know, while fewer than half of users aged 65 and older share this view [1]. Similarly, younger users are more accepting of their data being used to show advertisements for products or services, with 60% of those aged 18-49 finding it acceptable, compared to 63% of users aged 65 and older who find it unacceptable [4].

![Younger users are more accepting of data use for recommendations](image3)

When it comes to recommending events in their area, majorities across all age groups find this use of their data acceptable, with 78% of users aged 18-29 and 67% of those aged 65+ agreeing [3]. However, users are significantly less comfortable with their data being used for political messaging, with 31% of all users finding it "not at all acceptable" [2].

![Users are less comfortable with data use for political messaging](image2)

Overall comfort with data usage on social media is highly context-dependent, with users more accepting of practices that directly benefit them, such as event recommendations, and less accepting of practices like political messaging or targeted advertising [5], [10]. This aligns with broader trends showing that users’ comfort levels depend on how their data is used, with older users being particularly wary of certain practices [9].

Perceptions of fairness and effectiveness vary significantly across different automated decision-making systems, reflecting nuanced public attitudes toward their use. For instance, the personal finance score algorithm is viewed as effective by 54% of Americans in identifying good customers, but only 32% consider it fair to consumers, creating the largest effectiveness-fairness gap (+22 percentage points) among the systems evaluated [8][11]. ![Effective and fair gap in personal finance score](image8)

Similarly, the automated criminal risk score is seen as effective by 49% in identifying deserving parole candidates, with 50% deeming it fair to those being analyzed. This indicates a narrower gap (+1 percentage point) compared to the personal finance score [8]. ![Fairness and effectiveness of criminal risk score](image8)  

Other systems, such as automated resume screening and video job interview analysis, also show differences. Resume screening is viewed as effective by 47% and fair by 43%, while video interview analysis is considered effective by 39% and fair by 33% [8]. ![Fairness and effectiveness of resume screening and video interview analysis](image8)  

These disparities suggest that public trust in automated systems is highly contextual and influenced by concerns about fairness, privacy, and the removal of the human element. For example, skepticism about personal finance scores stems from privacy violations and perceived unfairness, while concerns about criminal risk scores emphasize the need for human judgment and individual circumstances [6][7]. ![Concerns about algorithmic decision-making](image6) ![Public concerns about criminal risk scores](image7)  

Demographic differences further highlight varying trust levels. Blacks and Hispanics are more likely than whites to view personal finance scores as fair (45% and 47% vs. 25%), while 61% of Blacks find parole scoring unfair, compared to 49% of whites and 38% of Hispanics [10]. ![Demographic differences in fairness perceptions](image3)  

In summary, perceptions of fairness and effectiveness differ widely across automated systems, with public trust shaped by concerns about bias, privacy, and the loss of human nuance. These differences underscore the need for greater transparency and accountability in the design and implementation of such technologies.

Partisans are deeply divided on the ethical standards of top Trump administration officials, with 76% of Republicans and Republican leaners rating them as excellent or good, while 90% of Democrats and Democratic leaners describe them as not good or poor [1]. This stark contrast is further emphasized by the fact that views of Trump administration officials are significantly lower compared to those of officials in the previous five administrations [10]. ![Ethical standards of top Trump administration officials remain at record lows compared to previous administrations](image1).

When it comes to trustworthiness, a majority of the public (58%) trusts what Trump says less than they trusted previous presidents, while just 26% trust him more [3]. This distrust is particularly pronounced among Democrats, with 94% saying they trust Trump less than previous presidents, compared to 58% of Republicans who trust him more [7][11]. ![Distrust in Trump’s statements is higher compared to previous presidents](image4).

The polarization in perceptions is not limited to ethical standards and trustworthiness but extends to economic policies as well. While 79% of Republicans believe Trump’s economic policies have improved conditions, nearly half of Democrats (46%) view them negatively [9]. ![Partisan views of Trump’s economic policies have become more polarized](image2). Overall, the data reveals a deeply partisan divide in how Trump’s ethical standards, trustworthiness, and economic policies are perceived compared to previous administrations.

Public perceptions of Trump’s responsibilities and trustworthiness differ significantly from those of previous presidents, and these views are heavily influenced by partisan divides. A majority of the public (58%) says they trust what Trump says less than they trusted previous presidents, with only 26% trusting him more. This distrust has grown since April 2017, when 51% said they trusted him less [6][12]. Among Democrats and Democratic leaners, distrust is even more pronounced, with 94% saying they trust Trump less than previous presidents [8]. Republicans, however, show more confidence, with 58% saying they trust Trump more than previous presidents [11].

![Trust in Trump compared to previous presidents varies widely by party](image6)  
The image illustrates the stark contrast in trust levels, with Democrats overwhelmingly distrusting Trump and Republicans generally trusting him more.

Views on Trump’s responsibilities also reflect partisan polarization. A majority (64%) believes Trump has a responsibility to release his tax returns, including 91% of Democrats but only 32% of Republicans [10]. Ethical standards of Trump’s administration are similarly divisive, with 76% of Republicans rating them as excellent or good, while 90% of Democrats see them as not good or poor [9].

![Partisan views on the ethical standards of Trump administration officials](image9)  
The image highlights the deep partisan divide in perceptions of ethical standards, with Republicans largely positive and Democrats overwhelmingly negative.

When it comes to evaluating Trump’s success, partisanship drives significant differences. In January 2019, 80% of Democrats viewed Trump as unsuccessful, compared to only 6% of Republicans. This partisan gap is wider than that seen for previous presidents like Obama, Bush, and Clinton at comparable points in their presidencies [1][image1][image2].

![Public perceptions of Trump’s success compared to previous presidents](image1)  
The image shows the polarized views of Trump’s success, with Democrats largely viewing him as unsuccessful and Republicans more likely to see him as successful or needing more time to judge.

In summary, public perceptions of Trump’s trustworthiness and responsibilities are more negative compared to previous presidents, and these views are deeply divided along partisan lines, with Republicans generally supportive and Democrats highly critical.

Perceptions of Trump's presidency vary significantly along partisan lines, particularly in terms of trust, ethical standards, economic impact, and long-term success. Republicans and Democrats hold starkly contrasting views, and these perceptions often differ from those of previous presidents.

When it comes to ethical standards, **90% of Democrats and Democratic leaners** believe the ethical standards of top Trump administration officials are "not good" or "poor," with 67% labeling them as "poor." In contrast, **76% of Republicans and Republican leaners** view these standards as "excellent" or "good," though only 16% consider them "excellent" [3]. ![Ethical standards of top Trump administration officials are viewed negatively by Democrats and positively by Republicans](image10).

On economic impact, partisan polarization has deepened since 2017. **79% of Republicans and Republican leaners** believe Trump’s economic policies have improved conditions, up from 63% in October 2017. Conversely, **46% of Democrats and Democratic leaners** now say his policies have made conditions worse [12]. ![Partisan views of Trump’s economic policies have become more polarized since fall 2017](image4).

Long-term perceptions of Trump’s success are also highly divided. **76% of Republicans and Republican leaners** say he will be successful, while **80% of Democrats and Democratic leaners** think he will be unsuccessful [4] [6]. This partisan divide is more pronounced than for previous presidents like Barack Obama or George W. Bush, where early judgments were less entrenched [2] [8]. ![Partisans are more likely to offer views on Trump’s success compared to prior presidents](image3).

Compared to past presidents, fewer people say it is "too early to tell" whether Trump will be successful **(23%)**, unlike Obama **(47%)**, Bush **(38%)**, or Clinton **(43%)** at comparable points [2] [5]. ![Trump’s long-term success perceptions are more negative compared to Obama, Bush, and Clinton](image8).

In summary, perceptions of Trump’s presidency are highly polarized along partisan lines, with Republicans generally supportive and Democrats critical, and these views are more entrenched and negative compared to those of previous presidents.

Perceptions of Trump’s presidency vary significantly between party affiliates and differ notably from those of his predecessors, Obama, Bush, and Clinton. Among Republicans and Republican-leaning independents, 65% believe Trump will be a successful president in the long run, similar to how 69% of Republicans viewed Bush in 2003 [6][10]. However, Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents overwhelmingly view Trump negatively, with 80% believing he will be unsuccessful [1]. This partisan divide is more pronounced than for previous presidents; for instance, at comparable points in their presidencies, fewer Democrats held such negative views of Obama (8%), Bush (48%), or Clinton (37%) [2][10].

![Partisan views of Trump’s success compared to Obama, Bush, and Clinton](image2)  
When it comes to economic policies, Republicans’ support for Trump has grown, with 79% now believing his policies have improved conditions, up from 63% in 2017 [9]. Conversely, Democrats’ views have become more negative, with 46% saying his policies have worsened conditions [9]. This polarization is evident in the chart below, showing the growing divergence in perceptions of Trump’s economic impact between party affiliates.

![Partisan views of Trump’s economic policies over time](image1)  
Public opinion trends also reveal lower expectations for Trump’s legacy. While 47% of Americans believe he will be unsuccessful in the long run, this is higher than the comparable shares for Obama (18%), Bush (28%), and Clinton (34%) [5][11]. Additionally, fewer people say it’s too early to judge Trump’s success (23%) compared to his predecessors, indicating a more decisive public opinion [3][5].  

![Long-term perceptions of Trump’s success compared to previous presidents](image3)  
Overall, Trump’s presidency has seen greater partisan polarization and more negative public assessments than those of Obama, Bush, and Clinton, with fewer undecided opinions and a starker divide between party affiliates.

Perceptions of Trump's potential success as a president are starkly divided along partisan lines. **About two-thirds of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (65%) believe Trump will be a successful president in the long run**, while **80% of Democrats and Democratic leaners think he will be unsuccessful** [9][12]. This partisan divide is further illustrated in the data: **only 3% of Democrats view Trump as successful, compared to 69% of Republicans** ![Partisan views on Trump's success](image6).

When it comes to confidence in Mueller’s investigation, the split is similarly pronounced. **72% of Democrats and Democratic leaners are at least somewhat confident in the fairness of Mueller’s investigation**, whereas **58% of Republicans and Republican leaners express little or no confidence in it** [10]. ![Confidence in Mueller's investigation](image1). This reflects a clear pattern: **Republicans, who are more likely to view Trump as successful, also tend to distrust Mueller’s investigation, while Democrats, who view Trump as unsuccessful, are more confident in Mueller’s fairness**.

The relationship between these perceptions is deeply rooted in partisanship. **Republicans’ confidence in Trump’s success and skepticism of Mueller align with their overall support for the president, while Democrats’ lack of confidence in Trump and trust in Mueller reflect their opposition to his presidency** [2][5][10]. ![Partisan confidence levels in Trump and Mueller](image7). This dynamic highlights how partisan identities shape both evaluations of Trump and trust in institutions like the Mueller investigation.

Perceptions of economic conditions and job availability vary significantly between political affiliations, with Republicans generally expressing more positive views than Democrats. Currently, 71% of Republicans say there are plenty of jobs available locally, compared to 53% of Democrats [1][6]. This partisan gap has been consistent over time, with Republicans historically more optimistic about job availability and personal financial situations. For example, in October 2017, 58% of Republicans and 47% of Democrats viewed jobs as widely available locally [6]. ![Republicans are more likely than Democrats to say there are plenty of jobs available locally](image4)

Similarly, Republicans are more likely to rate their personal financial situation as excellent or good (62% vs. 44% of Democrats) [3] and are more optimistic about future financial improvement (84% vs. 60%) [7]. ![Republicans are more optimistic about their financial future than Democrats](image8)

Trends over time show that positive views of job availability have increased across both parties, particularly for Republicans. The share of adults saying there are plenty of jobs locally (60%) is the highest since the question was first asked in 2001 [5]. Views of local job opportunities are among the most positive in the last two decades for both parties [4]. ![Positive perceptions of job availability have risen steadily since 2001](image7)

However, while majorities in both parties agree on the availability of jobs, perceptions of "good jobs" are less favorable, with 45% of adults saying good jobs are difficult to find [12]. This suggests that while job availability is seen positively, concerns remain about the quality of those jobs. ![Perceptions of good job availability are less positive than general job availability](image4)

In summary, Republicans consistently express more optimistic views of economic conditions and job availability than Democrats, and these perceptions have trended positively over time, especially for Republicans. However, concerns about the availability of "good jobs" persist across both parties.

Perceptions of job availability have become increasingly positive in recent years, but they remain sharply divided along partisan lines. Currently, 71% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents say there are plenty of jobs available locally, compared to 53% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents [4][6]. This partisan gap has widened since October 2017, when 58% of Republicans and 47% of Democrats held this view [6]. 

![Partisan views of job availability have shifted significantly over time, with Republicans consistently reporting higher optimism than Democrats.](image1)

The upward trend in positive perceptions of job availability has been particularly pronounced among Republicans. Since President Trump’s election, Republican views of the economy and job market have become much more favorable, with 75% rating economic conditions as excellent or good [12]. By contrast, Democrats have grown more negative in their assessments of the administration’s economic policies, with 46% now saying these policies have worsened economic conditions [7]. 

![Republicans and Democrats differ sharply in their views of job availability, with Republicans showing greater optimism.](image5)

Over the past two decades, both parties have experienced fluctuations in their perceptions of job availability. For instance, in 2001, only 42% of Republicans and 24% of Democrats said jobs were plentiful, but by 2019, these figures had risen to 69% and 33%, respectively [image1]. Despite these increases, the partisan gap has persisted, reflecting broader polarization in economic attitudes.

![Public satisfaction with the economy and job availability remains low, even as perceptions of job availability improve.](image3)

Interestingly, while perceptions of job availability have improved, public satisfaction with national conditions remains low. Only 26% of Americans are satisfied with the way things are going in the country, down from 33% in September 2019 [10]. This suggests that positive views of the job market have not translated into broader contentment with the state of the nation. Overall, partisan differences in perceptions of job availability remain significant and have intensified in recent years.

Public opinions on Wall Street's impact on the economy vary significantly based on political affiliation. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely to believe that Wall Street helps the U.S. economy, with 55% stating it helps more than it hurts, compared to 31% who think the opposite [2]. In contrast, Democrats are more divided, with 46% saying Wall Street hurts the economy more than it helps and 41% saying it helps more than it hurts [7]. ![Republicans are more likely to view Wall Street positively, while Democrats are divided](image1).

Satisfaction with national conditions has been consistently low across both parties for over a decade, with no more than about a third of Americans expressing satisfaction at any point [3]. Currently, only 26% of Americans are satisfied with the way things are going in the country, while 70% are dissatisfied [5]. Satisfaction levels have dropped sharply among both Republicans (from 59% to 47%) and Democrats (from 14% to 8%) since September [1][8]. ![Public dissatisfaction with national conditions has risen significantly](image5).

Overall, while Republicans tend to view Wall Street more favorably, both parties share a growing dissatisfaction with the state of the nation, reflecting a broader trend of declining public morale across the political spectrum.

Public satisfaction levels and political affiliations have shifted significantly from 1990 to 2019, with growing polarization between parties. In 1990, satisfaction levels were relatively higher, but by 2019, only 26% of Americans expressed satisfaction with the state of the nation, while 70% were dissatisfied [5]. This decline is evident across both parties, with Republicans showing a significant drop in satisfaction from 59% in September 2018 to 47% in 2019, the lowest since late 2017 [2]. Democrats, on the other hand, have consistently expressed low satisfaction, with only 8% satisfied in 2019 [10].

![Satisfaction and dissatisfaction trends from 1990 to 2019](image5)  
The graph illustrates the steady decline in satisfaction and rise in dissatisfaction over the past three decades.

Partisan divisions are also evident in views of Wall Street’s impact on the economy. Republicans are more likely to believe Wall Street helps the economy (55% vs. 31%) [6], while Democrats are more divided, with 46% saying it hurts and 41% saying it helps [7]. These views have remained relatively stable since 2014, but the partisan gap has grown, reflecting broader polarization [12].

![Partisan views on Wall Street's impact on the economy](image8)  
The chart highlights the stark contrast between Republican and Democratic perceptions of Wall Street’s role in the economy.

In summary, public satisfaction has declined significantly since 1990, with growing partisan polarization. This division extends to views on Wall Street, where Republicans and Democrats increasingly hold opposing perspectives on its economic impact.

Public confidence in Trump’s ability to make good appointments to the federal courts shows a stark divide between Republicans and Democrats. Among Republicans and Republican-leaning independents, **64% are very or somewhat confident** in Trump’s ability to make good judicial appointments, with **24% being very confident**. In contrast, only **12% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents** express confidence, with a mere **2% being very confident** [3][7][12]. This disparity reflects broader partisan differences in trust regarding Trump’s capabilities.

When compared to other tasks, Trump’s confidence ratings on judicial appointments are lower than his ratings for negotiating favorable trade agreements, where **89% of Republicans** express confidence, but similar to managing the executive branch effectively, where **51% of Republicans** are confident [3][6][9]. ![Image showing Republican and Democratic confidence levels on federal court appointments](image7) ![Image showing confidence levels on managing the executive branch](image3).

Overall, Republicans are more confident in Trump’s ability to negotiate trade agreements than in his judicial appointments or executive management, while Democrats remain deeply skeptical across all areas.

Confidence in Trump’s ability to separate his business interests from presidential decisions varies significantly across political affiliations. Most Republicans express confidence in Trump, with 55% saying they are very confident and 23% somewhat confident. Conservative Republicans are particularly supportive, with 66% very confident, compared to 39% of moderate and liberal Republicans [5]. In contrast, Democrats are deeply skeptical, with 69% not at all confident and another 20% not too confident. Liberal Democrats are the most skeptical, with 83% not at all confident [6]. Overall, only 28% of Americans are very confident, and 41% are not at all confident in Trump’s separation of interests [8].

![Comparison of confidence levels across political affiliations](image8)

Perceptions of Trump’s responsibility to release his tax returns also show sharp partisan divides. While 64% of the public believes he has this responsibility, this view is overwhelmingly supported by Democrats and Democratic leaners. However, only 32% of Republicans agree, with 64% saying he does not have this responsibility [9][10]. This stark contrast reflects the broader polarization in views of Trump’s ethical standards and transparency.

![Public and partisan views on Trump's responsibility to release tax returns](image6)

In summary, Republicans are far more confident in Trump’s separation of business interests and less likely to see his tax returns as a responsibility, while Democrats express strong skepticism on both issues.

Partisan divides significantly shape perceptions of COVID-19 response effectiveness and trust in institutions, with Republicans and Democrats holding starkly different views. For instance, only 22% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents believe the U.S. response has been more effective than that of other wealthy nations, while 87% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents view it as less effective [1][8]. This divergence is also evident in assessments of public health officials, with 72% of Democrats giving positive ratings to the CDC and other public health officials, compared to just 53% of Republicans [9][12]. ![Public health officials receive higher approval from Democrats than Republicans](image4).

The partisan gap is further highlighted in views on government actions during the pandemic. For example, 82% of Democrats consider the federal government’s inadequate response a major reason for the outbreak’s continuation, compared to only 21% of Republicans [2]. Similarly, Democrats are more likely than Republicans to praise state and local government officials for their handling of the crisis [5]. ![Democrats are more critical of the federal government’s response](image8).

However, there is bipartisan agreement on the positive performance of hospitals and medical centers, with 87% of Democrats and 90% of Republicans approving their response to COVID-19 [3][image1]. ![Hospitals receive bipartisan approval for their COVID-19 response](image1).

In summary, partisan divides dominate perceptions of COVID-19 response effectiveness and institutional trust, with Democrats expressing greater criticism of federal and public health officials while both parties agree on the commendable role of hospitals.

The perception of the COVID-19 response by public health officials and Donald Trump has been heavily influenced by partisan differences, as evidenced by multiple surveys from March to August. Among Democrats, positive views of public health officials like those at the CDC have remained largely stable, with 74% in March and 72% recently expressing approval [2][10]. In contrast, Republicans' positive ratings of public health officials have plummeted by 31 points, from 84% in March to 53% recently [2][10]. This decline is almost entirely driven by Republicans, reflecting growing partisan polarization over the handling of the pandemic [9][10].

![Republicans' positive ratings of public health officials fell sharply from March to August](image2)

Similarly, evaluations of Donald Trump’s response show stark partisan divides. Democrats’ disapproval of Trump’s handling of the crisis has risen sharply, with 56% rating his response as “poor” in March compared to 82% recently [3]. Trump’s overall job approval has also declined since March, though it remained relatively stable from June onward [5]. This suggests that while Democrats have grown increasingly critical of Trump’s response, Republicans’ views have not shifted as significantly.

![Democrats’ disapproval of Trump’s COVID-19 response increased steeply from March to August](image3)

These trends highlight how partisan affiliations shape public perceptions of leadership and institutional responses during the pandemic. Democrats tend to favor state and local government officials and public health experts, while Republicans have grown more skeptical of these entities and remain divided on Trump’s performance [6][7][12].

Approval ratings for public health officials and Donald Trump have shifted significantly from March to August, with notable partisan differences in these changes.  

Public health officials, such as those at the CDC, saw a decline in positive ratings. In March, 79% of Americans rated their response to the coronavirus outbreak as excellent or good, but this dropped to 63% by August [4]. This decline was driven almost entirely by Republicans, whose approval fell from 84% in March to 53% in August [1]. Democrats’ views remained relatively stable, with 74% approving in March and 72% in August [12]. ![Decline in approval of public health officials largely driven by Republicans](image7)  

Donald Trump’s approval ratings for his handling of the coronavirus also declined. In March, 45% of Americans approved of his response, but this fell to 37% by August [10]. Partisan differences were stark: 77% of Republicans approved of Trump’s performance, compared to just 5% of Democrats [2]. Among Democrats, the share rating Trump’s response as “poor” rose from 56% in March to 82% in August [8]. ![Trump’s approval ratings show significant partisan divide](image5)  

In summary, public health officials saw a significant drop in approval, primarily among Republicans, while Trump’s approval also declined sharply, with Democrats overwhelmingly critical of his response.

Americans have increasingly negative perceptions of both state governments and President Trump’s handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, though the extent and nature of criticism differ. Positive evaluations of state government responses have declined from 70% in March to 56% by July-August 2020 [8]. Similarly, nearly half of Americans (48%) rate Trump’s response as “poor,” a 16-point increase since March [9]. This indicates growing dissatisfaction with both state and federal leadership.

![Declining positive evaluations of state and Trump's COVID-19 response](image8)

Partisan divides further shape these perceptions. While Republicans are more likely to offer positive assessments of Trump’s response [5], Democrats are overwhelmingly critical, with 87% viewing the U.S. response as less effective than other wealthy nations [5]. In contrast, views of state governments are less polarized, though still declining across party lines [8].

![Partisan differences in views of federal and state responses](image7)

A key distinction lies in the specifics of criticism. While state governments are primarily criticized for lifting restrictions too quickly (58% consider this a major reason for the continued outbreak) [6], Trump’s handling is often judged more harshly for perceived federal inadequacies. For instance, 53% of Americans cite an inadequate federal response as a major reason for the outbreak’s persistence [4]. Democrats, in particular, are far more critical of the federal government’s role (82%) compared to Republicans (21%) [4].

![Concerns about lifting restrictions too quickly and inadequate federal response](image4)

In summary, while both state governments and Trump face declining approval, Trump’s response is viewed more critically, particularly regarding federal leadership, whereas state governments are primarily faulted for hastening the lifting of restrictions.

Americans’ perceptions of the effectiveness in handling COVID-19 vary significantly between elected officials and public health officials. Positive evaluations of public health officials, such as those with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), have declined from 79% in March to 63% in July-August [5]. This decline is largely driven by Republicans, with only 53% giving positive ratings, down from 84% in March, while Democrats’ views remain relatively stable at 72% [7]. ![Public health officials' ratings have declined](image2)

In contrast, assessments of elected officials are even more critical. Positive views of state government officials have dropped from 70% to 56%, and local government officials’ ratings have fallen from 69% to 60% [1]. Donald Trump’s positive ratings for handling the pandemic have also declined, with only 37% saying he is doing an excellent or good job, down from earlier in the outbreak [10]. ![Elected officials' ratings have declined significantly](image2)

Several factors are believed to contribute to the continued COVID-19 outbreak. Three-quarters of Americans cite too few people abiding by social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines as a major reason [2]. ![Social distancing and mask-wearing are major concerns](image3) A smaller majority (58%) point to lifting restrictions too quickly in some places as a significant factor [2]. ![Lifting restrictions too quickly is a concern](image7) Additionally, 53% view an inadequate federal government response as a major reason, though this view is heavily polarized, with 82% of Democrats and only 21% of Republicans agreeing [11]. ![Inadequate federal response is a concern](image3)

In summary, Americans are increasingly critical of both elected and public health officials’ handling of COVID-19, with concerns centering on poor adherence to guidelines, premature lifting of restrictions, and perceived inadequacies in the federal response.

Political affiliations significantly influence perceptions of government responsibility and the reasons cited for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak. Democrats and Republicans hold contrasting views on who should be primarily responsible for developing and executing policies to limit the spread of the virus. While 68% of Republicans believe state and local governments should take the lead, 64% of Democrats argue that the federal government bears most of the responsibility [8]. This division is further illustrated in image4, which shows the public’s split opinion on whether the federal government or state and local governments are primarily responsible.![Public divided over government responsibility during COVID-19](image4)

Regarding the reasons for the outbreak’s continuation, Democrats are more likely than Republicans to cite insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing (89% vs. 57%) and an inadequate federal government response (82% vs. 21%) as major factors [1][11]. Image2 highlights these partisan differences, with Democrats more likely to view these issues as significant contributors to the ongoing outbreak.![Partisan differences in reasons for COVID-19 continuation](image2)

Additionally, three-quarters of Americans agree that a major reason for the continued outbreak is that too few people are adhering to social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines, while 58% blame the lifting of restrictions too quickly [12]. Image1 supports this, showing that 75% of respondents consider insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing a major reason, followed by 58% who cite the premature lifting of restrictions.![Major reasons for the continuation of COVID-19](image1)

In summary, political affiliations shape perceptions of government responsibility and the causes of the COVID-19 outbreak, with Democrats more likely to criticize federal inaction and Republicans favoring state-level governance, while both parties acknowledge the role of insufficient public adherence to guidelines.

Political affiliations significantly shape perceptions about the main reasons for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak, particularly regarding government response and social distancing. Democrats are much more likely than Republicans to view inadequate federal government responses and lifting restrictions too quickly as major reasons for the outbreak's persistence. For instance, 82% of Democrats see an inadequate federal response as a major factor, compared to only 21% of Republicans [1][12]. Similarly, 82% of Democrats believe lifting restrictions too quickly is a major reason, while just 31% of Republicans agree [1][8].

![Democrats are more critical of the federal response and lifting restrictions](image2)

On the other hand, Republicans are more likely than Democrats to argue that it isn’t possible to do much to control the spread, though this view is still a minority in both groups (35% of Republicans vs. 20% of Democrats) [2]. Both parties, however, broadly agree that insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing are major reasons for the outbreak’s continuation, with 75% of the total population citing this as a top factor [3][5][7]. 

![Both parties agree on the importance of social distancing, but differ on other factors](image7)

Overall, Democrats emphasize government actions and restrictions as key drivers, while Republicans are more skeptical of the government’s role and the feasibility of controlling the outbreak.

Perceptions of the federal government’s response to the COVID-19 outbreak vary significantly between political affiliations. **82% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents** view an inadequate federal response as a major reason for the virus's continued spread, compared to just **21% of Republicans and GOP leaners**[1][2][11]. ![Wide partisan gap on federal response](image7)  

The general public cites several major reasons for the outbreak’s continuation:  
- **Insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing** is the top reason for both parties, with **75% of the public** overall seeing it as a major factor[4][8].  
- **Lifting restrictions too quickly** is another key issue, with **82% of Democrats** but only **31% of Republicans** considering it a major reason[9][11]. ![Partisan views on lifting restrictions](image3)  
- **Inadequate federal response** is a major reason for **53% of Americans**, with the partisan gap being the widest on this issue[6][11].  
- **Lack of timely testing** is also significant, with **49% of the public** citing it as a major reason, but **67% of Democrats** compared to **30% of Republicans**[6][7].  

Overall, Democrats are more likely than Republicans to attribute the outbreak’s continuation to factors like inadequate federal response, rapid lifting of restrictions, and insufficient testing, while Republicans are more divided, with many attributing the rise in cases to increased testing rather than new infections[1][4]. ![Partisan views on testing and infections](image1)

Partisan beliefs show significant differences in how Democrats and Republicans perceive the reasons for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak and the adequacy of measures in place. Democrats are far more likely than Republicans to attribute the ongoing outbreak to inadequate federal response, with 82% of Democrats viewing this as a major reason, compared to just 21% of Republicans [1][8]. Similarly, 82% of Democrats believe that lifting restrictions too quickly is a major factor, while only 31% of Republicans agree [7][8]. ![Federal response inadequacy](image5) 

On the other hand, Republicans are more likely to attribute the rise in confirmed cases to increased testing rather than new infections, with 62% holding this view compared to 8% of Democrats [3][11]. ![Testing vs. infections](image1) Additionally, Republicans are slightly more likely to believe that not enough social distancing and mask-wearing are major reasons for the outbreak, though majorities in both parties agree on this [10]. ![Social distancing and mask-wearing](image2) 

Furthermore, Democrats are more likely to point to a lack of timely testing as a major issue, with 67% citing this compared to 30% of Republicans [12]. ![Timely testing](image8) Republicans, however, are more inclined to believe that there is little that can be done to control the spread, with 35% holding this view compared to 20% of Democrats [6]. ![Control measures](image8)

In summary, Democrats are more critical of federal and state-level responses, while Republicans are more likely to attribute case increases to testing and believe in limitations on control measures. ![Partisan differences in COVID-19 beliefs](image7)

Perspectives on the reasons for rising COVID-19 cases and the lifting of restrictions vary significantly across political affiliations. Republicans and Democrats hold contrasting views on these issues, reflecting a deep partisan divide.  

Roughly two-thirds of conservative Republicans attribute the rise in COVID-19 cases primarily to increased testing [1], while 62% of Republicans overall share this view [8]. By contrast, Democrats overwhelmingly believe the increase in cases is due to more infections, not just more testing, with 80% holding this view [10].  

When it comes to the lifting of restrictions, 82% of Democrats say that some places have been too quick to ease restrictions, a major reason for the ongoing outbreak [2]. On the other hand, only 31% of Republicans agree, with 32% stating this is not a reason at all [2]. Republicans are more divided on this issue: 53% are more concerned that restrictions have not been lifted quickly enough, while 45% worry they have been lifted too quickly [3].  

![Graph showing partisan views on reasons for rising cases](image5)
