Democrats and Republicans hold sharply contrasting views on expanding the U.S.-Mexico border wall. By a wide margin, independents oppose Trump’s signature policy proposal, with 62% against and 36% in favor [1]. Specifically, Democratic-leaning independents overwhelmingly oppose the border wall (95% disapprove), as do Democratic identifiers (92%) [1]. In contrast, Republican-leaning independents favor expanding the border wall, though by a smaller margin than Republican identifiers. GOP leaners support substantial expansion by roughly three-to-one (75% to 23%), while those who affiliate with the Republican Party support it by nearly eight-to-one (87% to 11%) [10]. 

![Most Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents oppose expanding the U.S.-Mexico border wall, while most Republicans and Republican-leaning independents favor it.](image6) This contrast highlights the deep partisan divide on this issue.

There is a significant partisan divide in how Democrats and Republicans view the performance of public health officials in responding to COVID-19. Currently, 72% of Democrats and those who lean Democratic believe public health officials, such as those at the CDC, are doing well, which is little changed since March (74%) [3][8]. In contrast, only 53% of Republicans give positive ratings to public health officials, marking a sharp 31-point decline from the 84% who approved in late March [1][3][5]. This decline is almost entirely driven by Republicans, as Democrats’ views have remained largely stable [4]. ![Decline in Republican approval of public health officials](image1)

The data also shows that positive assessments of state and local government officials’ responses have slipped since March, with steeper declines among Republicans than Democrats. For example, approval of state officials dropped by 14 points and local officials by 9 points, with Republicans driving most of the decline [9]. ![Partisan differences in approval of government officials](image5)

These divergent views are part of a broader pattern of partisan differences in perceptions of the COVID-19 response. While both parties generally agree on the positive performance of hospitals and medical centers (88% overall), Republicans and Democrats are far more divided on the effectiveness of public health officials, state and local governments, and the U.S. response compared to other wealthy nations [2][6][12]. ![Partisan agreement on hospitals' response to COVID-19](image5) ![Divergent views on U.S. response compared to other nations](image7) 

In summary, Democrats remain largely supportive of public health officials’ response to COVID-19, while Republican approval has declined significantly since March, reflecting a widening partisan gap in perceptions.

Seniors (aged 65+) have significantly lower technology adoption rates compared to the general adult population. While 77% of seniors own a cell phone, this trails the national average of 91% [6]. Internet usage also shows a gap, with 59% of seniors reporting they go online, compared to higher rates among younger adults [7]. Broadband access at home is available to 47% of seniors, while it is more common in the general population [4]. ![{Seniors lag in internet and broadband adoption}](image2)

Social networking site usage is lower among seniors as well, with only 32% of seniors who go online using such platforms, compared to higher rates in younger age groups [12]. ![{Lower social networking usage among seniors}](image3)

To understand how the peak hour train car requirement changes with different scenarios for Caltrain service improvement, we can analyze the data provided in the quotes and image descriptions.

Currently, Caltrain operates with 5 trains per hour, each with 5 cars, totaling **25 train cars** during peak hours [1]. However, as demand increases, various scenarios are proposed to accommodate growth.

One scenario involves using **Metrolink cars**, which would allow 6 cars per train. With 5 trains per hour, this increases the total to **30 train cars** during peak hours [4]. ![Metrolink cars scenario](image4)

Another improvement is the **electrification** of trains. This allows for 6 trains per hour, each with 6 cars, resulting in **36 train cars** during peak hours. ![Electrification scenario](image4)

Building **longer platforms** would enable trains to have 8 cars each. With 6 trains per hour, this scenario increases capacity to **48 train cars** during peak hours [2]. ![Longer platforms scenario](image4)

Finally, **increased frequency** of trains, potentially with High-Speed Rail integration, allows for 8 trains per hour, each with 8 cars, resulting in **64 train cars** during peak hours [8]. ![Increased frequency scenario](image4)

In summary, the peak hour train car requirement increases from 25 today to 64 under the most ambitious improvement scenario. These changes are driven by electrification, longer platforms, and increased train frequency. Different scenarios yield progressively higher capacities: 30, 36, 48, and 64 train cars during peak hours.

The ethical standards of top Trump administration officials are viewed more negatively compared to those of previous administrations. Overall, only 39% of the public rate the ethical standards of Trump administration officials as excellent or good, while 59% describe them as not good or poor [2][3]. These ratings are notably lower than evaluations of top officials in the five previous administrations, dating back to Reagan [3][4]. For instance, during Obama’s presidency, 49% rated the ethical standards of his administration as excellent or good in June 2013, while Reagan’s administration received a 67% rating in October 1984 [7]. 

![Ethical standards ratings of Trump administration officials compared to previous administrations](image7)

Partisanship plays a significant role in these perceptions. Among Republicans and Republican leaners, 76% rate the ethical standards of Trump administration officials as excellent or good, whereas 90% of Democrats and Democratic leaners view them as not good or poor [7]. This stark partisan divide highlights the polarized nature of these evaluations. 

In summary, the ethical standards of Trump administration officials are rated lower than those of previous administrations, with a significant partisan split in these assessments.

Since the coronavirus pandemic was declared in March 2020, Americans' perceptions of the U.S. as the world’s leading economic power have declined. While 52% of Americans still view their country as the top economy, this is a 7-point drop from 59% in March, which was an unprecedented high in Pew Research Center’s surveys[7]. This decline is reflected in the data showing a decrease in the percentage of Americans who see the U.S. as economically dominant over the years, dropping from 59% in March 2020 to 52% by July 2020[8]. ![Line graph showing the percentage of Americans who view the U.S. as the world’s leading economic power over time, with a decline from 59% in March 2020 to 52% in July 2020.](image8)

There are notable differences in these perceptions based on political affiliations. Democrats have become significantly less likely to see the U.S. as the leading global economy, with 54% holding this opinion in March compared to 44% today[6][10]. In contrast, Republicans' views have remained relatively stable over the same period[6]. This partisan divide is further highlighted by the fact that Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely to maintain their confidence in the U.S. economic dominance compared to Democrats[7]. ![Bar chart showing the percentage of Democrats and Republicans who view the U.S. as the world’s leading economic power, with Democrats experiencing a significant decline from 54% in March to 44% in July 2020.](image6)

Overall, while a majority of Americans still see the U.S. as the world’s leading economic power, this perception has declined since the pandemic, with Democrats showing a sharper decrease in confidence compared to Republicans.

Americans and Germans hold significantly different views on which country is the world’s leading economic power. The number of farms in the U.S. experienced significant changes between 1880 and 1950. According to the data, in 1880, there were 1,597 farms in Hamilton County, and this number increased to its peak of 2,049 by 1900 [2]. However, by 1950, the number of farms had declined to 1,453 [image8]. This decline reflects a broader trend of farm consolidation driven by mechanization and increased costs of operation, as noted by Hamilton County historian Bertha Bremer, who pointed out that “power equipment has accelerated farming, and no longer are farm operators content with quarter sections of land, nor can they afford to operate on such a small scale due to increased costs of operation” [2]. 

![The number of farms in Hamilton County declined from 1,597 in 1880 to 1,453 in 1950.](image8) 

Thus, the number of farms in the U.S. decreased significantly from 1880 to 1950 due to mechanization and consolidation.

Perceptions of ethical standards vary significantly across educational and political affiliation groups. Among independents, 34% say neither the Republican nor Democratic Party has high ethical standards, with Republican and Democratic leaners equally likely to hold this view (33% each). In contrast, only 19% of Republicans and 18% of Democrats share this sentiment [1]. However, majorities of both Republicans (66%) and Democrats (64%) still describe their own party as having high ethical standards [3].

Educational attainment also plays a role. Nearly a third (31%) of college graduates say neither party has high ethical standards, compared to 26% of those with some college experience and 20% of those with a high school degree or less [11][12]. Additionally, 17% of college graduates believe both parties have high ethical standards, while 43% say it applies to only one party [5].

Among Democrats, ideological differences are modest, with 93% of liberal Democrats and 83% of conservative or moderate Democrats giving low marks for the ethical standards of the Trump administration [10]. Meanwhile, 47% of the public believes "high ethical standards" describes one party but not the other, while a quarter says it describes neither [7].

![Survey conducted April 25-May 1, 2018](image1)  
![Total](image3)  
![Describes both parties](image4)  
![All registered voters](image6)  
![Total](image7)  
![Republican Party Democratic Party](image8)  

Overall, perceptions of ethical standards are more critical among independents and those with higher education, while partisans are more likely to view their own party favorably.

The primary concerns of U.S. adults regarding the use of automated personal finance scores by companies revolve around privacy, fairness, and accuracy.

These concerns are further emphasized by the broader skepticism about algorithmic decision-making, where **58%** of Americans believe computer programs will always reflect some level of human bias [3]. Internet and broadband usage among seniors shows a clear decline as age increases. From 2004 to 2015, Hispanics consistently held more optimistic financial expectations compared to the general U.S. population. In 2004, about 31% of Latinos rated their financial condition as excellent or good, while 51% of the general public held a positive view of their finances[6]. By 2015, Hispanic optimism had risen significantly, with 81% expecting their family’s financial situation to improve in the next year, compared to 61% of the general public[7]. This 20 percentage point gap was the largest since the survey series began[7]. 

The increase in optimism among Hispanics was particularly notable after the Great Recession. Between 2008 and 2015, the share of Latinos expecting their finances to improve “a lot” or “some” rose by 14 percentage points (from 67% to 81%), while the general public saw only a 6-point increase (from 56% to 61%)[12]. 

![Hispanic financial optimism rose faster than the general public from 2004 to 2015](image2)  
The chart illustrates the divergence in financial optimism between Hispanics and the general public over time, peaking in 2015.  

In summary, Hispanics were consistently more optimistic about their financial future than the general public, with their expectations rising faster, especially after the Great Recession.

The data suggests that public satisfaction has not only declined but also become more polarized, with partisan views playing a significant role in shaping perceptions of the nation's condition.

Republicans' views on government efforts to reduce the terrorist threat have become increasingly critical over time. In January 2015, 63% of Republicans said the government was doing very or fairly well in reducing the terrorist threat, but by later in the year, this number dropped sharply to just 27% [3]. This represents a significant 36-point decline in positive assessments among Republicans. Among conservative Republicans specifically, the shift is even more pronounced: only 18% now say the government is doing well, compared to 59% in January [10].

The broader trend shows that Republicans have grown more likely to believe that anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough to protect the country. Since July 2013, the percentage of Republicans expressing this view has increased by 33 points, from 38% to 71% [4]. This shift aligns with a more negative overall assessment of government efforts to combat terrorism, with only 22% of Republicans viewing the government’s actions as effective in reducing the threat [11].

![A sharp decline in Republicans' positive views on anti-terrorism efforts](image3)  
![Increasing Republican concern that anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough](image1)

In summary, Republicans have become far more critical of government efforts to reduce the terrorist threat, with a significant decline in positive assessments and a growing belief that policies are insufficient.

Perceptions toward China have significantly shifted from 2018 to 2021, with a notable increase in negative views across all political affiliations in the U.S. However, the rise has been more pronounced among Republicans compared to Democrats.  

In 2018, 48% of Republicans and lean Republicans had "very cold" feelings toward China, which surged to 63% by 2021. Similarly, among Democrats and lean Democrats, the proportion with "very cold" feelings increased from 26% to 36% over the same period. ![Very cold feelings toward China increased more among Republicans than Democrats](image3)  

The partisan gap has also widened. While 62% of Republicans reported "very cold" feelings (0-24 on a feeling thermometer) in 2021—up 31 points since 2018—only 38% of Democrats felt the same, marking a 21-point increase [3]. ![The partisan gap in negative views of China has grown since 2018](image4)  

Overall, 67% of Americans now feel "cold" toward China, a significant rise from 46% in 2018. This shift is evident across demographics, with men, older adults, and those without college degrees more likely to hold "very cold" views [9] [10]. ![Majority of Americans feel cold toward China in 2021](image2)  

In summary, negative perceptions of China have increased sharply among both Republicans and Democrats since 2018, but the rise has been more dramatic among Republicans, widening the partisan gap.

Radio listening habits show notable differences between rural and urban areas, particularly in terms of the devices used and the types of programs favored.

![News and folk music are the most popular radio programs in rural areas](image5) As for program preferences, news is the most popular radio content across both regions, but folk music is particularly favored in rural areas, making up 10% of the listenership. Urban areas, on the other hand, show a more diverse range of listening habits, including news, Nepali music, and other programs like talk shows and phone-in sessions.

Overall, rural areas predominantly use traditional radios and favor news and folk music, while urban areas lean toward mobile devices and a broader variety of programs.

The Pew Research Center survey highlights significant gender disparities in STEM employment and pay, particularly in computer-related fields. Women in computer jobs are more likely to report gender discrimination and pay inequities compared to other STEM fields. For instance, 74% of women in computer occupations have experienced gender discrimination at work, compared to 16% of men in the same field [9]. ![Women in computer jobs report higher rates of gender discrimination](image5).

Additionally, women in computer jobs are more likely to say their gender has made it harder to succeed (42% vs. 30% of men) and that their workplace pays too little attention to increasing gender diversity (77% vs. 43% of men) [9]. ![Gender-related challenges are more pronounced in computer jobs](image5).

The data also shows that computer jobs are among the highest-paying STEM occupations, yet women in these roles face significant barriers to equity. This makes computer-related STEM fields the type with the largest gender gap in consistent employment and pay disparities. ![Women in computer jobs face unique challenges despite high pay](image5).

In summary, computer-related STEM jobs exhibit the largest gender gap in consistent employment and pay, as highlighted by the Pew Research Center survey.

Perceptions of online behavior and the types of content encountered on social media vary notably between men and women. Men are slightly more likely than women to encounter harassing or abusive behavior online, with 29% of men saying they frequently see people being mean or bullying on social media, compared to 19% of women [8]. Conversely, women are slightly more likely than men to report seeing kind or supportive behavior, with 22% of women saying they more often see such interactions, compared to 18% of men [8]. However, the largest shares of both men (52%) and women (56%) say they typically see an equal mix of supportive and bullying behavior [8].  

When it comes to deceptive behavior, men are around twice as likely as women to say they more often encounter people being deceptive on social media (24% vs. 13%) [11]. Despite these differences, majorities of both men (58%) and women (67%) see an equal mix of deceptiveness and attempts to correct misinformation [11].  

The most common types of content encountered on social media include posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated (58% of users see this frequently) and people making accusations or starting arguments without having all the facts (59% see this frequently) [7]. These trends are consistent across genders, though men and women differ in their perceptions of the emotional tone and intent behind the content they encounter.  

![Figure showing perceptions of deceptive and kind behavior on social media](image2)  

In summary, men and women perceive online behavior differently, with men more likely to encounter bullying and deceptive content, while women more often see kind and supportive interactions. Both genders, however, most frequently encounter dramatic posts and unfounded arguments.

The perception that news organizations had "too much" influence on presidential elections has significantly increased over time. In 2004, following George W. Bush’s reelection, just 45% of Bush voters said news organizations had too much influence [2]. However, by 2016, a majority of voters (57%) believed the press had too much influence on the election outcome, marking the highest share since 2000 [7]. ![The perception of press influence has increased over time, with 57% of voters in 2016 saying it had "too much" influence.](image2)

This trend is further highlighted by comparisons across elections. For instance, after the 2012 and 2008 elections, only 29% and 18% of Obama voters, respectively, felt the press had too much influence, compared to 50% of Clinton voters in 2016 [8]. Similarly, larger shares of Romney (69%) and McCain (77%) voters expressed this sentiment after their respective losses, compared to 62% of Trump voters in 2016 [4]. ![The share of voters saying the press had "too much" influence has grown significantly since 2004.](image8)

Overall, the data shows a clear upward trend in the perception of the press having excessive influence on election outcomes, reaching a peak in 2016.

Overall, Republicans’ optimism about the economy surged, while Democrats’ skepticism deepened.

Perceptions of U.S. involvement in solving global problems vary significantly across political affiliations. **Republicans** and **Democrats** both generally believe that global problems would be worse without U.S. involvement, with 62% of Republicans and 56% of Democrats holding this view [12]. However, among **liberal Democrats**, opinions are more divided: 50% say the world would be worse without U.S. involvement, while 45% believe U.S. efforts usually make things worse [11]. This split highlights a more critical stance among liberal Democrats compared to their moderate counterparts. 

![Majority of Republicans and Democrats agree global problems would be worse without U.S. involvement.](image4)

Additionally, **independents** show a similar trend to the overall population, with 55% agreeing that global problems would worsen without U.S. involvement [5]. This suggests that while there is a broad consensus among Republicans, Democrats, and independents on the importance of U.S. engagement, liberal Democrats remain more skeptical of its overall impact. 

![Independents align with the majority view on U.S. involvement in global problems.](image1)

In summary, while most political groups believe U.S. involvement is beneficial globally, liberal Democrats are more likely to question its effectiveness.

Generational differences among self-identified Hispanics significantly influence the likelihood of having Hispanic friends. Immigrant Latinos are the most likely to have Hispanic friends, with 77% saying all or most of their friends are Latinos [6]. ![Immigrant Latinos are most likely to have Hispanic friends](image4) This percentage drops to 55% among second-generation self-identified Latinos and further declines to just 37% among third or higher generation self-identified Latinos [6]. ![Second-generation Hispanics have fewer Hispanic friends than immigrants](image4) The trend suggests that as generations become more removed from their immigrant roots, their social networks become less homogeneously Hispanic. This is likely due to factors such as broader social integration, higher intermarriage rates, and reduced cultural connections to their ancestral origins [2, 10]. ![Third-generation Hispanics have the least Hispanic friends](image4) This pattern reflects a gradual shift in identity and social dynamics as Hispanic Americans become more assimilated into broader U.S. society.

The overall energy efficiency from source to wheel for electric vehicles (EVs) is generally higher compared to internal combustion engine (ICE) vehicles. This is due to the energy losses at different stages of the energy conversion process.

For electric vehicles, the process begins with energy generation (Well-to-Tank), where electricity is produced from various sources. This electricity is then converted into motion with minimal losses in the electric motor (Tank-to-Wheels). ![Electric vehicles have lower energy losses in the conversion process compared to ICE vehicles](image5)

In contrast, ICE vehicles involve more energy losses. The extraction, refining, and transportation of fuel (Well-to-Tank) are less efficient, and the combustion process in the engine (Tank-to-Wheels) is also inherently less efficient than electric motors. ![ICE vehicles experience significant energy losses during fuel production and combustion](image5)

Overall, electric vehicles are more energy-efficient from source to wheel due to fewer energy conversion losses.

Women in computer jobs experience significantly higher rates of gender-related discrimination compared to men in the same field. According to the data, **74% of women in computer jobs** report experiencing discrimination due to their gender, while only **16% of men** in these jobs report the same [4][5]. ![Women in computer jobs report significantly higher rates of gender discrimination compared to men](image7)

Women in computer jobs are also more likely to face specific forms of discrimination. For instance, **46% of women** report pay inequities compared to men in the same roles, and **40%** say they have been treated as if they were not competent at work because of their gender [9]. Additionally, women are more likely to experience sexual harassment at work (**30% of women vs. 7% of men**) and feel that their gender has made it harder to succeed in their job (**31% of women vs. 6% of men**) [12]. ![Women in computer jobs face higher rates of pay inequities and workplace harassment compared to men](image1)

Furthermore, women in computer jobs are less likely to believe that women are treated fairly in opportunities for promotion and advancement (**43% of women vs. 77% of men**) or in the recruitment and hiring process (**67% of women vs. 83% of men**) [7][11]. ![Women in computer jobs perceive less fairness in promotion and hiring processes compared to men](image7)

In summary, **women in computer jobs face far greater gender-related discrimination than men, including higher rates of pay inequities, workplace harassment, and perceived unfairness in career advancement opportunities**.

In the Arab Youth Survey, the ranking of countries preferred by Arab youth shifted from 2013 to 2014. 

In 2013, the top countries were the United States, France, and Turkey, with Saudi Arabia also being a notable preference. However, by 2014, the UAE emerged as the most favored country, surpassing the United States and other nations. ![The UAE became the top choice in 2014](image1). This shift is further highlighted by the growing perception of the UAE as a model nation that Arab youth would like to emulate [10].

Additionally, the United States maintained a strong position but lost its top ranking to the UAE, while Saudi Arabia remained a significant ally and preference among Arab youth. ![Saudi Arabia and the UAE were key allies in 2014](image2). The survey also noted that regional neighbors like Saudi Arabia and the UAE were considered more important allies than traditional Western countries [12]. 

Overall, the UAE’s rise to the top of the rankings in 2014 marked a significant change in the preferences of Arab youth, reflecting its growing influence and appeal as a modern and progressive nation. ![The UAE’s position strengthened in 2014](image3).

Physical health conditions significantly impact technology use among older adults compared to the general adult population. Many seniors face physical or health challenges that make using digital devices difficult. For instance, 23% of older adults have a physical or health condition that makes reading challenging, and 29% have a disability, handicap, or chronic disease that limits their daily activities [8]. These barriers contribute to lower technology adoption rates among seniors.

![23% of older adults have a condition that makes reading difficult](image4)

Seniors with these challenges are less likely to go online (49% vs. 66%), have broadband at home (38% vs. 53%), own a cell phone (69% vs. 82%), or have a smartphone (13% vs. 22%) compared to seniors without such conditions [6]. This disparity is particularly evident among those with life-impacting disabilities or chronic diseases, where only 22% own a tablet or e-book reader [2].

![Seniors with physical challenges have lower tech adoption rates](image3)

In contrast, the general adult population faces fewer physical barriers to technology use, leading to higher adoption rates. Among all adults, a smaller percentage report conditions that impede technology use, allowing for greater engagement with digital tools [8]. This comparison highlights the need for more accessible and user-friendly technologies tailored to the needs of older adults.

From March to August, the importance of abortion as a voting issue among Latino registered voters increased significantly. In March, 42% of Latino registered voters considered abortion a very important issue. By August, this figure had risen to 57%, reflecting a 15-percentage-point increase [1] [4] [8]. This shift was driven primarily by Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners, among whom the importance of abortion rose from 42% in March to 63% in August [1]. In contrast, the share of Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners who viewed abortion as very important remained relatively stable, increasing only slightly from 43% to 48% over the same period [1]. 

![A chart illustrating the increase in abortion's importance from March to August among Latino voters](image8)

The rise in abortion’s importance aligns with broader national trends following the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn the federal right to abortion in the United States [4]. This decision appears to have particularly resonated with Hispanic Democratic voters, making abortion a more salient issue in the lead-up to the 2022 midterm elections [4] [11].

The Union Square/Market Street station in San Francisco is served by multiple transit lines. It connects to the Powell Street BART and Muni Metro [11], which implies it is a hub for both BART and Muni services. Specifically:

- The Powell Street BART station is a key BART line serving this area.  
- The Muni Metro includes several light rail lines (such as the J, K, L, M, N, and T lines) that pass through the Market Street station.  
- Additionally, the Central Subway, which began service in 2019, connects to this area [12].

Therefore, **multiple lines from BART and Muni Metro go through the Union Square/Market Street station**, making it a central transit hub in San Francisco.

On the other hand, Latino Republicans and Republican leaners are more divided. **40%** of Latino Republicans and Republican-leaning conservatives say the Republican Party works hard to earn Latino votes, while **56%** say the same about the Democratic Party [10]. This suggests that while both groups view their own party more favorably, there is a notable cross-party acknowledgment of the Democratic Party’s efforts among Republicans. 

Additionally, **51%** of Latino Democrats say the Democratic Party works hard to earn Latino votes, while nearly half of Latino Republicans (**46%**) say the opposite about the Republican Party [4]. This further highlights the contrast in perceptions between the two groups. 

In summary, Latino Democrats are more likely to believe their party works hard to earn Latino votes compared to Latino Republicans. At the same time, a significant share of Latino Republicans acknowledge the Democratic Party’s efforts in this area.

The frequency of attending Hispanic cultural celebrations in childhood varies significantly across immigrant generations. Among self-identified Hispanics, foreign-born individuals report the highest rate of attending such celebrations, with 59% saying their parents often took them to these events when growing up [12]. This reflects their closer connection to their cultural roots, as most of this group grew up outside the U.S. 

![Foreign-born Hispanics have the highest attendance rate at cultural celebrations.](image1)

Second-generation self-identified Hispanics are slightly less likely to report frequent attendance, with 49% stating their immigrant parents often took them to Hispanic cultural celebrations [3]. This suggests a gradual decline in cultural immersion as families integrate into U.S. society. 

![Second-generation Hispanics show a slight decline in cultural celebration attendance.](image1)

For third or higher-generation self-identified Hispanics, the rate drops further, with only 35% reporting frequent attendance at these events during childhood [3]. This aligns with the broader trend of fading Hispanic cultural identity across generations, as family ties to immigrant experiences weaken [8]. 

![Third or higher-generation Hispanics experience the lowest attendance rates at cultural celebrations.](image1)

In summary, the frequency of attending Hispanic cultural celebrations in childhood decreases across immigrant generations, reflecting a gradual decline in cultural immersion and identity over time.

Women’s representation in STEM jobs varies significantly by education level compared to the overall employed population. Among STEM workers with a high school education or less, women make up **55%** of the workforce, which is higher than their overall representation in all employed jobs (**41%**) [4]. However, this trend shifts as education levels increase. For those with some college education, women’s representation in STEM drops slightly to **52%**, still above the overall employed figure (**49%**) [4].  

At the bachelor’s degree level, women account for **7%** of STEM workers, which is significantly lower than their representation in the overall employed population (**54%**) [4]. This disparity continues for those with advanced degrees. Among STEM workers with a master’s degree, women make up **47%** of the workforce, slightly below the overall employed population (**50%**) [4]. For those with professional or doctoral degrees, women’s representation in STEM is **42%**, compared to **54%** in the overall employed population [4].  

![Women’s representation in STEM jobs by education level compared to the overall employed population](image4)  

Overall, women are underrepresented in STEM jobs at higher education levels, particularly among those with bachelor’s or advanced degrees, while their representation is higher or comparable at lower education levels. This highlights the challenges women face in entering or remaining in STEM fields as they pursue higher education.

Female representation in STEM job clusters varies significantly, with women being overrepresented in some fields and underrepresented in others. Women account for the majority of healthcare practitioners and technicians, making up **75%** of this cluster [2][7]. They are also well-represented in life science jobs (**47%**) and math jobs (**46%**), which aligns closely with their overall share in the workforce [6]. 

However, women are notably underrepresented in computer occupations (**25%**) and engineering jobs (**14%**) [6][11]. In fact, engineering has one of the lowest shares of women, with mechanical and electrical engineering standing at just **8%** and **9%**, respectively [4]. 

The representation gap is particularly striking in computer jobs, where the share of women has decreased from **32%** in 1990 to **25%** today, despite the rapid growth in this field [11]. 

![Women’s representation in STEM job clusters varies widely, from 75% in health-related jobs to 14% in engineering](image4) 

In summary, while women dominate health-related STEM jobs, their presence is significantly lower in computer and engineering fields, highlighting persistent gender disparities across STEM occupational clusters.

The data underscores a clear trend: unfavorable opinions of China have grown substantially across all age groups, with older Americans leading this shift.

From 1870 to 2000, Hamilton County's population underwent significant fluctuations. According to the 1870 census, the county had a population of 130. This number surged dramatically in the following decades, reaching 8,267 in 1880 and peaking at 14,096 in 1890 [2]. 

![Population trends in Hamilton County from 1870 to 2000](image3)

However, after 1890, the population began to decline gradually. By 1900, it had decreased to 13,330, and it continued to fluctuate slightly over the next century. By 2000, the population stood at 9,403, which, despite the decline from its peak, was still significantly higher than the 1870 figure [2]. This trend reflects broader patterns of rural population shifts in the Midwest and Great Plains, where many small towns experienced similar declines due to changing economic and transportation dynamics [3]. 

In summary, Hamilton County's population grew rapidly in the late 1800s, peaked in 1890, and then gradually declined over the 20th century, stabilizing at 9,403 by 2000.

Pre-training significantly improves BLEU scores across various language pairs, but the extent of the improvement depends on factors such as language similarity, resource availability, and baseline system performance.

For higher-resource language pairs like Spanish (ES), French (FR), and Italian (IT) translating to Portuguese (PT), pre-training consistently provides gains of approximately 3 BLEU points. This is evident from the data in ![Dataset showing BLEU scores for high-resource languages](image2), where ES-PT increases from 17.8 to 24.8 (+7.0), FR-PT from 12.4 to 18.1 (+5.7), and IT-PT from 14.5 to 19.2 (+4.7) [2].

For low-resource languages, the impact of pre-training varies. For example, the GL (Galician) to EN (English) pair shows a dramatic improvement from a baseline BLEU of 2.2 to 13.2 with pre-training, as seen in ![Dataset showing BLEU scores for GL-EN](image3) [1][2]. However, other low-resource pairs like AZ (Azerbaijani) and BE (Belarusian) to EN show smaller gains. AZ-EN improves from 1.3 to 2.0, while BE-EN rises from 1.6 to 2.5 [2]. This suggests that pre-training is especially impactful for languages with moderate baseline performance but not extremely low resources [11].

The similarity between source and target languages also plays a role. For instance, GL-PT, which shares a high linguistic similarity, shows the largest gains, while BE-RU, with lower similarity, shows minimal improvement or even slight decreases, as highlighted in ![Dataset showing BLEU scores and similarity](image10) [5][10]. Additionally, aligning word embeddings further enhances BLEU scores, particularly in multilingual systems, as seen in ![Dataset showing aligned BLEU scores](image4) [10].

In summary, pre-training boosts BLEU scores across language pairs, with the greatest improvements seen in languages with moderate baseline performance and high linguistic similarity to their target languages.

The inclusion of reference translations in the **COMET-RANK** metric significantly enhances its performance across language pairs involving English. This is evident from the results in Table 7, where the model trained with both reference and source inputs consistently outperforms the version trained with reference only. For example, in the **en-cs** pair, the full model achieves a Kendall’s Tau score of 0.711 compared to 0.660 for the reference-only model. Similar improvements are observed in other pairs like **en-de** (0.799 vs. 0.764) and **en-fi** (0.671 vs. 0.630) [9]. ![Reference inclusion improves COMET-RANK scores across language pairs](image7)

The improvement is even more pronounced when English is the target language. For instance, in **de-en**, the full model achieves a score of 0.356, a significant increase from 0.249 for the reference-only variant. This trend is consistent across other reversed pairs like **fi-en** (0.278 vs. 0.159) and **tr-en** (0.260 vs. 0.128) [9]. The inclusion of the source text during training allows the model to better align translations with human judgments, even in zero-shot scenarios where English is the target [4]. ![Significant improvements in reversed language pairs with source inclusion](image7)

Overall, the **COMET-RANK** model’s reliance on both reference and source text leads to stronger correlations with human judgments, particularly in language pairs involving English, whether as the source or target language. This highlights the importance of incorporating both inputs for robust MT evaluation.

In relative evaluations, annotator agreement levels for Chameleon compared to other models show consistency but with some variability. When comparing Chameleon to Gemini+, 31.5% of cases had all three annotators agree, 58.1% had two annotators agree, and 10.3% had no agreement. Similar patterns are observed when comparing Chameleon to GPT-4V+, with 35.4% unanimous agreement, 55.2% two-annotator agreement, and 9.3% no agreement [4]. For comparisons with the original Gemini and GPT-4V models (without image augmentation), the agreement levels were slightly lower: Chameleon vs. Gemini had 30.2% unanimous agreement, 59.3% two-annotator agreement, and 10.5% no agreement, while Chameleon vs. GPT-4V had 28.6% unanimous agreement, 58.3% two-annotator agreement, and 13.1% no agreement [5].

These results suggest that inter-annotator reliability for Chameleon’s performance is generally strong, as the majority of cases (over 85%) have at least two annotators agreeing. The relatively low percentage of no-agreement cases (around 10%) indicates that Chameleon’s responses are often clear and consistent in quality, making it easier for annotators to reach a consensus. However, the variability in unanimous agreement (~28% to 35%) implies that Chameleon’s performance is sometimes on par with or similar to the baselines, leading to more subjective judgments in relative evaluations [4].

When the number of demonstration samples increases from 1 to 5, there is a significant improvement in Micro-F1 performance for both the MAVEN-ERE and CTB datasets, whether logical constraints are included or not. However, the improvements become limited when the number of demonstrations increases further, especially beyond 10 samples. 

![Adding logical constraints provides stable improvements, especially with more demonstrations.](image1)

For instance, on the MAVEN-ERE dataset, the performance with 5 demonstrations and logical constraints (25.7%) surpasses that with 10 demonstrations without logical constraints (24.5%) [4]. This indicates that logical constraints can compensate for a smaller number of demonstrations, demonstrating their importance in enhancing LLM performance. The results suggest that while increasing demonstration samples initially boosts performance, the marginal gains diminish after a certain point, and logical constraints play a crucial role in achieving better results with fewer demonstrations.

The main error types identified in Step-Back Prompting on TimeQA include **Reasoning Error**, **RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation)**, **Context Loss**, **Factual Error**, **Math Error**, and **Principle Error** [4][5][6]. Among these, **Reasoning Error** and **RAG** are the dominant sources of errors [3]. Specifically, **Reasoning Error** occurs when the model makes mistakes in intermediate reasoning steps before arriving at the final answer, while **RAG** errors happen when the retrieval process fails to fetch relevant information despite a correct step-back question [5][10].

![Error breakdown in Step-Back Prompting shows Reasoning and RAG as dominant error sources](image3)  
The image confirms that **Reasoning Error** and **RAG** are the major contributors to errors in Step-Back Prompting on TimeQA.

**Context Loss** occurs when the model deviates from addressing the original question, **Factual Error** arises when the model incorrectly recites its own factual knowledge, and **Math Error** happens in intermediate calculations [5][6]. **Principle Error**, which occurs during the Abstraction step, is less frequent, accounting for only a small fraction of errors [12]. 

![Principle Error comprises a small fraction of errors, with Reasoning Error and Math Error being dominant](image7)  
This image illustrates that **Principle Error** is minimal, while **Reasoning Error** and **Math Error** dominate the error distribution.

In summary, **Reasoning Error** and **RAG** are the primary error types in Step-Back Prompting on TimeQA, with **Principle Error** being the least frequent.

Post-hoc correction appears to have the most representative papers in the survey, as indicated by the extensive categorization and examples provided in the literature. The post-hoc correction strategy involves refining the model output after it has been generated, without updating the model parameters [2]. This method is highlighted for its flexibility and ability to incorporate diverse natural language feedback, ranging from specific diagnostic reports to broader writing suggestions [1]. 

![Post-hoc Correction with External Feedback involves a refine model, critic model, and external tools to improve outputs](image5)

Additionally, the survey categorizes post-hoc correction into three key strategies: Self-Correction, Correction with External Feedback, and Multi-Agent Debate [1]. The detailed table in image3 further supports this by listing numerous studies under the post-hoc correction category, showcasing a variety of applications such as QA, code generation, and fact-checking. This breadth of research underscores the prominence of post-hoc correction in the reviewed literature. 

![A detailed table listing various studies and methods under post-hoc correction](image3)

In summary, post-hoc correction stands out as the most represented strategy in the survey due to its extensive application and the variety of methods it encompasses.

The parameter \(\alpha\) in the Tversky Index (TI) plays a significant role in balancing false-positives and false-negatives, thus influencing the F1 score. Experiments on the Chinese OntoNotes4.0 and English QuoRef datasets demonstrate that varying \(\alpha\) leads to different F1 scores, with optimal values yielding the highest performance. 

![F1 scores for different \(\alpha\) values on Chinese Onto4.0 and English QuoRef](image1) shows the experimental results. For the Chinese OntoNotes4.0 dataset, the highest F1 score of 84.67 is achieved when \(\alpha\) is set to 0.6. In contrast, for the English QuoRef dataset, the optimal \(\alpha\) is 0.4, resulting in an F1 score of 68.44. This indicates that the optimal \(\alpha\) value varies depending on the dataset, highlighting its importance in fine-tuning the tradeoff between false-positives and false-negatives [4][11]. 

In summary, \(\alpha\) significantly impacts the F1 score, with the optimal values being 0.6 for Chinese OntoNotes4.0 and 0.4 for English QuoRef.

The TRADE model demonstrates the best joint performance specifically on the restaurant subset of the MultiWOZ dataset, achieving a joint goal accuracy of 65.35% [3][7]. This outperforms other models such as GCE, which achieves 60.93% joint accuracy on the same subset [3]. 

![TRADE performance on MultiWOZ and its restaurant subset](image3)  
The comparison table above shows TRADE's joint accuracy in contrast to other models like MDBT, GLAD, GCE, and SpanPtr, further confirming its superior performance [7]. 

TRADE's ability to handle multi-domain dialogues effectively, combined with its transfer learning capabilities, contributes to its strong performance on this dataset [11]. For instance, it uses a copy mechanism to predict domain, slot, and value triplets, which is particularly useful in complex multi-turn conversations [11]. 

Additionally, TRADE's fine-tuning with the GEM strategy helps maintain high performance even when adapting to new domains, as seen in its results on the restaurant subset [1][4]. 

In summary, TRADE is the top-performing model for the restaurant subset of MultiWOZ, as evidenced by its joint goal accuracy and advanced transfer learning features.

The multitask model in Figure 1b differs from the single-task model in Figure 1a primarily in how decoder attention is structured. In the **single-task model**, there is a single decoder that attends directly to the encoder states to generate the output sequence. ![The single-task model uses a single decoder with direct attention to the encoder states](image6(a)) [11]. In contrast, the **multitask model** employs two decoders, each with its own attention mechanism, but they share the same encoder. ![The multitask model uses two decoders with separate attention mechanisms, both sharing the same encoder](image6(b)) [12]. This means that while the encoder’s output is shared, each decoder independently attends to the encoder states to perform its specific task, allowing for more specialized processing of the input sequence.

The RAR (Retrieving and Ranking) pipeline for multimodal retrieval consists of several key components, each playing a critical role in enhancing the fine-grained perception capabilities of Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs). 

![The multimodal retriever encodes and stores feature embeddings for efficient retrieval](image1)  
The **Multimodal Retriever** is the first component, responsible for querying a large external memory or database to find relevant information. It encodes and stores multimodal embeddings (visual and textual) and employs indexing techniques like the HNSW algorithm to optimize retrieval speed and efficiency. This step ensures that the top-k most similar categories to the input image are identified [9].

After retrieval, the process moves to the **Inference Pipeline**. Here, the retrieved category labels and image embeddings are integrated and sent to the MLLMs through a ranking prompt. The MLLMs, leveraging their internal knowledge and the retrieved information, rank the candidate categories to make the final prediction [2][6]. 

![The ranking prompt merges retrieved categories with image embeddings for MLLMs](image6)  
The **Ranking Prompt** is a crucial element in this process, guiding the MLLMs to rank the retrieved candidates based on similarity. This step ensures a contextually aware and accurate classification prediction [5].

For object detection tasks, the pipeline includes a **Pre-processing Step** where images are cropped based on bounding boxes and resized to a fixed proportion. Non-target areas are blurred to focus the MLLM’s attention on the objects of interest, facilitating better identification [4].

The RAR pipeline combines these components to synergize the strengths of retrieval-based methods and MLLMs, significantly improving performance in fine-grained, few-shot, and zero-shot visual recognition tasks [8][12].

The authors divided the process of causal inference into **six key steps**, as outlined in the preparation and solution phases of their multi-step reasoning process. These steps are:

1. Identifying the causal graph structure [5].  
2. Determining the causal query type [5].  
3. Formulating the query symbolically and precisely [5].  
4. Extracting relevant data from the prompt [5].  
5. Correctly deducing the estimand using causal inference techniques [5].  
6. Evaluating the estimand to answer the question [5].  

This structured approach ensures both natural language understanding and formal causal reasoning are applied effectively. 

![Steps in the causal inference process](image4)

The weight in the Weighted Decoding Response table significantly influences the generated response for the input "Yes, I'm studying law at the moment." At lower weights (e.g., -5.0), the response becomes nonsensical, as seen with the output "ONsvsscisvsivemsnivennvecnceuivass" [image1]. At a weight of 0.0, the response is generic and safe: "That sounds like a lot of fun!" As the weight increases to 3.0, the model generates a more specific and engaging response: "That sounds like a lot of fun. How long have you been studying?" However, at very high weights (e.g., 7.0 and 10.0), the output becomes incoherent or overly specific, such as "I majored in practising my spiritual full time philosophy test" or "Ohwow! Merna jean isa paino yi hao hui bu acara sya gila [...]" [image1]. This demonstrates that while moderate weights improve specificity and engagement, extreme weights can lead to nonsensical or inappropriate outputs, aligning with the findings that weighted decoding risks going off-distribution when the weight is too strong [2].

The function used to determine a probability distribution over the two warrants in the proposed architecture is the softmax function. The logits \( z_{0}^{(i)} \) and \( z_{1}^{(i)} \) are concatenated and passed through softmax to compute the probabilities:  
\[ \mathbf{p}^{(i)}\!\stackrel{\cdot}{=}\!\mathrm{softmax}\!\big([z_{0}^{(i)},z_{1}^{(i)}]\big). \]  
This results in a probability distribution over the two warrants, and the prediction is made by selecting the warrant with the highest probability: \( \hat{y}^{(i)}=\arg\operatorname*{max}_{j}\mathbf{p}^{(i)} \) [5].  

![BERT architecture for processing argument-warrant pairs](image2)

SenseBERT abstracts the role of "bass" in the sentence "Dan cooked a bass on the grill" by assigning it the supersense **noun.food**, indicating that "bass" is interpreted as a type of food in this context. ![SenseBERT interprets "bass" as noun.food in the sentence "Dan cooked a bass on the grill."](image4) 

This approach allows SenseBERT to generalize semantically similar notions even when they do not share the same phrasing, enhancing its ability to extract knowledge from training examples [4].

Retrieval Augmentation (RA) significantly impacts both accuracy and hallucination rates across Head, Torso, and Tail entity categories. The results from the ablation study, as shown in `![Retrieval Augmentation Impact](image4)`, demonstrate that RA consistently improves accuracy and reduces hallucination rates across all categories.

For **Head entities**, the accuracy increases from 24.4% to 27.1%, while hallucination rates decrease from 75.6% to 72.9%. The improvement in accuracy is modest, with a +11.1% gain, while hallucination rates see a -3.6% reduction. This indicates that RA provides some benefit even for more common entities.

In the **Torso category**, the impact is more pronounced. Accuracy rises from 19.1% to 22.7%, a +18.8% improvement, and hallucination rates drop from 80.9% to 17.3%, a significant -44% reduction. This highlights RA’s effectiveness in addressing challenges with moderately frequent entities.

The **Tail category** sees the most substantial improvement. Accuracy increases from 6.8% to 12.6%, a +85.3% gain, while hallucination rates decrease from 93.2% to 87.4%, a -6.2% reduction. This underscores RA’s critical role in mitigating hallucinations and improving accuracy for long-tail entities, which are often underrepresented in training data [4, 11]. 

Overall, RA proves to be a powerful tool, particularly for torso-to-tail entities, where it addresses the challenges of infrequent and fine-grained entities by leveraging external knowledge sources [10]. This is further supported by the ablation study, which shows that RA enhances performance across all metrics, especially for less common entities [9].

The triplet margin loss in the Translation Ranking model is used to optimize the embedding space by ensuring that the distance between the "better" hypothesis (\(h^{+}\)) and the anchors (source and reference) is smaller than the distance between the "worse" hypothesis (\(h^{-}\)) and the anchors by at least a margin \(\epsilon\) [10]. This encourages the model to learn a representation where higher-quality translations are closer to the source and reference in the embedding space, while lower-quality translations are pushed further away. 

![Triplet margin loss optimizes embedding space to distinguish better and worse hypotheses](image7)

By minimizing this loss, the model aligns the semantic feature space more effectively, improving its ability to rank translation hypotheses accurately based on their quality [5].

The 'Post-hoc Correction with External Feedback' strategy enhances the refinement of outputs by incorporating external models or tools to provide feedback after the initial generation. This process is iterative, allowing the language model to refine its outputs based on the feedback received. As depicted in image3, the external feedback is provided by models such as trained critics, code interpreters, or other tools, which evaluate and guide the refinement process. This approach ensures that the outputs are not only corrected but also improved in terms of factual accuracy, reasoning consistency, and overall quality [3][6][9].

![Post-hoc correction process using external feedback](image3)

The flexibility of post-hoc correction lies in its ability to utilize diverse feedback sources without requiring updates to the model parameters. This method is particularly useful in tasks like question answering, code generation, and fact-checking, where external knowledge or tools can significantly enhance the accuracy and reliability of the outputs [2][3][9]. The iterative nature of this strategy ensures that the final output meets the desired quality standards, making it a practical and effective approach for refining language model outputs.

Tree Traversal Retrieval and Collapsed Tree Retrieval are two distinct methods used by the RAPTOR model to retrieve information from its hierarchical tree structure. Here’s how they differ:

1. **Tree Traversal Retrieval**: This method traverses the tree layer-by-layer. It begins by selecting the top-k most relevant root nodes based on their cosine similarity to the query embedding. The process then continues to the children of these nodes, selecting the top-k nodes at each subsequent layer based on similarity to the query vector. This continues until leaf nodes are reached, and the text from all selected nodes is concatenated to form the retrieved context [7][8][9]. ![Tree Traversal Retrieval involves layer-by-layer node selection](image3)

2. **Collapsed Tree Retrieval**: In contrast, this method flattens the hierarchical tree into a single layer, treating all nodes as if they are on the same level. Instead of traversing layer-by-layer, it evaluates all nodes simultaneously to find the most relevant ones based on the query. This approach offers greater flexibility by not being constrained by the tree’s hierarchical structure [10][11]. ![Collapsed Tree Retrieval flattens the tree for simultaneous node evaluation](image3)

The key difference lies in the traversal strategy: Tree Traversal Retrieval is hierarchical and selective, while Collapsed Tree Retrieval is flat and comprehensive, often outperforming the former by retrieving information at the correct level of granularity for a given question [3]. ![Collapsed Tree Retrieval offers greater flexibility and performance](image4)

The DAE (Deterministic Autoencoder) and VAE (Variational Autoencoder) models exhibit distinct characteristics in their visualization of style and content spaces. The key differences are evident in the t-SNE plots, which reveal how sentences with different styles and content are distributed in the latent space.

In the style space, sentences with different styles are clearly separated for both DAE and VAE, as shown in the t-SNE plots. However, the latent space learned by the VAE is considerably smoother and more continuous compared to the DAE. This smoothness in the VAE's latent space is a result of its probabilistic framework, which imposes a distribution on the latent vector and penalizes the Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence for regularization [1] [8]. 

On the other hand, in the content space, sentences with different styles are indistinguishable for both models. This indicates that the content space is effectively disentangled from style, focusing solely on the semantic content of the sentences [8].

Here is the visualization of the style and content spaces for both models:

![Sentences with different styles are separated in the style space but indistinguishable in the content space](image1)

In summary, while both DAE and VAE achieve clear separation of styles in the style space, the VAE produces a smoother and more continuous latent space due to its probabilistic approach. Both models successfully disentangle content from style, as sentences with different styles are indistinguishable in the content space.

The purpose of the combination layers in Figure 2 is to merge the forward and backward representations generated by the two towers of the model to predict the center token. This is achieved through a self-attention module followed by a feed-forward network (FFN) block [5]. The self-attention module accesses information about the entire input surrounding the current target token, enabling the model to utilize context from both directions (left and right) for prediction [5]. 

For the base model, the forward and backward representations are summed, while in larger models, they are concatenated. The keys and values for the attention module are derived from these forward and backward states [5]. This combination mechanism ensures that the model has access to comprehensive contextual information, which is critical for tasks like named entity recognition (NER) and sentence classification [1][10]. 

![The combination layers merge forward and backward representations to predict the center token using a self-attention module and FFN block.](image6)

In summary, the combination layers integrate bidirectional context to enhance the model’s ability to predict tokens accurately during both training and fine-tuning for downstream tasks.

The supervised fine-tuning (SFT) dataset statistics directly influence the Chameleon model's inference strategy by ensuring balanced and high-quality training across diverse modalities, which is crucial for its mixed-modal capabilities. The dataset is divided into categories such as Text, Code, Visual Chat, Image Generation, Interleaved Text/Image Generation, and Safety, each targeting specific model capabilities and safety improvements [2][3].

For instance, the **Visual Chat** and **Interleaved Text/Image Generation** categories include high-quality data collected via third-party vendors, which ensures the model can effectively handle tasks requiring interleaved text and image inputs [4]. The **Image Generation** dataset is curated using an aesthetic classifier, focusing on high-quality images that align with the model's tokenizer resolution, enhancing the model's ability to generate visually appealing and contextually relevant images [6]. ![The dataset includes high-quality visual chat and interleaved text/image data for effective mixed-modal training](image5).

Balancing modalities during SFT is critical to prevent the model from developing biases toward a single modality, ensuring it can generate mixed-modal content appropriately [11]. This balance is reflected in the dataset statistics, which show substantial representation across text, images, and interleaved content, such as 16.9K samples for Interleaved Generation and 15.6K for Visual Chat [5].

Furthermore, the **Safety** category includes prompts designed to test and refine the model's ability to handle sensitive topics, ensuring safe and ethical outputs. This comprehensive approach to data curation directly supports Chameleon's inference strategy by enabling it to generate high-quality, balanced, and safe mixed-modal content [7].

In summary, the SFT dataset statistics reflect a strategic focus on modality balance, high-quality data, and safety, which are essential for Chameleon's ability to perform well in mixed-modal tasks like interleaved text and image generation.

The DETR model utilizes object queries as a crucial component in its transformer decoder architecture to predict object detections. These object queries are learned positional encodings that act as input embeddings to the decoder. Unlike traditional autoregressive models, DETR processes all object queries in parallel at each decoder layer, enabling the model to reason globally about all objects in the image simultaneously [5].

![Object queries are learned positional encodings passed to the decoder, enabling parallel processing](image5)

The object queries are transformed into output embeddings by the decoder, which are then independently decoded into box coordinates and class labels by a feed-forward network. By leveraging self-attention and encoder-decoder attention mechanisms, the model explores pairwise relations between objects while using the entire image as context [5]. This design allows DETR to predict the final set of detections directly, eliminating the need for hand-designed components like non-maximum suppression [2].

In summary, object queries in DETR serve as the mechanism for the decoder to generate unique predictions for each object in the image, enabling global reasoning and efficient parallel processing.

To calculate the average performance gap between ProgramFC and QACheck on the HOVER dataset, we first need the F1 scores for both systems across the two-hop, three-hop, and four-hop claims.

- Three-hop: 54.67 - 54.18 = 0.49

The average performance gap is calculated as:

The **background backoff variant** of the ScRNN (Semi-character Recurrent Neural Network) model performs best across all types of spelling errors. It achieves the lowest word error rate (WER) of **6.9%** in the "all" attack setting, which includes swap, drop, add, and keyboard errors. This represents a **32% relative error reduction** compared to the vanilla ScRNN model with a pass-through backoff strategy [6].

![The background backoff variant achieves the lowest WER at 6.9%.](image1)

Additionally, the background backoff variant consistently outperforms other methods, such as After The Deadline (ATD) and other backoff strategies, across various attack types. For example, it maintains lower error rates in swap (5.4%), drop (8.1%), add (6.4%), and keyboard (7.6%) errors compared to pass-through and neutral variants [image1].

![The background backoff variant outperforms ATD and other strategies across attacks.](image5)

This superior performance is attributed to its ability to handle unseen words in the test corpus by leveraging a larger background corpus, which contains 78K words compared to the foreground corpus’s 10K words [6]. Thus, the background backoff variant is the most effective spell-correction method for combating adversarial spelling errors.

The **Sythus** process for generating instruction-response pairs involves several steps, as outlined below:

1. **Step 1: Prompt Generation**  
   The process begins with the creation of prompts, which include **system messages** and **visual annotations**. System messages define the tone and style of the generated content, while visual annotations provide essential image information such as bounding boxes and descriptions to guide ChatGPT. Additionally, **in-context examples** are included to assist ChatGPT in learning within the context [4].

2. **Step 2: Instruction-Response Pair Generation**  
   Using the prompts, ChatGPT generates **instruction-response pairs** based on the provided visual context. This step ensures that the pairs are creative, diverse, and aligned with the visual content [4].

3. **Step 3: Filtering**  
   The generated instruction-response pairs are filtered to ensure quality and relevance. This step involves refining the pairs to meet the desired standards for training multi-modal models [4].

4. **Step 4: Translation**  
   The final step involves translating the instruction-response pairs from English into multiple languages, including **Chinese (zh)**, **Japanese (ja)**, **Spanish (es)**, **German (de)**, **French (fr)**, **Korean (ko)**, and **Arabic (ar)**. This ensures the dataset supports multi-lingual usage [4].

![Sythus process involves prompt generation, instruction-response pair generation, filtering, and translation](image2)  

This automated pipeline ensures the creation of high-quality, diverse, and multi-lingual instruction-response pairs for training robust multi-modal models.

The Translation Ranking model, as depicted in Figure 2, receives a tuple of four segments as input: the source text (`s`), a “better” hypothesis (`h⁺`), a “worse” hypothesis (`h⁻`), and the reference translation (`r`). These segments are independently encoded using a pretrained cross-lingual encoder and a pooling layer to generate sentence embeddings. The model then optimizes the embedding space using the triplet margin loss to minimize the distance between the “better” hypothesis and the anchors (source and reference) [1][4].

![Translation Ranking model architecture with inputs: source, reference, better hypothesis, and worse hypothesis](image1)

Relation extraction performance tends to improve as the number of entities in a sentence increases, especially when utilizing relation propagation. Figure 4 demonstrates this by showing relation scores as a function of the number of entities in a sentence for D Y GIE and D Y GIE without relation propagation on ACE05. The figure indicates that relation propagation achieves significant improvement in sentences with more entities, where broader context becomes more crucial for accurate extraction [1]. ![Relation propagation significantly improves performance in sentences with more entities](image7).

The dynamic span graph approach in D Y GIE enhances interaction across tasks, allowing the model to learn useful information from broader context, which is particularly beneficial for relation extraction [2]. This is further supported by the results in Table 2, where D Y GIE achieves substantial improvements on relation extraction tasks across multiple datasets, including ACE04 and ACE05, with relative improvements of 25.8% and 13.7%, respectively [5]. ![D Y GIE achieves state-of-the-art performance in relation extraction](image4).

Relation propagation operates by defining a beam of entity spans most likely to be involved in a relation and using a tensor to capture scores of each relation type. This process aggregates neighboring span representations on the relation graph, which helps in accurately predicting relations, especially in sentences with multiple entities [6]. The performance peaks at the second iteration of relation propagation, as shown in Figure 3b, indicating that the model effectively utilizes broader context within a few iterations [8]. ![Relation propagation achieves the best performance at the second iteration](image8).

In summary, relation extraction performance improves with the number of entities in a sentence, and relation propagation significantly enhances this performance by leveraging broader context, particularly in complex sentences with multiple entities.

When repetition control is introduced, it reduces the frequency of question-asking in generated text. For instance, setting `z=10` in conditional training (CT) is intended to produce 100% questions, but with repetition control, it only achieves a 79.67% question-asking rate. This limitation arises from weighted decoding’s `extrep bigram` feature, which discourages bigrams that have appeared in previous utterances. Since common question-related bigrams like "do you" or "what is" are often repeated across questions, the model avoids generating them, leading to fewer questions overall [10].

To address this, an adjusted setting, `z=10 (boost)`, is introduced, where the `extrep bigram` feature is not used during beam search but is applied afterward for reranking. This allows the model to produce necessary question-related bigrams, increasing the question-asking rate to 99.54%, albeit with a slight increase in external bigram repetition ![Repetition control reduces question-asking frequency by limiting common bigrams](image4).

The two methods introduced in Figure 3, LSTUR-ini and LSTUR-con, differ in how they integrate long-term and short-term user representations for unified user modeling. 

The first method, **LSTUR-ini**, uses the long-term user representation (LTUR) to initialize the hidden state of the GRU network in the short-term user representation (STUR) model. This approach leverages the long-term preferences of users as a foundation for capturing their short-term interests, which are then updated through the GRU network. The final user representation is derived from the last hidden state of the GRU network [2].

![LSTUR-ini method initializes GRU's hidden state with LTUR.](image2_a)

In contrast, the second method, **LSTUR-con**, concatenates the long-term user representation with the short-term user representation to form the final user vector. This method ensures that both long-term preferences and short-term interests are directly combined, retaining all information from both representations [2]. 

![LSTUR-con method concatenates LTUR and STUR as a unified vector.](image2_b)

Both methods are effective in improving news recommendation performance, but experiments show that LSTUR-con tends to be more stable, as it preserves all information from both representations without relying on a sequential update process [6].

The Iterative, Recursive, and Adaptive retrieval processes in Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) systems differ in their approaches to enhancing retrieval quality and relevance:

1. **Iterative Retrieval**: This process involves multiple retrieval iterations, where the model refines its search based on previous results. For instance, ITER-RETGEN [14] synergizes retrieval-enhanced generation with generation-enhanced retrieval to improve contextual knowledge and response quality in subsequent iterations [3]. ![Iterative retrieval involves refining search through multiple iterations](image2)

2. **Recursive Retrieval**: This method uses a hierarchical approach to retrieve data, often summarizing sections of a document before performing secondary, more refined searches. It is particularly useful for complex scenarios where user needs are nuanced or ambiguous. For example, recursive retrieval can involve creating a clarification tree to optimize ambiguous queries [4]. ![Recursive retrieval involves hierarchical and refined searches](image2)

3. **Adaptive Retrieval**: This approach allows the system to dynamically decide when and what to retrieve based on the context. Techniques like Flare [24] and Self-RAG [25] enable LLMs to actively determine the optimal moments for retrieval, improving efficiency and relevance [12]. ![Adaptive retrieval dynamically adjusts retrieval timing and content](image2)

In summary, iterative retrieval focuses on refining results through multiple passes, recursive retrieval uses a hierarchical approach to deepen search relevance, and adaptive retrieval dynamically adjusts retrieval based on context.

Adversarial training significantly impacts model performance, as demonstrated by the evaluation data. When the model is trained on adversarial distractors, its accuracy on the original distractors drops from 67.08 F1 to 59.12 F1, indicating that adversarial training introduces a shift in the distribution of distractors that the model must adapt to [1][7]. ![Model performance comparison](image2) However, when the same model is re-trained on adversarial distractors, its accuracy on adversarial distractors increases from 46.84 F1 to 60.10 F1, showing that the model can recover much of its original performance when adapted to the new distribution [3][7]. Further, when adversarial distractors are filtered by entity type, the model’s accuracy drops to 40.73 F1 on the original distractors but increases to 58.42 F1 on the adversarial distractors with filtering, highlighting both the challenge and adaptability of the model under more constrained adversarial conditions [2][7]. These results suggest that while adversarial training initially degrades performance, re-training on adversarial examples enables the model to adapt and recover much of its original accuracy.

The inclusion of gold paragraphs and distractors significantly impacts the F1 scores in multi-hop question answering models. When gold paragraphs are included, the model’s performance improves substantially. For example, in the open-domain setting, single-paragraph BERT achieves an F1 score of 53.12 when additional gold paragraphs are provided, compared to 39.12 F1 without them [5]. This highlights the critical role of accurate retrieval systems in ensuring that the model has access to relevant evidence.

Distractors, on the other hand, can degrade model performance, especially when they are weak or lack diversity. In the HOTPOT QA distractor setting, single-paragraph BERT achieves 67.08 F1, but this drops to 46.84 F1 when adversarial distractors are introduced [2]. However, re-training the model on these adversarial distractors allows it to recover some of its accuracy, reaching 60.10 F1 [2]. This suggests that while distractors can initially hinder performance, models can adapt to new distributions of distractors through re-training.

![The inclusion of gold paragraphs raises F1 scores significantly.](image4)

The use of type-filtered distractors, where only paragraphs matching the entity type of the gold paragraphs are included, further reduces the model’s accuracy to 40.73 F1. Yet, re-training on adversarially selected distractors improves this to 58.42 F1 [8]. This indicates that even sophisticated distractor selection methods can limit performance unless the model is specifically trained to handle them.

![Adversarial distractors initially lower F1 but re-training can restore performance.](image2)

These findings underscore the importance of both retrieval quality and distractor design in multi-hop question answering. Models struggle when gold paragraphs are not retrieved, and even when they are, poorly chosen distractors can reduce effectiveness. Future work should focus on developing better retrieval methods and more challenging distractor sets to improve model robustness and accuracy.

In summary, gold paragraphs enhance F1 scores by providing relevant evidence, while distractors can lower scores unless the model is re-trained to adapt to their distribution. This highlights the need for improved retrieval systems and distractor selection in advancing multi-hop question answering models.

In Figure 4, the components marked as 'Word LSTM-B' and 'Word LSTM-F' represent bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) layers that process word representations in a named entity recognition (NER) model. 'Word LSTM-B' stands for the backward LSTM, which processes the sequence from the end to the beginning, capturing dependencies in the reverse direction. 'Word LSTM-F' stands for the forward LSTM, which processes the sequence from the beginning to the end, capturing dependencies in the forward direction. Together, these bidirectional LSTMs allow the model to incorporate context from both past and future words, enhancing its ability to predict named entities accurately. ![Word LSTMs capture bidirectional context for word representations](image5).
